description:
This place is awesome. Not only is the hummus fresh and creamy, it's also one of the best in the city. I love the atmosphere and the small feeling to it, and the way they've managed to fit all the tables in. It gets super busy even on a random Thursday night! So that might be the only reason you have to wait a little bit otherwise the service is great. The food is amazing I have had a few of the apps and the wraps are always a very great and filling bet. 
The haloumi cheese appetizer is probably my favorite and really like the hummus with it as a complement. 
I also really like how nice the people are here. I left the 2nd half of my wrap in the to go container and forgot it on my table. I was a few blocks away when I realized and ran back but they had just thrown it away. They were so nice to make me a new one to take home with me.
author: Ian S.

description:
The vibe is that of a relaxed cafe with mellow  jazz type of music in the background...you aren't quite transported the way some places can manage with the decor, smells and sounds...there was actually a funny, not appealing smell when I walked in. 

Service is unfortunately neither warm or memorable...

I wanted to try the lamb and okra, a salad and hummus planning to take some food home but got told that's too much food! my bad -oink!

The tabouli salad was fresh and lemony the way I like it. 
The lamb dish with okra flavor profile overpoweringly salty,  and this is coming from an admitted salt-a-holic. I asked for a side of the yogurt sauce to cut the flavor. It was nice to try something different but I would forgo if I came back for another round. 

The coffee was tasty.

Overall, a solid corner place for some Lebanese food.

Maybe next time I'll come with someone so I can order more to try ;)
author: Cyntia Q.

description:
Eh. The food was pretty good, and not terribly overpriced by SF standards.
But nothing about this place really stood out, and if anything, the mediocre service brought this down to 3 stars.

We got quite a few things -- the spicy hummus with pita, the fried potatoes (hard to go wrong), the eggplant, both of the Lebanese "pizzas", and some chicken shwarma. (They were out of lamb shwarma...at 6pm, I guess.)

The food was tasty albeit oily, but all the bread things just felt over-toasted? All the chewiness in the breads had turned into a crispy crunch which wasn't bad, but not at all what I expected from pita.

The service was surprisingly cold, and we had the waitress walk by us a few times without acknowledging our attempts to get her attention.

I want to give this place another chance because of all the great reviews, so I hope next time is better.
author: Gautam G.

description:
I came here because my Uber driver recommended this place as an authentic spot for Lebanese food.

After trying the platter, I recommend ordering three items: fatet batinjan (fried eggplant with baked pita), cauliflower, and hummus with beef

I like that the pita bread is warm, and the five stars are mostly because fatet batinjan is so good.
author: Andrea T.

description: A friend and I walk into this restaurant and we are excited because it's not busy yet. We choose our seats. As soon as we sit down there is this rank smell. It smelled like sewer and cleaning products.....nausea....We moved seats and the server advised that there were no windows in the back so there wasn't any ventilation. We ordered a few dishes to share. The food was good but not delicious. We ordered a dish that was ground beef and lamb meatballs with potatoes simmered in tomatoes sauce. Tell my why we only got 3 small meatballs and this dish was 18.00. I am still trying to figure out what did we pay for. I have been wanting to go here so I finally was able to see for myself.
author: Stacie J.

description:
I was excited when I saw the majority of the reviews but I was not very impressed.
First of, the place is perfectly situated, well decorated and has a friendly staff.
Second, their selection is nice and not typical of all the Lebanese restaurants.

The Good:
Ouzi,
Hummus,
Hummus with beef,
battata harra
grape leaves

The Not so good:
tabbouli - had ZERO flavour. I love tabbouli and was very dissapointed
Mazzat salad - also disappointing in the flavor department 
shawarma - not good 

I had visited this place couple of years back and it was better, not sure if the recipes or chef changed
author: Jad A.

description:
Returned after nearly seven years to the same spot. Glad to see it's holding up.

Review stands at 3 stars or A-OK.

What holds +'s:
+ Service still attentive and prompt
+ For $20 you can share with two others and get three hot and three cold mezes

What falters -'s:
- Menu is nearly all vegetarian except for the ouzi which has indiscernible bits of ground lamb buried in rice
- It's not the most memorable meal. And if my taste buds lie then the two Lebanese diners even said the food was just ok.
author: Yiven C.

description:
Things I was unaware of before dining at Mazzat:

1) Lebanese food is delicious.
2) Lebanese food is vegetarian friendly.
3) Lebanese food is (relatively) healthy.
4) I need to come to Mazzat on an empty stomach.

Behold, vegetarians, there is amazing Lebanese food waiting for you at Mazzat! We came here on a whim and will easily be adding it to our "nah, let's go somewhere we know an love" list of San Francisco restaurants.

The Mazzat Platter (as other Yelp reviews will tell you) is the way to go, and takes your dollar the furthest. You can select three cold Mazzat of which I recommend:

1) the Hummus Harr - delicious homemade hummus with a little something extra;
2) the Labne - cheese with incredibly zesty zaater; and
3) the Babaghanouge - roasted eggplant with tahini, garlic, and other flavors.

And you can select three warm Mazzat, of which I recommend:

1) Fatet Batinjan - my goodness, this is amazing. The pita croutons give this fried eggplant an extra crisp to it. If I could, I'd order three of these;
2) Foul Madummas - fava beans with garlic and olive oil; and
3) Halloumi Cheese - who can say no to Halloumi cheese?

But, to be fair, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The Zaatar Pita (Thyme) is also a delicious entree choice, as well as the lentil soup (made for vegans!)

I cannot emphasize enough how much I love, LOVE, that Mazzat has so many options for vegetarians. Come here for date night, come here with friends - this cozy and adorable restaurant will fill your soul and fill your stomach.
author: Sejal D.

description:
I had the pleasure of enjoying a wonderful dinner at Mazzat while down in the Bay celebrating a friend's birthday. He made reservations for 8 of us at 8 PM on a Saturday night - it was a good thing he made reservations, as the place was packed. We were seated right away and the service throughout our way was phenomenal. 

We opted to do their $20/per person special which included our choice of 3 hot and 3 cold dishes for the table to share (every person at the table must agree to do this deal or else you can't do it). The best part: they scale their portion size for the size of the party. Although there were 8 of us, everyone got to try every single dish and there was enough for seconds (and even thirds!). 

All of the food was outstanding. I don't recall every dish we ordered but I remember loving all of them. The fried cheese and hummus with beef were two of my favorites. And the servers kept bringing fresh, warm pita when we ran out. The whole experience was tremendous. I only wish I lived closer to Mazzat to come to eat here more often.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Mazzat is a cozy little Lebanese restaurant just off the major foot traffic of Hayes. Our party of 3 was seated in less than 30 minutes on a Friday night, which is unheard of in Hayes! The menu is really expansive as well with options that are both vegetarian and carnivore friendly. 

The staple that we order every time is the batata harra (these spicy fried potatoes that are meant to share but I can totally finish by myself). It's a huge hit with anybody I go with! The classic hummus is also great, and it comes with a super fluffy pita that rivals Oren's Hummus Shop down in South Bay. 

The staff is also so cheery, and the service is quick. It's a great place to go for solid Lebanese food!
author: Denise L.

description: If you love tapas, you will love this place!  It's a cute little place in Hayes Valley that serves delicious Mediterrean food.  There is a sampler for $20 a person where you can choose 3 hot dishes and 3 cold dishes.  With most dishes ranging from $8-10, this is the best bang for your buck!  Vegetarians would go nuts for this place as most dishes offered are vegetarian and even though I am not a vegetarian, I would totally consider it after this place.  Warm pita is served with the dishes and serves as a wonderful vessel for all the wonderful food.  Would highly recommend the egg plant with fried pita chips on top, so flavorful and probably my favorite dish.  There is a hot potato dish that was delicious, had a little kick but not too spicy.  Would recommend the olives and pickled veggies as it added a nice crisp coolness to everything else we were eating.  Honestly I don't think you could go wrong with any dish here, I hope you like egg plant because most dishes are egg plant based.  I think 4 out of the 6 dishes we ordered were egg plant!  It was a delightful dinner and it was also nice because it was not heavy.  Definitely will come back to eat here!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Review is for food alone because oh my goodness was it delicious.  We arrived straight from the airport and were both hungry and a little tired.  We managed to get a table in the cozy restaurant and quickly decided on the shared mezze platter of hot and cold mezzes.  The selections were abundant and difficult to chose but I don't think you could make a bad choice.  

Fried cauliflower
Roasted eggplant with fried pita and yogurt sauce
Tabbouleh
Hummus with beef
Salad with feta and tomatoes
And something else equally delicious

Everything was so good and the whole platter was a great deal and very flavorful. Replenished pita when needed and the staff were friendly and hospitable.  I would certainly come back when in the SF area.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
TLDR - Neighborhood gem for Lebanese/Middle Eastern food. Get the Mazzat Platter for a good sampling

Came here on a Monday night around 8:15PM and it was quite busy! The space is small but has a nice atmosphere. They have a Mazzat Platter option, which includes 3 cold mazzat and 3 hot mazzat for $20/person. The platter sounds like a great way to get a taste of a variety of mazzat without spending a ton, but since we had 4 people, we figured we'd order things a-la-carte and get 7 dishes for less.

Everything was pretty good but I'd definitely recommend the Babaghanouge if you like roasted eggplant and the Arnabeet if you like cauliflower

--- COLD MAZZAT ---
* BABAGHANOUGE ($8) - 5/5
[roasted eggplant, tahini, garlic, lemon juice, parsley olive oil]
Smokey, creamy and rich

* MUTABAL ($9) - 4/5
[smoked/roasted eggplant, peppers, tomatoes, parsley, lemon juice, olive oil with a hint of pomegranate sauce]
tangy eggplant 

* MAKDOUS ($8) - 3/5
[tangy stuffed eggplant with walnuts, red pepper, garlic, olive oil]
Reminded me of pickled olives. A little too sour for me.

--- HOT MAZZAT ---
* ARNABEET ($10) - 5/5
[fried cauliflower, garlic, lemon juice]
Yumm. Tender and tangy

* BATATA HARRA ($9) - 4/5
[fried potatoes, chili peppers, cilantro, garlic, lemon juice]
Potatoes were tender. Nice flavor - a little tangy, a little spicy

* HUMMUS WITH BEEF ($10) - 4.5/5
[hummus topped with marinated beef and pine nuts]
The hummus itself was amazing. Very creamy, not at all grainy, and a little richer than your average hummus. The beef gave it more of a savory touch.

* OUZI ($10) - 3/5
[jasmine rice cooked, ground lamb and beef, pine nuts, almonds]
Rice was tender soft but overall not super special
author: Jessie L.

description: This place is fabulous! We ordered a few small plates and a bottle of rose and had a lovely time. Food was excellent. Service was excellent. It's a pretty small venue so try and get there when it's not busy.
author: David R.

description:
I'll be honest... I've had Mazzat bookmarked in Yelp for awhile and had never dined there before this week. What a mistake!

Mazzat is definitely a go-to in Hayes Valley. The restaurant, itself, has an elegant yet cozy vibe to it. The service is attentive but servers do not hover. And the food is so so tasty! My group started out with Khyar Blaban (cold yogurt and pita) - it was great. We also had the Halloumi Cheese starter - DELICIOUS. The Kafta was seasoned perfectly and I would definitely order it again. Overall, Mazzat is a wonderful spot and I can't wait to return again soon.
author: Katie C.

description: Food was fine and service was ok - nothing to rave about though. Lots of dips and hummus variations. Somewhat pricey for the quality.
author: Matthew S.

description: Perfect spot for a happy hour with a friend. Everything we eat was delicious. The 6 appetizer platter is plenty for 2 people for dinner!
author: Paterson W.

description:
I'm a fan for sure! Came here with my boyfriend and his mother to have a sit-down dinner. We ordered the mazzat special, which comes with 3 cold and 3 hot dishes. They gave us some recommendations. We were completely lost on what to order, but the staff were helpful and patient. Amongst the 3 of us, the food was too much, but it was delicious nevertheless. My boyfriend's mother never had Lebanese food, so this was a eye-opening experience for her. 

The only complaint I have is that the service was extremely slow. We sat near the entrance, which was further away from the waitresses. Trying to get their attention was difficult and asking for simple things, like water or the bill took way too long.
author: Emily F.

description:
Charming restaurant in the Hayes area of San Francisco. We came here on a Friday night with reservations for 845. When we got there this quaint restaurant was packed and we were told it would be 5 minutes. 15 minutes later (we had to wait outside because it was so small) and we finally got seated.

Once seated, it took ten minutes for them to come over and take out orders. They were super nice and had good recommendations for us. Took 30 minutes to get our food :/

The restaurant is really cute and is great for a date night or a group dinner. A little loud bc everyone is so close together.

The reason they get 4 stars is because the food is REALLY good! Unique flavors and a really large menus to choose from. Perfect place to get many different dishes to share.

I thought it was a great place. As long as you have a little patience, it will be worth it!
author: Brock G.

description:
Mazzat is a little known corner restaurant on Laguna that seemed exciting and enticing when walking in.

We were a group of 3 and started off by going for a set of mezze for the table. We started off with the hummus harra, which was fantastic. Creamy and fresh, it had the right balance of flavors and texture.

However, that was the only thing that was good here. We got the halloumi cheese, which was old and definitely not fresh. We also ordered the batata Harara, which while having flavor, were dry. The green bean dish was absolutely flavorless, the beans were from a can and this was barely edible.

The last thing we ordered was the fattoush salad, which was plated very well, but ended up being sweet. Never in my life have I had a sweet fattoush, which was due to the fact of the addition of balsamic vinaigrette to the salad.

Overall, the place was very average and I would come again only for the hummus.
author: Anubhav J.

description:
One of our go to places before the symphony or opera. Reasonably priced, quality food is getting harder to find in Hayes Valley, which has become semi-chic over the last twenty years. 

Mazzat is a casual Lebanese restaurant. Service is fast and friendly. Their hummus is excellent. We order the same thing every time, the pick six items platter. Their smoked eggplant is especially tasty. The wine list is decent and the wines aren't expensive. It's a cute place and going here means we get to walk off our meal on the way to the music.
author: Stuart R.

description:
The food was really good, and the staff were friendly. However, I am currently hunting for the most authentic Lebanese restaurant in town, and this one isn't as authentic as you can be abroad. 
It still is delicious food, they have the main mezzes and main courses you would expect in a Lebanese restaurant, but some important items were missing (Where are the cheese rolls?). 
They have a great selection of Lebanese wine, which was so refreshing. The atmosphere was lovely, and the food was good.
author: Riham B.

description:
The food here is incredible! I've been here many times, both just with one friend and with a larger group, and it's always on point. However, the service makes the experience fall flat. We always have to flag down a waiter to ask for more water and pita, and sometimes those refills don't come. The waiters also aren't particularly friendly. A smile and friendly conversation could go a long way.

Also one time, we made a reservation for 7, and when we showed up at the specified time, they had no table for us. They couldn't tell us how long the wait would be either, and we ended up waiting 30 minutes past the reservation time for our table.

TLDR: Food is incredible. Service is not great.
author: Megan M.

description:
Good food, bad service. 
We were seated by the window, which was partly open and as day turned to evening, it became windy and cold. I slid the window shut, and a few minutes later, the waiter came over, put his elbow in my face (reaching in between my friend and I) while he opened the window and walked away without saying a word. He was also pretty short with us when taking our order.
I ordered the Basia, and it was very good, but there were only a few chunks of actual meat in there, for $18. My food came out an awkwardly long time after my friend's food, to the point that he felt bad continuing to eat. Also, nothing came out hot. It was all lukewarm.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I came here for dinner last Saturday. They were able to get us in with only a 30 minute wait which was nice because everywhere else was at least 1 hour+.

I love wine and was excited to try Lebanese wine. I got the petite nior which was very smooth and easy to drink. Additionally, the pour , two thumbs up! Let's just say I always have at least 2 glasses of wine when I'm out for dinner and I only needed to order one. 

My boyfriend and I shared the falafel appetizer which was very pleasing. I find that many places, the falafel is dry and overloaded with caraway seeds. These were moist and flavorful. For our entree my boyfriend got Bamia and me, the Kabsseh. My entree was quite delicious, chicken thighs were moist and well seasoned as well as a nice rice medley. However, my boyfriends Bamia was actually quite bland. The lamb was well cooked but okra was overdone and it lacked seasoning. His left overs the following day with added cumin plus salt and pepper, made the dish much more tasty. Maybe  it was just a bad batch. 

The service was so-so. I have a thing (because I'm a former server) about "pre-bussing". If we are stacking old plates on the table and the server comes over but doesn't grab them, that drives me insane. Beyond the lack of table cleanliness, the staff was friendly. 

Would try happy hour.
author: Katlyn H.

description:
This Lebanese restaurant is in a great part of Hayes Valley. I came here with some coworkers for dinner and I was not disappointed.

Although the wait staff was a bit slow to serve us, the quality and the portion of the food really made up for it.

For appetizers, I tried the humus as well as the potatoes with chili sauce over it. It had a bit of a kick but was really tasty. 

I tried the Kabsse, which was served in a bowl with meatballs cooked in a nice tomato sauce. They give you a side of rice which I put over it and it was so filling!

Overall: price- on the high end, portion size- appetizers on the small side, entrées good portions.

This was a great experience and I would definitely come back.
author: Jeremiah Z.

description:
This is a great place and a real neighborhood restaurant, not one of those fake "neighborhood places" where to get a table you either have to reserve a month in advance or wait in line for an hour and a half on the sidewalk.
Here you get in, there are tables available right away, people are friendly and nice and the dishes are super-good! No frills, none of that attitude: ahh, here we are the best of this of that. Just normal people running an excellent restaurant and taking care of normal customers. So nice :)
author: Luca R.

description: 20% Mandatory tipping for 4 or more, ridiculous. Got to the restaurant 930 pm and the waitress was rushing us to eat fast because they were going to close in 30 mins
author: German D.

description:
Great place, really cute! Ordered a bunch of the hot and cold apps, all of which were great except for the halloumi cheese which was extremely salty. I'd recommend getting the mazzat platter next time which allows you to pick and choose a total of 6 dishes (3 cold, 3 hot). 

Next time I'll be sure to try the falafel.
author: Brynn K.

description:
I really enjoyed Mazzat! We were a little disappointed that in order to get a starter platter it was like $20 per person and everyonr had to get it. We just wanted to try a bunch of stuff with smaller options but want really an option. 

That said, the food we did order was fantastic! My friend ordered the Kafta wrap, I got the Bamia dinner, and we shared an order of Halloumi cheese. The wrap was super big, she could only finish half, and the Bamia was still decent sized where I barely finished mine. So good portion and great flavors! 

Wait staff and the ambience were great! It's pretty casual but still had a good ambience. 

Overall, really great! And I can't wait to come by again and try some different dishes :)
author: Brandon P.

description: The friendly service and delicious platters of food are the reasons to visit Mazzat, a casual, affordable Lebanese restaurant near Hayes Valley. Coming for dinner, we were seated right away, and the plethora of "Mazzat" dishes looked so appealing, that we decided to make a meal out of the Mazzat platter, a combination of 3 cold and 3 hot appetizers for $20/person. The spicy hummus harr was smooth and tasty (though a bit on the watery side), the labne (yogurt cheese) was thick and creamy, and both of these went so well with the basket of pita bread on the side. The ouzi was a delicious rice dish (with a yogurt/cucumber sauce on the side) mixed with ground beef and lamb, and it had a very distinct cinnamony flavor from the spices. I was a big fan of the Mazzat salad, a simple combination of feta, parsley, and tomatoes. The fatet batinjan (fried eggplant in yogurt sauce with pita croutons) I found rather flavorless, and the arnabeet (fried cauliflower) was unfortunately soggy and overcooked. In addition to the platter, we also ordered the za'atar pita, a delicious flatbread covered with a ton of za'atar (thyme/sesame/olive oil). The portion sizes were all extremely generous, and we had plenty of leftovers to take home. Overall, this was a great value restaurant offering some delicious home-style food!
author: David K.

description: This is a really cool little sidewalk restaurant with a nice atmosphere inside.  Menu is very specific to food from the Levant and in specific appetizer plates or tapas style dishes (hot and cold).  We had a couple good plates of this to start mostly featuring eggplant varieties and then had a couple traditional main courses - the Kafta and the Lamb/Okra grilled in tomato based curry.  Both were good and the meat cooked very well but lacking in salt.  The Kafta has more spices in the meat and waste better of the two.  We also shared a Lebanese pizza that was very different and very tasty.  Service was good and the experience was unique as you don't see a lot of these dishes featured on menus.  Prices are very reasonable too.  Family of 4 ate till we were  full and total bill was under $75.
author: Shankar S.

description:
Worse service EVER!

We've been there many times: the food is not great but good enough to come back. Generally the service is decent.

Last night (Thursday 9/21), we arrived and a nice young lady seats us by the door, on a high-top 2 seaters. 5 minutes later (if not more), a man calling himself "the host" comes to tell us we cannot sit there because the table is reserved and if we want another table we will have to wait for a while. He also tells us that the person who sat us "doesn't know what she is doing because she is not the host". Wow, this is bad.

Questions to Mazzat: 
1) If this rude guy is the host, why wasn't he doing is job when we arrived?
2) Since when do you take reservation for 2?
3) Is saying out loud that your colleague "doesn't know what she is doing" a respectful way to talk about the staff? 
4) Do you think it's good customer service?

There are plenty of options in the Hayes Valley and I'll bring my money elsewhere.
author: Lili G.

description:
This place is a gem! The food is top notch. I love Mediterranean food in general, but this place takes the cake for quality food. Everything we got was so good, it's hard to say what's best. We got the hummus, patatas, roasted eggplant, and the chicken thighs entree. We shared everything and were more than stuffed by the end. 

Unfortunately, the service wasn't fantastic as they were a little slow, but overall a great experience. The place is small and can get kind of loud but it was still enjoyable nonetheless. Definitely a good spot for some different food!
author: Tiffany F.

description:
I loved food and service here the first couple of times I dined at this place. However, last time, in spite of making a reservation we were not given a table for a long time and to make things worse the receptionist was pretty rude to us. 

I am definitely not going here again! I hope the service does improve though.

Also, online reservations through Opentable did not work for this particular place and when you call them at 4pm (the time when they open) no one responds to the calls until after 4.30pm.
author: Shalini O.

description:
This place is a neighborhood gem. 

We've been exploring the menu and each dish served has been exactly as described, and yet to disappoint. 

It's affordable, it's authentic, it's delicious. (Psst! Know what?: it's better than Chez Maman). 

Places like these must conquer the gentrified sameness of hipster menus chock full of roasted Brussels sprouts and kale salads. 

Really good. The kitchen cares. Try it.
author: Angela K.

description: There is better Mediterranean food out there. I didn't enjoy the chicken shawarma wrap as much as I hoped.
author: G G.

description:
If you could read between the lines of this review what you'd understand is that I liked this restaurant in spite of eating nothing particularly remarkable or memorable here.  I liked it even though a couple of the 6 Mazzats sampled weren't very good and the other four were only decent.  I liked it regardless of the fact that there wasn't a single thing I (or anyone at my table) raved over.  

That's saying something.  

What I liked about it - and why I'd even return to it - is this:

*  A $45 bottle of Lebanese red wine was quite perfect

*  The Mazzat Platter ($20/person) was a nice shared dish that allowed us to sample 6 different menu items (3 hot/3 cold) of our choice.  I like trying a lot of things. 

*  Though the food wasn't best in class I found it both satisfying and well-priced.  

*  The service was mellow and excellent.  On a weeknight three of us walked in and pretty much held down our table for the entire evening with no pressure to move along or purchase  more.  

Hey look, you didn't even need to read between the lines.  

Mazzat is a good place from which to enjoy wine and food, less a destination restaurant than one that's good enough for a weeknight with friends.  It's a bit away from the crowds of Hayes Street but near enough that it wouldn't be a bad place to dine before or after a Civic Center event.  Add it to your list of "maybes" for those times you're in that area looking for something that's good enough.
author: Tracey A.

description: Excellent Lebanese cuisine. We went with a group of 5 and shared all the dishes. The babaganoush, haloomi cheese were excellent. The meat dishes were good as well. The baclava was ok but the Turkish coffee presentation made up for it. Service was attentive and friendly. We only wished they served cocktails and bubblies.
author: Tina C.

description: Get the $20 each platters! You get so much yummy food. Favorites are the hummus and cauliflower.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Came here with some friends after bar hopping in the area 

Kabsseh - the blend of sweet/savory in the rice did not resonate with me, as for the chicken it was fine (not as moist as I would have liked) and overall didn't enjoy the dish

For $18, the dish was simply not worth the price

Overall Thoughts

I'll have to return again and order better to see if it changes my feelings
author: Eddie W.
Aryn C.

description: 2 stars because my dish, the falafel wrap was delicious but unfortunately my partners order never arrived. He ordered the chicken shawarma wrap. The waiter apparently didn't hear the wrap part and we received a different dish by a different waitress.  When we told her about the mix-up she told us the correct order would be out in a few minutes. 10 minutes later and no sign of the wrap, we see the same wrong dish at the kitchen counter and the waitress arguing with the kitchen staff. We assume they made the wrong dish again. The waitress doesn't come by with an update or apology. We flag down the original waiter and he says "oh you guys canceled the first dish." We explain the mixup and his response, "we make dishes according to when they're received...". No apology. At this point we give up. We pay for my meal and walk out totally disappointed by the experience.
author: Anita P.

description: Every once in a while I get excited about a new place I try. I was excited to try this place. Unfortunately they screwed up a to go order and I didn't realize until I got home a half hour later. I think there was a new guy working. It could have been a misunderstanding but that would be a stretch. Besides the location, the other great food in the area and really unsatisfactory service available to resolve my order (they didn't really try to help me) this place might be okay. I'll never go back, I'll never suggest it to anyone and I'll name 10 places that are better if anyone ever asks me. Just being honest about a horrible experiance.
author: Ben M.

description:
Is it wrong that when I think of this place that I have this immature desire to call it 'Hazmat'? Yeah I know that's wrong in so many ways, but it just comes out of my mouth without warning much like everything else I say. However, my malaprop didn't dampen my long-standing desire to try this unassuming place on the corner of Fell and Laguna because I'm always on the lookout for interesting Middle Eastern fare in this city. Tuba and Anar are good, so is Wally's Cafe in Emeryville which serves Lebanese specialties, too. I didn't know Mazzat was owned by the same folks who own Mazza Luna on Van Ness, which was too dark and clubby for my taste (review: http://bit.ly/1Qv2i0Z).

Mazzat is also on the dark side but with a bit more family-friendly vibe given the diners I saw when I entered the place early on a Thursday evening. Usually it looks packed in the compact space, but it was more inviting with just a couple of tables occupied. I was seated closer to the back where it was pretty quiet, but that didn't stop the server from being quite attentive. there were a lot of appetizing choices in the menu though it was a bit pricier than I expected. I started modestly with the $8 serving of Lentil Soup which was rich and delicious, almost like a cream of mushroom soup but purely vegan (photo: http://bit.ly/1TwnPvr). It came with a generous supply of grilled pita bread that I found hard to resist (photo: http://bit.ly/1RYkntM).

For my entree, I went with the $18 Bamia, which was a velvety-looking stew with sauteed green okra and bits of lamb swimming in a shimmering, darkened tomato sauce mixed with fried garlic (photo: http://bit.ly/1oEmXdb). It was tasty though probably more saucy than I was wanting for a main dish. It was helpful that it came with a good portion of jasmine rice on the side, which I promptly scooped up and dunked into the stew in spoonfuls like it was a Japanese curry dish (photo: http://bit.ly/1Qzc74d). It was solid country-style food nicely presented though nothing that fancy. I'd definitely recommend it those on the flexitarian side who don't want a lot of meat for dinner but plenty of familiar Middle Eastern flavors.

FOOD - 4 stars...tasty, unadorned Lebanese dishes for a hearty appetite
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...comfortable enough when they aren't busy but kinda dark
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive considering the other parties were high maintenance
TOTAL - 4 stars...OK, I'll stop calling it 'Hazmat' now
author: Ed U.

description:
I stopped by here with my girlfriend to grab a bite to eat. I ended up arriving a few minutes ahead of her and they seated me promptly, which was nice of them considering the whole party wasn't at the restaurant at the time.

We ended up ordering the Halloumi cheese, the hummus with beef, and the Kafta, which is ground beef and lamb cooked in a tomato sauce with a number of spices and served with rice. 

The food here was scrumptious, and I in particular enjoyed the Halloumi cheese, which is grilled and just slightly melted before serving. Definitely would recommend. 

Service here was a little slow considering the amount of people in the restaurant, but the food is well prepared and a good value. 

I haven't had a chance to come back and try the starter platter, but would like to!
author: Chet A.

description:
Amazing! My dad and I had the 20-per person sampler platter with 3 hot dishes and three cold. We had the hummus and beef, goat cheese salad, olives and pickled veggies, more hummus, rice and lamb, and something else but it was probably really good lol. 

But yeah, they were awesome. The waitress was so nice and put a smile on our face! I would definitely go back :)
author: Devin C.

description: Amazing. We got the sampler for $20. 3 hot and 3 cold sides. Each was incredible. I particularly loved the Halumi.
author: Charles H.

description: Nice quite place, we tried mezza platter with my wife. All was good. Service was nice and on time.
author: Alper B.

description: Delicious Lebanese food and excellent service. We got the dish sampler for 2 to have the option to try a lot of their sides. And the cheeses!!!!! Must have
author: Ingrid O.
Allie H.

description: Mazzat didn't live up to expectations. The service was good, but the food was bland and lukewarm. We had two of their appetizers and drinks, having stopped there for a quick pre-dinner bite. We ordered the rice dish and the kibbe (sp?). We thought both lacked flavor.
author: S G.

description:
Server was Lisa; would've been sick as heezy if bro who poured my water was Bart. Right? Tell me that wouldn't be #freshtodeath. Plus a line cook up in the back named Burns. And some loudazz mzafza called Sideshow. #fahgettaboudit I'd be eating here every week.

Love when restos let me #yolosolo order dishes specifically intended for multiple people. Flyllaxin katamari damacy-esque "lounge moderne" x smoo jazz tunes. #lowkey fun dinner.

MAZZAT PLATTER "parties of two or more" #holla
$20 pp ($40 min) #mixnmatch 3 hot x 3 cold apps

(^_^) Mosaka (http://bit.ly/1PV5UP9)
Mufasaaa. Say it again!

(^_^) Falafel (http://bit.ly/1XSKC97)
Not awful.

(^_^) Hummus x Beef (http://bit.ly/1QcSMEN)
Between yo teef.

(^_^) Babaghanouge (http://bit.ly/1XZc5k9)
Got some splainin to do!

(^_^) Iced Tea $4 (http://bit.ly/1N9qqHS)
You & me.

(-_^) Radio Rahib (http://bit.ly/1XZc7Zp)
Rest in peab.

(-_^) Macadoshis (http://bit.ly/1R7Lh2b)
Salt osmosis.

Wanna return for some #yomtv wraps.
author: Dan B.

description: Excellent food, cozy ambience & great wine! Their batata harra & zaatar pita- highly recommended. Easily one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco for Lebanese food.
author: Mansi D.

description: Our favorite Lebanese spot in all of the bay!!!! Kafta is delicious and perfectly spiced! Shawarma- delicious. Hummus and lebneh are amazing. Lemon mint tea is my boyfriends favorite. Only bad part is they don't sell knafeh for dessert. We look forward to eating here every time we are in town and have shown all of our friends this place and they all give it 5 stars as well!!!!
author: Sue F.

description:
I went here tonight for catch-up dinner with a friend. We went at around 6:30 and were seated instantly, since it seems to be a small corner restaurant. There were some people inside, but it wasn't too loud, and I liked that the ambiance was close and warm :)

Based on a lot of suggestions, we got the Mazzat platter, which is a set of 3 Hot and 3 Cold dishes. For two people, it was a lot of food, and we had plenty leftovers to take home....we also got extra pita because we ran out of bread before running out of anything else, so I guess it was a decent price at $20 per person. 

Hot Dishes:
1. Hummus with Beef: The hummus was pretty good, and I liked that there were full chickpeas and pine nuts in it, although now I kind of wish we had gotten the Hummus Harr instead. I found it to be pretty standard, nice hummus.
2. Fatet Batinjan: This was surprisingly my favorite hot dish by far, especially considering I am usually a very carnivorous diner.... The croutons were sooo good, and the crunch contrasted well with how soft the eggplants were. It was seasoned nicely and really hit the spot for that burst of unique flavor that I was craving.
3. Ouzi: This was okay. It wasn't that much rice, and I think it was pretty soft and flavorful, but it wasn't mind-blowing. I usually don't like lamb because I find it gamey, but there wasn't anything about this dish that bothered me either, so I guess that was a plus!

Cold Dishes:
1. Tabouli: Um....I don't remember this one super well.....so I'm assuming it was neither amazing nor distasteful, but there was a lot going on that platter, and my focus was definitely directed at the Fatet Batinjan and the Shankaleesh, really...
2. Mutabal: I think this was pretty good. It was a unique, fruity-sweet flavor and added a nice contrast to the mostly savory dishes we had on our platter. 
3. Shankaleesh: I was surprised that this was my favorite cold dish! It was pretty salty, but sooo, soo good. I think this one was one I might crave in the future. I just liked how all the flavors matched so well together, and it balanced nicely with the pita.

The pita, by the way, was awesome. Served nice and warm, they were cut in to wedges, and kind of chewy when biting in to them. I get a little hungry when I think about it.
author: Diane J.

description: I love Mediterranean food and was so excited to try this place based on all the glowing reviews and enormous menu. Unfortunately, it was a huge disappointment. The food was oily rather than flavorful. My boyfriend's wrap lacked flavor and spices, but had so much oil he couldn't finish it. My pizza was extremely greasy. 2 hours later and I still feel ill from all of the oil. I wish I spent the calories on a better meal, honestly. At least it wasn't overpriced. The additional star is for the cute interior.
author: ashley d.

description:
I love this place! We ordered the platter for two and it was extremely filling. We didn't even finish actually; I think it could be a platter for three. 

Everything tastes very fresh and with the mix of veggie and meat dishes - balance was also good. The restaurant itself is not that big; we came on a Monday night and it was fine (no wait). Unfortunately, they were out of some ingredient when we went but I'll be back to try the lamb!
author: Juliana P.

description:
What's the downside of trying exotic specialties with names of dishes that you don't know how to pronounce? Butchering through your order order because you don't know how to pronounce the names of dishes.

Mazzat has a good selection of interesting Lebanese/Mediterranean food--beyond the usual hummus-kebab-wrap into the realm of multi-dimensional spices and herbs.

After scrutinizing the menu and thinking through several family style ways to order, we concluded the most cost-effective option was the Mazzat platter, which gives you a choice of 3 hot and 3 cold mazzat (appetizers). At $20/person, the Mazzat platter is on the upper end of the price range for a standard dinner but is a great way to sample all their creations. (Also, it abides by the rule of thumb that you can't go wrong ordering what the restaurant is named after.)

The spoils:

3 cold mazzat:
(++) Hummus harr (chickpeas mixed with garlic, lemon juice, chili paste, tahini, topped with fried pine-nuts): Pretty good hummus, made even better with the toppings. Has a kick from the chili but could use more spice.
(+/-) Makdous (tangy stuffed eggplant with walnuts, red pepper, garlic and olive oil): Fascinated because I've never seen this before. The eggplants and walnuts make an interesting combination but was very very salty.
(++) Warek enab (grape leaves stuffed with rice cooked with olive oil and lemon juice): Nice robust, pungent grape leaf flavor.

3 hot mazzat:
(++) Mosaka with beef (eggplants topped with homemade garlic tomato sauce): Probably the least adventures, but hearty and satisfying.
(++) Arnabeet (fried cauliflower topped with garlic and lemon juice): Reminds me of fried bar food, but the garlic and lemon juice are a great addition.
(++) Ouzi (jasmine rice cooked with ground lamb and beef in special spice blend, topped with pine nuts and almonds): Mmm, aromatic goodness. The spice blend is borderline rogue, the pine nuts and almonds add an extra layer of nutty earthiness, and the soft ground lamb and beef in rice are pillow-soft. Odd description, I know, but perhaps that's why I'm a self-proclaimed Yelp food blogger rather than an actual food critic.

(+) Complimentary pita: Fresh, warm, and soft. I recommend mixing and matching! Well... except maybe for the grape leaf wraps would not fare the best with pita. Otherwise, pita + hummus + other mazzats are DIY fun (sort of like charcuterie board finger food) because you never know exactly what to expect.

Service and ambiance were good, not too busy on a weekend night even at peak dinner time. Mazzat definitely satisfied my curiosity and I would recommend it for any foodie's SF bucket list, though for my everyday, peasant-level Mediterranean food staple I think I will stick with simple shawarma wraps at local delis. Then I can save $ and splurge on more fancy new places :3 Hehe, life of a foodie on a budget.
author: Edna C.

description:
What I ate: Hummus harr, bamia
Visit date: July 20, 2015
First time? No.

I had been here a few years back and remember my food experience fondly. I was finally able to take my fiancé here and I was just as pleased with the experience, if not more. I had the bamia and shared a hummus plate. 

The bamia is amazing. I could leave it at that but let me indulge you more. I'm a big fan of lamb and an even bigger fan of fall off the bone meats. The bamia is just that -- super juicy and tender pieces of lamb that basically melt in your mouth. The sauce is rich and robust. Pour that over rice and I'm a happy camper. The bamia also has pieces of okra, which I am also a big fan of. I only wish there were more. 

The hummus harr is their house made hummus with a dash of spice. I definitely recommend it if you like heat. It's just enough spice to spike your appetite. It's served with pita, but you might want to put it on everything you order.
author: Erin G.

description:
They are not ready at 4pm. Took me awhile to get my order. 
I'm very punctual and I expect good service but no one will rush for you here.
author: Lana S.

description: Falafal is extremely dry. I asked for garlic yogurt sauce to go and they packed plain yogurt sauce.
author: Rini R.

description: What are they thinking? We went in for dinner last night. We were seated and given menus. As we're waiting for service the 'manager' comes up to tell us we can't have the table we're seated at. It was 'reserved.' Mazzat *does not take reservations*! All other open tables were taken as we were waiting for service. We have to leave. So, the manager needs to be relieved of his duties. He's a liar. As you might imagine, we will never return to Mazzat. We will endeavor to persuade as many people as we can to avoid this place.
author: Gary C.

description: Tremendous flavor and freshness to this food! We got the sampler/tasting menu, which allows two people to get a platter of 3 cold dishes and 3 hot dishes for about $45. Portion sizes could/should have been a bit larger. But the quality of the food itself was top notch! Although the service was a little weird in that each interaction you would have with the wait staff would be with a different person, it was adequately expeditious.
author: Abe A.

description: Stopped hear on a late Saturday afternoon. The four of us were seated right away. Staff was very attentive. Before our waters were halfway gone someone would be there to fill them up. I ordered the artichoke chicken pizza. It was good, but I felt it could have been more flavorful. The people who I was with ordered the lamb schwarma and thought it was just alright as well. Overall, service was excellent and food was alright.
author: Bernadette T.

description:
Solid Mediterranean place if you're in the neighborhood. I wouldn't make this a destination though. Great for an intimate dinner for two or a group no bigger than 6 (the dining space isn't very large). Service was pretty good.

We got hummus, grilled eggplant appetizer, the shwarma wrap, and the kafta wrap. Lots of food for a good price. The eggplant was really good. The wraps were okay.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Had planned on going to a restaurant close by but it was not open and my party was very hungry after a long day of sightseeing. 

While looking for a place to grab a drink to wait until the restaurant opened we stumbled upon Mazzat.  Best thing to happen to us today.  They were very welcoming and helped us sort out the menu and peace together our shared dinner.

The food was prepared quickly, tasted great and everyone was satisfied.  Would highly recommend Mazzat to anyone looking for quality middle-eastern food in a nice, quaint atmosphere.

Was a little off the beaten track for tourist but well worth the extended walk.

Thanks very much.
author: Kevin G.

description:
My son and I were seeking dinner before the Opera (Don Pasquale) on a rainy Saturday evening and decided to try Mazzat based on Yelp reviews.  It is a reasonable 10 minute brisk walk to the Opera House.  Likely due to the early hour and inclement weather, it was not crowded when we arrived around 5:20 pm. 

We were greeted by the friendly staff and seated.  While ordering we made the server aware of our opera time constraints.  We were assured that nothing we ordered would take too long.  Indeed we had plenty of time to enjoy the good food before having to be back at the Opera house for the 6:30 pm pre-show lecture. 

The menu is very interesting, but was intrigued us was the combination appetizer platter.  If everyone at the table will order the same thing, it is a good deal for $20/person and gives you a choice of a total of 6 dishes (3 hot and 3 cold).  It is important to note that EVERYONE at the table must order it.

We had the Arnabeet, Fatet Betinjan, Ouzi, Dolmas, Lebna, and Mutabal.  It comes with slices of pita bread. 

Everything was very tasty.  Each item was distinct and delicious.  The dolmas were the only ordinary thing (we probably should have had chosen something else for that item). They were good, but not special.  The other dishes were very good. 

My son finished his meal with a Lebanese Coffee ($5), which is a strong, spiced coffee served in a little metal pitcher with a wooden horizontal handle to pour into a tiny cup.   He really enjoyed it. 

Service was good and we enjoyed our dinner.
author: Mike M.

description: Amazing food, people and a great deal! Always come here with a friend and get the two person special with the hot and cold platter combo.
author: O J.

description:
Trust me I'm A Middle Eastern I know what I'm talking about

We went here as we were craving some home dishes and we we were  so glad we did go here! 
We ordered the platter it was so delicious we could not get enough
Hummus Harr
Dolma
Arnabet
Fatet betnjan 
Taboleh 
All was excellent! 
We also ordered Kufta which was so good as well trust me i know cause im a middle Eastern
The only thing I got confused for the price of the platter just know that it is 20 per person so  you will be paying 40$
The waitress was sooo kind and sweet and very welcoming thank you for a nice evening I appreciate it
author: Nara S.

description:
We came here for dinner and to get out of the pouring rain on a Saturday night.

I started with the Almaza pilsner which was interestingly flavorful; one of the better pilsners I've ever had. We ordered the falafel appetizer, which is a dish I've seen many places get wrong. The falafel had a good balance of herbs and was nice and crunchy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside; just as a falafel should be.

For my entree I ordered the Bamia. The rice that accompanied the dish was properly cooked and well presented. The lamb was tender, but the okra was overcooked. More troubling is how bland the dish was. It was almost as if the chef forgot about seasonings. Bites without the lamb just tasted like tomato sauce out of a can. I took half of the dish home and added 1/8 teaspoon of cumin, salt, and pepper and ate it for lunch the next day. It was much better as lunch than dinner.

The service was friendly. Decor was cute in that "I don't care that half of our light bulbs are out" kind of way.
author: John P.

description:
I am rating this restaurant based on a bad experience with service. When I ordered my meal, I wanted to try the mazzat platter to tray a variety of things - BEWARE!!! They automatically charge you $20per person for the number of people at your table, even if you just want it for your meal! This was NOT made clear to me before or after ordering. Yes, it is stated on the menu but since it is out of the ordinary, I really feel that it is up to the waitstaff to let guests know of this before ordering and to avoid a shock when the bill comes. I've been a server before and I know customers don't always read the fine print (case in point, I did not!). Our bill was over $60 for two people and it was SOOOOO not worth it!

Because the server was not candid with us, we over-ordered and could not take leftovers as we were not going straight home. What a waste of food and money!!

Ok, now that I have described the bad experience, let's get to the food. The food was mediocre. There's a much better middle eastern restaurant in Walnut Creek that you could feed 6 people for the price we paid for one dinner here AND the food is much better. 

We got the mazzat platter with hummus with beef, cauliflower, falafel, baba ghanoush, stuffed eggplant, and stuffed grape leaves. The hummus, cauliflower, and baba ghanoush are the only items I'd get again - they were pretty good. Here's why I wouldn't get the other 3: the falfel was a little stale and chewy (yuk!), the stuffed eggplant is pickled and WAYYYYY too salty - so salty I couldn't finish it, and the grape leaves were decent - I might get them again, actually.

We also tried the kefta - don't waste your time. It's bland and not a big portion size for $18. 

This restaurant must have high rent and not enough customers to charge the prices they do.

So, the takeaways: try this place if you want (I am not putting my seal of approval on it, hence the 2-star review) but don't let them scam you with the mazzat platter! If you do go, try the hummus (I liked it with beef), baba ghanoush, and cauliflower (and maybe the grape leaves).
author: Jess A.

description: I just tried this place tonight with my hubby and we were lucky we could get a table as a walk-in on a Saturday night. I would recommend a reservation even for 2 people. I think that the Mazzat Platter is a great way to sample the menu the first time. It is $20 per person, the entire party has to get it and includes 3 hot items and 3 cold items with no exception. We had kebbeh, mosaka and arnabeet as our 3 hot items, and rahib, Mazzat salad and kabees as our cold items. We enjoyed all of our items and it went well with our low carb diet. When I am off of my diet, I will go back to try their fatet batinjan, hummus with pita bread, mujadara, Lebanese pizza and falafel wrap.
author: C L.

description:
LOVED LOVED LOVED our meal.

5 of us had dinner here last night and it was fantastic.  Portion size for the appetizers were decent so we all enjoyed a continuing round of apps (no one ordered a "dinner").  

Food tasted so fresh and the flavor combinations were delightful.  Pita bread on the side came to the table hot and fluffy.  Super yummy.  Waiter refilled our basket several times wihtout us having to ask.

Price for 5 and before tipping came to $86 which seemed unbelievable for the quantity and quality of the food.

Definitely returning.
author: Terrie G.

description:
My boyfriend and I shared two hot plates and one wrap, and we both left full and satisfied!

- Fate Batinjan (fried eggplant & pita croutons with yogurt sauce): A must-order if you love eggplant! The crispy croutons provided a great contrast in texture to the super soft eggplant, and the yogurt sauce really complimented both. Really good flavors!

- Kebbeh (ground beef stuffed deep fried cracked wheat with garlic sauce): Probably my least favorite dish out of the 3 we ordered, but by no means was it bad. Thought it was unique, and it tasted good, though I wish there was more meat inside.

- Kafta wrap (ground beef/lamb, eggplant, potato, hummus): Super flavorful/ Again, I wish there was more meat because there was a lot more potato, but this was still tasty and very filling. 

Side note: Meat pies are one of the top review highlights, but they apparently haven't had it on the menu in two years.

Overall, I was really surprised how much I enjoyed this meal!
author: Sara L.

description:
Quite the charming little place in Hayes Valley.

Made a reservation for two and were seated immediately once both of us arrived.

What I like about the Mazzat Platter is that you can choose everything your heart desires, which helps people with food ADD like myself. There are many tempting choices, but we went with the following (if I remember correctly lol): 

Baba ghanoush
Warek enab 
Mazzat salad
Hummus with beef
Ouzi
Rahib

Both the eggplant dishes and the hummus with beef were my favorite. I felt the hummus needed some work but the texture was spot on and the beef was flavorful. I could eat that eggplant for daaaaays.

I also love that they have tons of vegetarian options that aren't fried or straight up carbs. 

Skipped dessert.
author: Shereen A.

description: The appetizers are small but unique.  We had the shawarma, kefta and kabssi for our dinner.  The shawarma is like a lamb wrap and was dry.  The kefta was great.  It's like a mini meatloaf slash meatball with tomatoe broth.  The kabssi was a really soft juicy chicken over rice.  Good food.  I say check it out.
author: Zeke L.

description:
I came here to eat on a Saturday night since there were options for vegetarian food. My fiancé and I arrived with no reservations at 6:30pm and was told that it would be a 45 minute wait. Not too shabby since we wanted to walk around Hayes Valley beforehand. We came back about 20 minutes when the waiter saw us waiting outside and asked if we were okay with the bar seating. Sweet - so we took the offer, but noted for next time, to call and make the reservations.

Interior: The inside of the restaurant is pretty small - about 10+ tables and a bar counter that seats 4 people. The kitchen is so small and viewable (next to the bar).

Food: We ordered the Mazzat platter (feeds 2 people at $20/person), which came with 3 cold and 3 hot mazzat of your choice and served with hot, fresh pita bread. For cold, we ordered the Hummus Harr, Babaghanouge, and Shankaleesh. For hot, we ordered Halloumi Cheese, Batata Harra, and Falafel. All was delicious! My favorite was the Hummus Harr, Batata Harra, and Shakaleesh! Surprisingly, when I first saw the basket of pita bread, I thought that it wouldn't be enough. But no, this restaurant already knows how it works and provided the perfect amount of pita bread. The Mazzat platter did feed for 2 people exactly and had us walking out of there happily full and satisfied.

Drinks: I had their Mint Lemonade and it was refreshing and delicious. Next time I would love to try their Lebanese tea with mint.

The only thing I would give feedback to the restaurant is probably to have more menus. It took a good 10-15 minutes after we were seated to get them. I think it was because everyone at other tables were taking their time looking at the menu so there weren't enough for everyone in the full, packed restaurant. However, the bartender was great on serving us water right when we sat down - so points on that.
author: Kelly T.

description: Delicious authentic Lebanese and Mediterranean food served with flair on stylish large white plates in a cozy, nicely lit neighborhood restaurant at surprisingly reasonable prices and some interesting wines. The shared small plates (3 cold plus 3 hot, minimum of two at $20 each) is the draw. We had a buttery melt in your mouth shawarma in a thin, flaky lavash ($13) and this beautiful chicken entree ($18) over rice pilaf studded with fruits similar to an Indian biyrani. Portions were huge. We will be back.
author: gigi b.

description:
Came here in a Friday night around 6:30 without a reservation.  Found it on Yelp - then when we got there we realized we pass this place coming off the highway all the time.

When we arrived it was so hot and humid inside that my glasses fogged up. I found my husband had just gotten there to meet us.. he was sweating up a storm.  Without a reservation we were seated in the back at a small table for three (A little while later they asked us if we wanted to move up front to a bigger table - but we were already settled in)

Our waiter really tried to please us - giving my friend who is into wine a bunch of tastes of stuff.  We ordered a bottle and a few things including the moussaka (really just roasted eggplant and tomatoes, our favorite of the night), some cauliflower, the ground lamb and rice dish, halloumi cheese and a pizza with feta & onions

I thought it was all pretty tasty and a lot of food for 3 for $100 plus tip.

The bathroom was a bit off-putting, especially since it was a oval bowl with a round seat, so just kinda gross...spend the $18 and get a new seat people!
author: Amy W.

description: Food was good, a little more on the expensive side. My friend and I got mezzehs to share. They were great! Full of flavor. Next time I would only get one share not two. It was a lot to eat, we ended up with tons of leftovers. The waiter was really nice and the place had a good vibe
author: Monica A.

description: One of my fave places to dine in the Civic Center area. The ambiance is so charming and romantic! Fave dishes include the fatet batinjan (eggplant with pita croutons, my #1 fave dish), chicken artichoke pita, kafta, and ouzi (ground lamb and beef with rice). We found the foul mudammas a bit bland. Other worthy dishes are the lubieh bezait (green beans) and arnabeet (cauliflower).
author: Andrew L.

description:
I LOVEEEE Mazzat!!!

Has been on my list for so long and then I came twice in one week. Basically ordered the same thing both times. You MUST get the Labne and the Mediterranean Pizza. Not positive that was what it was called but you'll know when you see it. 

I never had Labne before and I am addicted. I bought some at Rainbows and it doesn't compare to Mazzats. Not all yogurt cheeses are made the same! 

Service here is super friendly! Super engaging but not in an overbearing way. Lots of wine to choose from. Last time I was there someone had broken one of their windows which I hope is fixed by now. So mean!!!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
The food was okay. The one star is really for the service that we experienced while dining here. I walked in around 6:30 and didn't have a reservation. The hostess I spoke to pointed to a table for 2 and told me that we could sit there, if we would be able to leave at 7:45. That was over an hour away so I figured that was doable -- yes, it was strange to me that she put a time limit on my dinner but I really didn't want to have to wait for another table. So I sit down and my friend arrives shortly afterwards. We placed our order and proceeded to chat, order and eat the food (which, might I add, took quite a while to arrive). At one point I realized that I hadn't been checking the time, and looked at my phone. It said 8:00 pm, so I mentioned to my friend that it was past 7:45, but since no one had approached us about finishing up, it must not have been a big deal.

Fast forward to us ordering some Turkish coffee to wrap up our meal. We are drinking out of our little cups when suddenly our whole table is cleared and we are left with the check. They took the coffee pot, which was still half full of coffee, away from us while we were still drinking it! It was so bizarre and we called over the hostess from the beginning to ask her if they could bring it back, since we weren't done with it. She responded with, "We don't do to go cups for coffee." I explained to her that we weren't asking for to go cups... we just wanted it right now at the restaurant. After she repeated her reply a second time, it dawned upon me what was happening. She was passive aggressively letting us know that our time was up (no more end-of-dinner coffee for us, yikes!!) and that we should leave the restaurant. She then turned to me and said "I told you that you had to leave here at 7:45. You are still here." I couldn't believe it. She was punishing us for not obeying her orders? My friend told her that she could have reminded us once it hit 7:45 (I promise we are not bad people -- we would have left at that point if she had reminded us. We honestly just forgot, and when it didn't come up again, we didn't think anything of it). She turned to her to say, "Well, I told your friend 7:45 at the beginning," and then turned back to me and said, very rudely, "Did you not say 7:45?" 

At this point I felt so attacked by her rudeness that I simply apologized. I did genuinely feel bad if I inconvenienced her by forgetting to leave her restaurant at EXACTLY 7:45 pm, but honestly I've never had a hostess act like this towards me before so I didn't really know what to say. At this point, my friend tells her we're leaving and she walks away. I have never felt so anxious and attacked at a restaurant before. The passive aggressiveness really was unnecessary and I wish that I had just said no to her when she told me we needed to leave the table at a specific time.
author: Maheen S.

description: Most of the restaurant was empty, we were in front of other guest. They insisted that we sit right next to the door and would not let us sit anywhere else, even though we had been waiting there for quiet a while to be seated. Also despite half the restaurant being empty somehow it was all reserved. When we asked to be switched to a different table since the door had a bad draft, the waiter had to go "talk to management", which amounted to taking some orders and taking long time to walk around the room before coming back and saying no. The heck? Terribly rude staff.
author: Zhi C.

description:
The food was quite tasty but there were three things I would have wished were different:
- some of the wine on the menu was not available so we accepted the alternative they suggested... which turned out being more expensive than other bottles... they should tell you if their suggestion is in a higher range
- they brought the appetizers and then a couple minutes later brought the dinner. The whole point of appetizers is to nibble and chat and taste the wine before dinner comes, not as a side dish to the entree
- there is a lot of salt in the dishes. We all were thirsty after dinner from all the salt 

That said, the flavor was great and people were friendly.
author: Warzie L.

description: The best Lebanese food I've ever had! The hummus and pita was incredible and the lamb schwarma was also really great. Definitely suggest getting a couple items and sharing.
author: Ronak M.

description:
If you want good, affordable and veg-friendly Mediterranean food, definitely go to Mazzat! My sister and I are both vegetarians and there were so many options that we had a hard time choosing what to order. We ended up going with the sampler platter where you get to choose 3 hot and 3 cold dishes. I definitely recommend this because you get to try a bunch of different things. We had the Dolmas, babaganouj, hummus, eggplant, cheese, etc. All highly recommend! 

I docked one star because they were out of a couple dishes when we were there.. Other than that, it was great!
author: Harmony H.

description:
We adore Lebanese food and have had it in the Middle East and make some favorite dishes at home. We were looking forward to this meal but left disappointed. I thought it was 3 stars but my wife would have only given them two. Since she knows much more about Middle Eastern food than me I'm deferring to her opinion. She said she felt sick after the meal. 

The tip off that it wasn't going to be a great meal was walking in to a bad smell - couldn't tell if it was cleaning products or mustiness but it was not the smell of great food cooking.Seems like either they cook at a different location or have it all made up and microwave each order. 

We ordered a combo where you could select 3 hot and 3 cold mezze for $20 person. For two people the portions are smaller that the regular order but you get to try six items instead of four. 

We had what they called moussaka that was fried eggplant chunks in tomato sauce. I didn't think it was great but my wife said that was one of two that she would order again. We had the Mazzat salad which was ok but had too much parsley for me. The labnah was tasty but one can easily buy it in a middle eastern grocery and add olive oil and zataar. The fatet betinjan was one of my favorites, another eggplant dish with pita croutons but my wife disliked this one. She had the ouzi- a rice dish with lamb and reported it was ok. The final dish was mutabal on the receipt but the waiter had recommended one called rahib- we both thought the mutabal was one of the better dishes so it was just as well the kitchen made a mistake. 

I was going to have a birthday meal here but so glad just the two of us popped in for a preview. Going to cancel that reservation now. 

And a pet peeve - please buy a larger toilet seat that fits the fixture. Less than the cost of the mezze platter at any hardware store.
author: Marco M.

description:
This is my go-to restaurant in Hayes Valley because it's usually not too crowded, and serves great comfort food.  Mazzat makes some of the best pita bread I've had in the US.  I usually get bored after one bite into pita bread ("Oh right, THAT'S why i don't eat this ish.")  But here I don't know if they slather it in butter or something but it just tastes insanely good and addictive.

I've eaten here about half a dozen times and always had a good experience.  They're super proud of their Lebanese food here and the owner guy gives great recommendations.


---- SMALL DISHES ----

Hummus Harr: 3 stars
Spicy hummus with fried pine nuts, but their hummus is only okay here.  (Better than the grocery store, but not as good as many other restaurants on my list.

Fatet Batinjan: 5 stars
The best eggplant dish -- grilled or fried to crispy softness.

Makdous: 4 stars
Tangy pepper stuffed with deliciousness.

Labne: 3.5 stars
More yoghurt-like and less savory / flavourful than the cheeselike labne in Lebanon.

Loubieh Bizeit: 4 stars
Great vegetarian dish.

Foul Mudammas: 4 stars
Fava beans is an acquired taste... Not as good as the foul in Lebanon, but at least it's not sweet.

Ouzi:  3.5 stars
Hearty dish with lamb, beef, rice.
author: Letitia L.

description: Had expectations for this place and it did not deliver. Babaganosh was alright but kibe and basmati rice was mediocre. What a shame. I'm not coming back.
author: Katarine Q.

description: I've never had such a luscious wrap before in my life. How honored I feel to have tried the lamb wraps here. 10/10 would go back again.
author: Theodora C.

description:
I came here for dinner on Saturday night, and among two people, we ordered three small tapas to share. We got the arnabeet (fried cauliflower), fatet batinjan (fried eggplant w/ yogurt sauce), and hummus harr. The fatet batinjan was my favorite among the three. The yogurt sauce and the pita croutons really mixed well with the eggplant. I also enjoyed the pine nuts on top. The fried cauliflower was okay - a little too mushy for my taste. The hummus was a lot - I got a little tired of it after a few pieces of pita bread. If you're going for hummus, definitely get the hummus harr because the addition of chili paste and pine nuts really makes it better. I had a sip of the Lebanese tea with mint, and it was nice - although I probably could have gotten that anywhere or made it at home. 

Overall, a cute restaurant with a date-y vibe, dark lighting, and lots of options to share.
author: Steph V.

description:
One of the best restaurants I've been to in some time. Everything my boyfriend and I ordered was delicious (especially the baklava-- best we've ever had.). When we went in (around 530pm) we were the only customers there for about 30 minutes, which was surprising. Service was great, ambience was great, location is great.

I highly recommend this place.
author: Grace P.

description: We stumbled upon Mazzat's when we originally were going to try a nearby Japanese restaurant but the wait was too long. We've always enjoyed Greek food and never experienced Lebanese cuisine.  The food was excellent and atmosphere delightful. We will definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Jennie N.

description:
Everything from the service to the food is perfect here. 

Some pro tips:
-Order the sampler, you won't regret it. I recommend getting the eggplant dish from either the cold or hot menu.
-Call ahead so they can put your name down if there is a wait.
-The restaurant is tiny so expect to get cozy with your neighbor
author: Gaurav B.

description: Came here last night for anniversary dinner. Had high expectations and they were exceeded. We had the arnabeet to start, which came with pita, and then the kabsseh and kafta as the main course. Everything was amazing, but the kabsseh was just spectacularly delicious. Perfectly spiced. Portions were fairly large too, easily enough for lunch today. Service was friendly and quick and the atmosphere was nice. Can't wait to come back! Would highly recommend!
author: Madeline M.

description: The food is good. One of the best tomato-fera cheese salad I've tried. Price is ok. Order 6 small dishes for 2 and pay 40$. Service is good as well. I would recommend. I'm not sure about returning so soon. I want to try new places.
author: Rafael M.

description:
SO DELICIOUS! I am Lebanese, so I am a little picky about my Arab food, but this place had amazing food and staff were very helpful. 
Prices were a little steeper than I thought they should be, but I guess that is San Francisco in general. 
I highly recommend getting the Mazzat platter of hot and cold appetizers if you have 2 or more people with you.
author: Lauren G.

description:
The food was incredibly delicious and our servers were very polite. A table next to us had gotten the tabouli and were a little upset that there were no grains. When they brought it to the waiter's attention, he was incredibly polite and offered to make it as they preferred. 

Great price, super delicious, awesome staff! And the ambience was adorable. We walked up to Madrone after dinner.
author: Jerrica V.

description:
My friend put our names on the list last night at around 7:45, the hostess said it'd be about a 30 minute wait and that they'd call us when our table was ready.  We had a drink nearby, and walked back to Mazzat at 8:20 to see if our table was ready.  

We walked in, asked the hostess, and she said:  "Oh, hm.  I forgot to put you on the list.  We're really busy tonight, I'm sorry guys."

I said "So we can't eat here?"

She smiled and said "Hah, sorry!"  Smiled at the bartender, smiled back at us.  Shrugged.
author: Tommy G.

description: Cute and warm decor celebrating Lebanon! We ordered 6 dishes (3 cold, 3 hot) and everything was very delicious. My favorites were Fatet batinjan, a cooked eggplant dish with cool yogurt and crispy crouton like garnish and halloumi cheese, a Lebanese staple. They do run out of things so call in to make an earlier reservation or come earlier. Baklava for dessert was the perfect end to our meal (see pictures). Prices are fair and portions are good :) We will be coming back!
author: Bijal P.

description: Excellent- everything about this place and the experience is great- I've been twice.  Great variety of food with their platter (as expected with this type of food), good decor, not crazy busy, in a nice part of Hayes Valley
author: Charles C.

description:
I enjoyed my dinner at Mazzat. Even though other reviews have mentioned slow/poor service I didn't find that the case at all. My server was very friendly and attentive and everything arrived at a reasonable time. 
We ordered the mazzat special which is $20/person (minimum of 2 people) for 6 mazzat dishes: hummus with beef, smoked eggplant, babaganoush, Labne (Lebanese cheese), Ouzi, and green beans. They were all very tasty and in particular, I was glad I tried the Lebanese cheese since it was something new to me. It had a thick yogurt consistency and tasted similar to cream cheese but tangier. Personally, I was excited to try the smoked eggplant, BUT there were bits of peppers in them and I hate peppers :(. I did notice the mazzat choices are kind of similar to each other--so if you dislike eggplant or chickpeas, then.. go elsewhere. 
The price for drinks and food is kind of high (then again, it is SF) and dinner will probably run you $30-40/person especially if you get a drink. Then again it is a cute little restaurant and a good place for a date or to catch up with a friend. The $20/person for the mazzat special seemed high but we were pretty stuffed (since you dip most of the dishes with pita bread!) and couldn't finish the food.
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place out. A perfect selection of Lebanese favorites although I didn't see charcoal chicken on the menu. 
We had the grilled eggplant, mazzat salad and the chicken with rice and yoghurt sauce (available after 5pm). 
They were all fabulous and a perfect taster of hot, cold and main plates. The 3 plates was definitely sufficient servings to feed 2 people.
We came at 6pm on a Sunday after an SF Jazz concert and did not need a reservation. 
Looking forward to coming back to taste more. It's a warm cozy atmosphere.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
This is a charming little Lebanese restaurant, gracefully straddling neighborhood coziness with a touch of subtle sophistication.  

It's not just the dinnerware that adds some elegance to their delicious Middle Eastern offerings, it's the preparation and overall presentation.  Each dish is a feast for the senses, delighting the eyes with a flurry of color and texture before ever taking a single bite.  We had the Mazzat platter (you'll understand why you will do the same after seeing the diverse array of choices on the menu) and everything we sampled was delicious.  Their wine selection, while limited, was surprisingly good too.

Recommended if you truly want to enjoy the tastes of Middle Eastern cuisine -and also want a nice place for a date night.  We had a great evening here.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Have passed by here en route to somewhere, often to Richmond or Sunset after City Arts or Mission outing. Decided - I have to eat here sometime. I learned to appreciate Lebanese food when I worked in U.K. I had gotten so obsessed about it that summer, that I ended up riding tube EVERYWHERE in London in search of the best of the best Lebanese food. I found a ton near Paddington Station and one near Sherlock Holme's residence. Ever since then I've been on a look out for authentic Lebanese food. San Francisco, for all of its food diversity and snobbery, lacks decent Lebanese food, (or Moroccan if you ask me). There is zero Alsatian restaurant here either, which is just about my favorite type of food on earth (combining German and French food, sort of my version of heaven!) But I digress. 

Mazzat is a Lebanese restaurant. It has extremely wonderful selection of mazzat, which is basically tapas. My favorite is kebbeh, and followed by hummus with beef. get ouzi: rice and lamb never tasted better. For cold mazzat, of course babaghanouge, mutabal, and labne. Kabees is colorful but too salty (yes it's pickled veggies but I was hoping for something resembled the stuff I get in London!). 

It also had a very cool cave wine from Lebanon. They poured generously and it made me extremely happy. I'm a light weight so I usually have a sip and then pass it to my date. This was no exception. 

Food aside, this is a great restaurant for catching up. N8 and I had a lot to catch up. Last month has been a whirlwind for me and him. I felt that I'd gone into the tunnel and out on the other end, and now I'm an entirely new person with absolutely zero short term memory. I gave N8 a run down of my ever so chaotic life, and he gave me his (not chaotic but eventful nonetheless). We could not stop eating. The food was absolutely delicious and the pita bread was warm and refilled often.

To cap the evening we ordered a lebanese coffee which had more cardamon, otherwise like Turkish coffee, and simply divine. One pot was too big for one person, best to be shared with your friend. 

This was an intensely amazing meal with things you'd not often get in San Francisco. By the end of the meal we were all caught up. We synched our calendars to schedule in our next outing, while waited for check to arrive. Now that I've finally had my Lebanese food fix, I wondered what other Middle East restaurants I'd drum up for the next adventure food outing.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Came for dinner on a weeknight without a reservation. Service was attentive and prompt. Sever gave great recommendations. The establishment was clean and not too loud.
