My group and I did the combo mazzat platter with kefta. Everything was flavorful and tasty. My only complaint was the green beans... they tasted like they were from a can. Everything else was fresh and well seasoned. 

I appreciated the Lebanese wine selection. Overall I would recommend!
author: Miss H.

description: Delicious lamb and okra stew..fantastic wine. Very sweet waiters...Can't wait to go back.
author: Dana D.

description: I wish I had tried them sooner as I've lived in the area for a few years. The space is warm and quiet and features comfortable lighting. It's a nice place to have a comfortable casual dinner where actual conversations are possible. We ordered the fatet batenjan, haloumi cheese, hummus with beef and kabsseh. We really enjoyed eating the fatet batenjan with a bit of the haloumi. I imagine it's not how it's meant to be eaten but the contrast in he flavors complimented each other really well. The hummus with beef was as expected - I don't think I've ever met a hummus I didn't like. Serving for the kabsseh was very generous - it felt like it was good enough for two even if we hadn't ordered other small plates. The flavors felt warm but well balanced and never overwhelmed. The food itself had a subtle but palpable homemade/family recipe vibe. Overall, a very good experience. Looking forward to the other things on the menu.
author: Isabel R.

description: I came here four times, every time was great experience! Reasonable price for quality food! For two people, two appetizers, one pizza, and one dinner meal without drink around $50 with tax before tips; I still have a lot of food to take out. Great value and friendly stuff!
author: Lohas D.

description:
We happened to park across the street from Mazzat and took the opportunity to dine at this Lebanese restaurant that was new to us.  This was on a Saturday evening.  We did not have reservations so we were happy to sit at the counter, where the service was perfunctory, but OK.

I ordered the Bamia and Maureen ordered the Kabsseh. I was attracted to the Bamia by the menu's description: "Sautéed green okra cooked with tomato sauce & tender lamb topped with fried garlic, served with jasmine rice".  When the dish arrived, I saw chunks of lamb in a stew of brown gravy.  I did not perceive the okra or tomatoes.   I stared at the dish, waiting for the okra to arrive.  When nothing came, I asked the waitress, who told me that all of the veggies were in the gravy.  Indeed, the veggies were there, albeit cut up into tiny pieces and cooked until mushy.  I admit to being a Lebanese cuisine newbie, so I can't complain.

Let the eating begin!   The lamb was tender and moist and the sauce was fragrant and delicately and deliciously spiced.   It was very good for a stew.   Maureen's Kabsseh, (which arrived about 7 minutes after my dish was delivered), was visually attractive.  I sampled her dish, and found it to be delicious.  The texture of the Kabsseh is not a stew, like the Bamia.  It contained a generous portion of dark meat chicken on the bone, served over basmati rice cooked with green peas, onions, carrots and raisins.  Very tasty.

If we dine at Mazzat again, I'd choose the Kabsseh.
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
Good vibe, very friendly staff, but the food and price left a lot to be desired. A dinner for two with one shared starter, a main for each person, and a glass of wine for each person came out to about ~$100. For flavor and quality at about a 2.5/5, this is tremendously overpriced.

For example, a plate of hummus costs $10. Uh... A glass of mediocre lebanese wine = $14.

You can get the same quality of Mediterranean cuisine at other places in the area for ~20% less.
author: J D.

description: A spectacular restaurant. The hummus and babaghanoush appetizers are scrumptious. Every dish we had for that matter was culinarily crafted to perfection. I greatly enjoyed my dining experience here at Mazzat. The service was also excellent. Definitely recommend to anyone who is seeking some Mediterranean cuisine.
author: Salim F.

description: Made reservations and was seated 25 minutes after our reservation time. Was also seated at a table meant for 2 (although our party was 3). Food was solid, would give 4 stars if it wasn't for other circumstances.
author: Luke A.

description:
We went there on a weekday, very poor service, high priced and the food was too dry. Did I mention 20% gratuity on 4 people!!!! wow.
We never even got water till dinner was practically over, nor did they offer. I had to wave down a waitress a few times to request water & bread. And it was not a busy night! So much for visiting the city trying to get a nice dinner with family and end up with a $200 bill for 4 people ( no alcohol drinks ). Outrageous. Two stars because the restaurant was very clean.
author: erma a.

description:
First off, my I was pleasantly surprised by the ambiance of this place. I decided to go here on a date after reading positive reviews on Yelp and just loved the charming interior and vibe of this cute neighborhood eatery. It couldn't have been better from a "make an impression" perspective. 

Now on the food side, it was a solid meal all around. Very good but not great to be exact. We ordered a couple of plates, a meat dish that resembled beef stew in taste and texture, a spicy potato dish, a rice dish and a cooked eggplant dish (sorry that I don't remember the exact names of the dishes). Yes, all the dishes were flavorful, in particular the eggplant which had a nice consistency for being eggplant. The beef was very tender, and for someone who doesn't a lot of meat, I couldn't have been happier. 

I would recommend everyone give this place a try. I'd like to come back and try some other dishes--perhaps on another date.
author: Tu V.

description:
I had dinner here a few nights ago and as the 4 star rating says...Yay!  I'm a fan.  3 of us stopped in for dinner on a Wednesday night without a reservation and they sat us promptly at the bar.  Nice!  We ordered the Dao white wine and it was great before and during the meal!  After a few minutes of having our wine the server came over and offered us a table...which we took!  Nice of them!

Dinner was scrumptious!  We started with Hummus Harr which was good but a bit too creamy and the Foul Madummas which is fava bean and both these were served with warm pita bread (YUM!).  I pretty sure the Foul Madummas was my favorite dish of the evening...but it was all so good it's hard to say.  We also started with the Halloumi Cheese which was also tasty.  We then all shared the Kafta dinner which is Ground beef & Lamb mixed with parsley & onions, cooked in tomato sauce, served with jasmine rice...I will definitely be having that again!

The staff made you feel very welcome and they were so sweet.  I think one person was serving everybody, but we were not in a rush so it was no bother.  Loved it!  Want to go back this weekend!
author: Melanie L.

description:
Came here with a group of friends and we started it off with the Fatet Batinjan (fried egg plant with yogurt sauce) and the hummus with pita bread which were both good but didn't rock my world or anything. 

This may have been just a poor choice on my part but I ordered the Falafel wrap ($10) but it was incredibly dry and bland. And while usually I'm all about the large portion sizes at a great price, here I wish they shrunk my wrap and made it a little more flavorful. I only was able to finish half of my wrap because 1) it wasn't that tasty and 2) it was HUGE. Each half was about half the size of my head it was seriously impressive sizing.

I would like to mention that my friend ordered the Chicken Artichoke Pita ($10) and that was amazing!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
Never really seen this place before as this little Lebanese restaurant is located on a corner a bit off in Hayes Valley, but I'm so happy that I got the chance to eat here! Came here for dinner w/ a group of friends (2 being Lebanese), & of course, we let the 2 take charge in our orders.

Cold Mazzat:
-Warek Enab (grape leaves stuffed w/ rice cooked w/ olive oil & lemon juice) $7
-Hummus (chickpeas w/ garlic,lemon juice&tahini) $8

Hot Mazzat:
-Kebbeh (deep fried cracked wheat stuffed w/ ground beef, served w/garlic sauce) $10

-Fatoush (Trad'l Lebanese salad) $10

-Kafta Dinner (ground beef&lamb w/parsley&onions, cooked in tomato sauce, served w/ jasmine rice) $18

Everything that we had tasted absolutely delicious & so flavorful w/ all the spices&seasoning! My favorite dishes were the Kebbeh & Hummus which I def recommend trying. The owners were there that night, so they were very sweet & attentive. Plus, to end the night, we got Baklava, which was sweet&warm! Overall, wonderful first experience w/ a beautiful ambiance, great company, & tasty food! Def recommend trying for Middle Eastern food
author: Trina N.

description: I was really happy to come across a Lebanese restaurant that has items on their menu that you can't find in just another "Mediterranean" place. Everyone here was friendly and helpful and extremely accommodating. Their price point, portion size, and most importantly taste were great. They have several vegetarian options and they accommodate gluten free customers. Thank you for a wonderful dining experience!
author: Tarun P.

description:
Went there because it had some good reviews on yelp but not really impressed. The ambience of the place is nice, food not so much. We ordered a complete vegetarian meal.
We ordered the 
Fattoush salad- Average. The server highly recommended this, but was not that great.
Fried eggplant - This was the only good dish that we had. 
Falafel wrap - ok. It was quite dry.
author: Varun A.

description:
The food was amazing! We ordered the Hummas with beef; it was so smooth and spices were perfectly blended. For my dinner I had the Kafta and the portion size was huge. I at half of mine and took the rest home. The Kafta was delicious and my family wants to come here again and again. 

The only downside is the restaurant is kind of small, loud, cramped, and if you go, you should really make a reservation. It is still worth it to go. We did not and had to sit at the bar or we would have waited 30 minute for a table. It was okay though because sitting at the bar, we had our water glasses filled more quickly, and our waiter was cute and polite. 

This place is bomb and anyone would be stupid to pass this place up.
author: Grace C.

description: I have been here once a week the past month.  I have had a craving and this place takes care of my need.  I go with the chicken shawarma sandwich.  Consistent every time.  Place is clean and fairly quick even during the lunch rush.
author: Zack K.

description:
(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:
stylish

Service+++:
Friendly

Value+++:
inexpensive
_________________
Food

3 Hot/ 3Cold Tapas
Hummus++:
Babaghanouge+++:
The taste was wonderful. I feel strongly eggplants and garlic.
Rahib++:
The fried eggplants was crispy, which the appearance was so cute.
Ouzi++:
It's first time to eat, which tasted interesting.

Two more tapas  with Pita breads

Lebanese coffee & dessert ++:

It's like Turkish coffee, which the coffee cups and the pot were so beautiful.
These items made me fascinated.
 
The dessert was like mille-feuille pie, which was a little bit wet. The taste was honey and pistachio.
author: Hiromi S.

description: Food and atmosphere were great. On the pricier side but not surprising for the area and the ambience.
author: Nitesh D.

description:
I really enjoyed my two dining experiences here! This place is cute, intimate and has some great food! 

Some of my favorites: 
Hummus Harr - This is some great hummus in my opinion! The mix of the hummus with tahini gives it a lighter texture and the extra spices give it just the right amount of kick! I definitely recommend this for everyone

Batata Harra - These potatoes are delicious! They have a spicy sauce on top of them which gives the potatoes a great flavor

Mujadara - This dish is pretty simple - basically just rice and lentils with a yogurt sauce but in my opinion, it's a comfort food style dish. I really like the flavors of the rice and the yogurt adds a nice refreshing aftertaste 

I've also tried the Foul Mudammas, Halloumi Cheese, and the Mazzat House Pita all of which were alright but I would definitely recommend the above 3 over these. 

I love that I live close to this restaurant so I can come back and try more of their extensive menu!
author: Malika R.

description: Came by for dinner last night. My second time ordering their appetizer for two. Food was outstanding and service even better. My mom ordered their karlovacko beer from Croatia, nice surprise seeing that on the menu.
author: K C.

description:
If you're looking for a date night place, Mazzat is perf.  The menu is a bit difficult to understand if you're not familiar with Mediterranean food, but there's an option that's $18/person, and you get to choose 3 hot and 3 cold mazzat to share with unlimited pita bread!  

My roommate and I didn't really know what we were doing, so we let the waiter take over.  We told him a couple that we were interested in, and let him pair for us... and I'm glad we did that!

We ended up getting:
COLD:
1) Hummus (can't really go wrong)
2) Warek Enab (grape leave wrapped thing) - both of our least favourite
3) Shankaleesh (feta cheese with tomatoes, onions, olive oil - most flavourful / zesty of all the things we ordered, and my favourite cold mazzat!)

HOT:
1) Falafel (thought it'd be kind of boring to order, but turned out to be both our favourite (hot) mazzat!)
2) Mujadara (lentil rice + yogurt sauce on the side.  my roommate loved this, but I didn't think it tasted like anything.  I mixed it with the Shankaleesh and Eraydiss for flavour though!)
3) Eraydiss (looks like shrimp gumbo, but is basically just mushy eggplant.  shrimp was really good, but the vegetables were forgettable)

FYI: I posted a picture, but the falafels were on the side.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Started off nicely enough. Cute ambiance, kind maitre d, and a romantic table for two. Tried a couple Lebanese red wines and one was surprisingly tasty and full bodied. 

Then everything went downhill. The hot hummus with beef came out room temperature. Halloumi cheese was mediocre. When our entrees came out, I was still excited because I basically lived on kafta when I lived in Turkey and was curious what the Lebanese twist (if any) would be. Too bad Mazzat's were barely edible. Super dry, unseasoned, with what tasted like tomato sauce straight from the jar (and not even Newman's Own standard).

Here's the worst part. After only a couple bites of my entree, I looked up at my fiance in complete panic. At the beginning of the evening, I explicitly told the waitress that he's allergic to nuts and yet she forgot about the almonds in the jasmine rice. My fiance, not knowing any better, was already 4 bites in, before feeling his throat close up. He ran home, while I stayed to take care of the bill.

When I told the waitress, "Ahem, there are nuts in his rice," she responded, "But those are almonds." Lady, if you don't know almonds are nuts, you should not be working at a restaurant! Worst of all, she didn't take anything off the bill, even though he ran out of the restaurant after only a few bites. 

I'm only giving 2 stars because when I explained the situation to the manager, he took both my entree and my fiance's off the check. So I tipped him 20%, which I sincerely went to him and not that horrid waitress. Management, if you're reading, fire that waitress. Manager-- you were a sweetheart and handled the situation perfectly. Thank you. Though we're never coming back...
author: Alyssa Y.

description:
Good service but the meat has no taste. No Middle Eastern or Lebanese flavor at all.

Got the Shawarma wrap, avoid...
author: Narma G.

description:
Another great experience!  2 times in one week!

Food is absolutely superb.  We always opt for a bunch of hot/cold Mezze and one meal and share it amongst ourselves.  It's the best way to taste the many great dishes here. 

The restaurant is on the smaller side, so if you can, make a reservation!
author: Matt V.

description:
It's really hard to do bad Middle Eastern food. On the other hand, it's also hard to do really good Middle Eastern food. Mazzat does it! Sandwich was mind-blowingly good, and freaking huge. And not super expensive, unlike a lot of Middle Eastern places. A++.

Place was packed though. Next time will have to figure out if can book reservations...
author: B H.

description: This is literally my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Period.
author: Dave L.

description:
Came here for dinner.

They sat us very quick as the previous party left right away. It took them more than 15 mins to bring us some water although we asked twice!!!

We ordered Lentil Soup, babaganoush, fava bean dish and falafel wrap.

Lentil soup was VERY salty!! Price was higher than what we normally pay for lentil soup($8 which normally is around $5-6) in any Mediterranean restaurant.

Babaganoush was also soooooo salty!! It was enough that killed the eggplant flavor.

Fava bean dish was very blend and was warm to cold!! It didn't have much of a texture.

Extra bread and falafel wrap were ok and nothing special!!

In general, it was overpriced for the food and service was not as we expected from the reviews considering so many other good Mediterranean restaurants that we have been in the city. Probably won't go back again.
author: Faranak R.

description: This is the first time I'm going to right a bad review for anyone/biz, but I feel like I'm tired of not speaking up when I'm not happy. So here it is: I found this place on yelp it had good reviews and all. But the food is even close to deserve this ratings. The lentil soap as ok somewhat tasteless, the salad was just stupid! They put this pile of romaine lettuce with a bunch of chunks on it with some more big chunks of radish, cucumbers and papers in a small plate. I have high cholesterol, so I ask for the dressing on side. So I can make sure it's not too much oil.  It was half oil/Not virgin olive oil and something thick like balsamic, but it didn't taste like. Than I order a falafel for my husband. I decided to take a bite the falafel was cold on the inside and churckely(I know it's not a word, but this one deserve it). I can't believe this dinner cost me $49.  Sorry for typos I'm writing this very quickly.
author: Sil B.

description: Mazzat is just the best Lebanese place in town. Friendly staff, amazing food, we feel at home every time.
author: tennyson p.

description: Delicious. Great vegetarian options. Their shared appetizer dinner is amazing and only costs $20/person for a full meal. Highly recommend the Fatet Batinjan.
author: Divya R.

description:
Food was great, Atmosphere amazing.
Love local shops and the service.
author: Mo M.

description: I ate here after the Women's March and really enjoyed it. I love Mediterranean food and really enjoyed sharing lots of mezze.  One of my favorite dishes was a pickled eggplant dish that was really unique. Will definitely come back.
author: Emily S.

description:
Hummus and Majudara are good here. Majudara is lentil rice that comes with carrots.

Hummus is kinda spicy that gives you an awesome taste. I had a great dinner here!
author: Pratik J.

description: Super delicious, authentic Lebanese food at a decent price point. Ambiance is cute, casual, and a little romantic. Love this place.
author: Ali H.

description: Tasty, unique food and good service.  A little compact-one of those places where you might be close enough to hear the next table's conversation, but very pleasant ambiance and good food.  I especially liked the pickled eggplant!
author: Jill G.

description: Mazzat was a lot of fun! Great options, service, and ambiance. I was so surprised at how delicious the Lebanese coffee was. The only downside was that it was a bit cold due to the door opening and closing all the time. Me and my party split the platter and shared a plethora of dishes. The lentil soup was delicious as well!
author: Becky T.

description: My favorite place in Hayes Valley for the delicious food and kind staff. Plus is that it is not filled with the disgusting normal white yuppy garbage that every other bar/restaurant is now swarmed with. Stay beautiful Mazzat!
author: Gertrude E.

description: Hands down my favorite Mediterranean spot in SF. Always get the Mazzat platter and LOVE every dish: the fried cauliflower is life-changing and the hummus is some of the best I've ever had. Atmosphere is great! Restaurant is nicely furnished.
author: Jones B.

description: Delish! Staff very friendly! Fun to share plates with friends! Great for vegans!
author: Pj M.

description: I didn't catch the name of our server, but we had a great time here for my buddy's birthday. We'll be back when we get the chance.
author: Byron M.

description:
Came in looking for a table for 4 on a rainy day and there was no wait. That was pretty much where the pros of my dinner ended. 

Cons:
1. It took a very long time. Once seated we were ignored for a while. Once orders were placed, we waited 30+ min. One of the staff came by and said it would be out shortly. 

2.  Cold food. I had ordered a lamb dish that was a stew that came with a side of rice. It Came out cold.  I brought this to their attention and my dish was whisked away without much comment and reappeared also without comment 5-10 min later. 

3. The food itself was just ok. Surprisingly lacking in the spices that I associate with Lebanese food. It was a lamb stew with okra. Maybe a little salty and a little sweet but without much flavor. Same for most of the other dishes at our table. 

4. Worse of all was that we felt that we were forced to overtip. For a table of 4 or more they automatically add on a 20% tip which is normal. But they add on the tip before the tax so you're taxed on that as well. So really it was 21.8% mandatory tip for terrible service. We never had the same waiter coming by twice even when they did come by. 

Considering all the good reviews, what a disappointment!  Will never come back especially with so many better restaurants in the area.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
A group of 4 and us ended up in Mazzat last Friday for dinner. My husband and I were the only Lebanese in the group. The place is tiny making it very cozy, recommended for dates. The service was very professional and quick. The food is AUTHENTIC! look it's not 100% real lebanese taste but it's a damn 95% ( the ingredients in the USA taste different than those in Lebanon to be fare ) 

It made me feel I am back in my country. The chanklish, the makdous, the babaghanouj everything was great! And they do Tabbouleh the way it should be done! without that quinoa sh**. 

Some dishes were more of fusion than authentic like the fatet. But they have Lebanese beer Almaza! 

So overall if you are looking for a new culinary authentic experience give it a try I am sure you will love it.
author: Tamara S.

description: Small but busy Lebanese restaurant in Hayes Valley- perfect for a fun date. I highly recommend getting the platter, which comes with 3 hot and 3 cold dishes and ends up being way more food than we can finish! The eggplant with yogurt and fries pita is amazing. Definitely call ahead as this place can get crowded.
author: J L.

description: Small cozy spot. You might end up at a weird table with really wobbly stools. The floor is uneven in some spots. The house white wine I got was awful, but the food is amazing.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Me and my boyfriend ordered Spinach Fatayer and can you believe the staff microwaved it in front of us?! Gees..talk about no shame. 

As expected, the spinach fatayer did not taste that great. You can tell it was microwaved by the temperature difference of the exterior and the interior. 
The inside spinach filling was steaming hot and the bread exterior was mildly warm. The bread exterior was soft and not very satisfying.

 I can imagine that if the spinach fatayer was warmed up in the oven, the quality would have immensely improved, ending up with a crusty exterior. 
What a disappointment. Me and my boyfriend will never come here again.
author: Charlene C.

description: Come here with friends and share their small plates! Everything we had here was excellent. We shared an entree and five small plates--between the four of us, we were all full. We wished they had a slightly bigger alcohol menu with a better beer selection, so I wouldn't recommend this for happy hour/drinking. However, it's an excellent option for dinner!
author: Dorie C.

description: Great Lebanese resturant with great ambiance. The service was out standing spec silly Adel...he was very kind.
author: Nic S.

description: Really deliciously food. Chicken is so tender. Beef and lamb also very good. Nut, pea, rice, sauce mixed to make a vary tast. My father said American can make delicious food why they eat bread. No air conditioning, kitchen mix with bar, small space. But the good taste will make me back again.
author: 楠

description:
Nothing blew my mind and left me wanting more, but it also wasn't terrible either. The highlight of our experience was server, who was prompt and quick to refill our drinks.
We started off our meal with an appetizer of hummus, the pita bread was warm and tasted fresh baked. I also got the kafta - which was good, but I have had better. Would I go again? Sure. But would this be at the top of my list of places to go. Probably not.
author: Kim K.

description:
Our second experience with Lebanese food. Very delicious. Especially enjoyed the Ouzi, a yummy rice. Didn't get the Schwarma-will next time. 
Quick service. Went early on a Friday and got seated right away. Done in under an hour. Nice ambience.
author: Patty P.

description:
Still love this place. This is probably one of my most frequented restaurants in San Francisco, and as a huge meat eater, saying this about a place where meat is not their front-and-center, is saying A LOT.

The mazzat platter combo is still one of the best deals in San Francisco for a dinner/meal at $18 per person, for a combination of 3 hot and 3 cold mazzats, beautifully and artfully presented to you, as well as bountiful and more than enough!
author: Joshua L.

description:
DELICIOUS!! Maybe I just ordered all the right dishes because I see the reviews haven't been so hot. For two people we had plenty of food sharing two appetizers and a large plate/dinner. We got the mosaka (eggplant) which was delicious as well as the spicy potatoes (batata harra)- which was yummy but I felt like I could have made something similar roasting potatoes and adding sriracha. 

Kabsseh is the main plate we got (rice, veggies, tender chicken thigh)- the meat was sooo juicy and flavorful! Portion was also huge. I'd highly recommend the Kabsseh.

Also a good venue for large parties (lots of platters), or on a date at the bar (they seem to have nice cocktails).
author: Connie W.

description:
One of the best meals of my life. I ordered the Mezzat Platter and the food was absolutely perfect. I am very picky and have tried many different types of hummus, dolma, etc. 

Mazzat was one of the most delicious Mediterranean meals EVER. It is authentic, housemade, Lebanese perfection.
author: Kathryn D.

description:
Tried this place about a month ago. First time we ordered wine along with some hot and cold mazzat dishes. Food is yummy and very well priced. Second time we tried the combo dish where you can pick 3 hot & 3 cold entree for $20/person. We went home all stuffed with the yummy food 

Parking can be a nightmare in this area on a Friday or Saturday due to close location of too many restaurants
author: Kishor K.

description: I cannot say enough about how great the humus tastes! The other food is great too! The service is wonderful as well!
author: Traci E.

description:
Warm pita, humus, and beef. Everything I can ask for except the extra beef.

I've had a sit down at this place and the ambiance is arguably one of the best in the valley. Combine with a reasonable price and it's an easy four.

Medium volume makes it especially intimidate -- hard to hear without leaning in a bit, not too loud, you know, just loud enough to make everyone else fade into the background. Dim lighting with hard spots here and there -- makes it feel like you're stealing away into the evening. Perfect for sharing a bottle of wine and a warm plate.

In any case the hummus is savory and the pita is warm. But don't take my word for it. Walk in, grab some takeout, and remember the place as a good one to drink at.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Forgetting my credit card from lunch and finding a perfect parking spot left us with the option of finding a dinner spot on a Friday night in Hayes Valley.

We have driven by Mazzat many times and vowed to try it one day so today was the pefect night. Arriving without a reservation around 7:00pm, we were seated promptly. The restaurant is small but the ambiance is charming, as perfect for couples as it is for groups.

We opted for the mazzat platter and choosing 6 items. Normally you can only choose 3 cold and 3 hot items but our server was nice and allowed us to choose one more hot item over the cold.

Favorites: 
Egglant bajinjan-wow, this was amazingly delicious
Shrimp-they give you quite a bit
Lebna-creamy cheese that goes well with pita bread

The pita bread was also warm and very soft.
author: Betty C.

description: I can't figure out why this place isn't packed every night with people, this restaurant is a little gem in SF! Why? Well, the food is simply delicious if you like Mediterranean style, service is nice, price very cheap and there's always room to sit! What are you waiting for?
author: Julien S.

description:
Came here to catch up with a friend. We decided to order the 3 hot 3 cold platter for $18 per person, and it turned out to be a really, really good idea. I'm enthralled by the idea of having multiple small plates, because at the end of the meal I was satisfied but not stuffed. This is key when trying to lose weight and eat healthily.

Interior deco is very nice. Not too modern that it becomes cold. Lots of dark wood and yellowish lights, which I really enjoyed looking at.

We ordered hummus, Mosaka, Lubieh Bezait, Ouzi, Warek Enab, and Khyar Blaban. My favorite dish was the Mosaka by far -- the eggplants were soft and the garlic-tomato sauce was delectable. Of course, our meal came with a nice wire bowl full of soft+warm pita bread that we gladly cleared off. I really enjoyed the food I ordered this time and I definitely want to return, to continue the courting stage when first familiarizing self with a restaurant.
author: Vivian L.

description:
There's something about Hayes Valley that makes me crave Levantine fare. I know this doesn't make any sense. Why should overpriced boutiques and uber-trendy schnitzel-shops that I can't get into (YOU know who I'm talking about) shift my thoughts to grape leaves, olives, and flatbread? I don't know. I'm a complicated man. Let's move on.

Mazzat (like mezze) means "appetizer" and that is what you should order. The menu is decidedly anti-entrée, burying a handful of dinners near the back. Some were even crossed out on my visit. Instead, you should trust the overture of mazzat options: they are helpfully divided into hot and cold. These run about $8-10 each, but a sampler platter gets you 6 (3 hot, 3 cold) for $20 per seated diner. 

Me and my two dates (a "tripoli" if you will... eh?)  shared a few items. The hummus harr is a spicy hummus topped with fried pine nuts. I loved it. The baseball-sized portion never seemed to disappear no matter how much toasted pita I threw at it. And I went hard. We skipped the halloumi (though tempting) in favor of the labne: creamy kefir topped with olive oil. It tasted like zesty Greek yogurt and that is more than acceptable. We also gave some Lebanese "pizza" a try. Basically it's flatbread topped with zataar. Not bad, but I think sticking to the mazzat menu is the way to go.

I left stuffed and I would definitely return.

Obligatory Title Pun: ZAT's all folks!

Menu Readability: Blech. White centered sans on a black field topped with a strange almost oily header typeface. Pregnant with typos. 

Need to mention: They have some Lebanese wine on the menu if you're into that kind of thing.

What this place teaches me about myself: When a $800 sweater rubs me the wrong way, I can find peace in the Middle East.
author: Vivek S.

description: Great service. Great food. Great prices. Came here for a date night and I won't ever forget it.
author: Lauren C.

description: Great neighborhood joint. Depending on the day of the week they will run out of falafel. Otherwise, make sure to try the Ouzi and a shwarma. The preparation is delicious.
author: Steven O.

description:
Amazingly flavorful food, good service, and great deals on dinner make Mazzat a wonderful place to go out with a middle eastern flare.

I came to this place on the recommendation of my good friend and we met up here with her husband on a Thursday. The place is small, but has lovely, darker decor and varied levels of seating (low, high). We were greeted and seated promptly, and we had time to catch up while waiting to order. When their dishes came out 10 mins before mine, the staff were attentive and got mine out asap.

They had the platter deal where it is $18 each for three hot and three cold appetizers. From the warm and soft chickpeas to the crispy eggplant and lamb with rice, each had a varied texture and set of flavors. Nothing was overwhelming, everything tasted great. I had the chicken over rice, which was a huge mound of a cinnamon-infused rice with peas, carrots, raisins and almond and pine nuts. The chicken thighs were tender and very moist, yum!

I couldn't have been happier with my dinner at Mazzat, I had leftovers of delicious chicken over spiced rice and a great time out with friends. Head out if you would like to taste the flavor of Lebanon in a luscious atmosphere with amazing scents.
author: Jim A.

description:
Vivek A. and I opted out of the shared mazzat platter and ordered individual dishes of what yelpers recommended most.

Ambience:
Came in on a Tuesday evening at 7 and not a single person was eating here. Very quiet the whole dinner through. Dim lighting, festive music and simple decor.

Food:
+Eggplant/Fatet Bajinjan- YUMMY!! so much flavor and the croutons were a great touch
+Beef Hummus & Pita- pretty small serving and too much olive oil that the beef was floating in
+ Kebna- described as kefir cheese but is more of a yogurt with a ton of olive oil on top

Service:
Attentive. Fast. and Friendly enough.

I'd come back for the eggplant and try the Shankaleesh.

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
Tiny place that could easily be missed except for the fact that it's right on the corner of the road. I'm surprised my friend managed to get a table for 10+ people reserved here for a birthday dinner.

I was vegetarian for the day, and decided to get a few hot mazzats to try. I ordered the falafel, the fried cauliflower, the moussaka and the holloumi cheese. Apparently I did well ordering since the waitress complimented only my choices ;) Heh heh.

The dishes were excellent, and you could get all the pita bread you wanted to go with them. The holloumi cheese was chewy, much like some sort of string cheese, quite salty, and fried. You don't want to eat that alone. The falafel was fried just right, and the moussaka was not the layered version -- rather, the mashed eggplant version, but it was still delicious. The cauliflower came out late so by the time I had it I was quite full, but I still liked it.

It was overall a great meditarranean experience in a homey restaurant that has a lot to offer. They also have some Lebanese wine as well!
author: Alice C.

description: We ordered a variety of hot and cold appetizers, which all came out fairly quickly for the table to share. We also ordered a kafta, which was served after all the apps (which makes sense, but our intention was to have a family style dinner with all the plates) - and unfortunately, this was the worst dish of them all. Generally all the apps were decent, but the highlights were the babaghanouge and mosaka. The haloumi cheese was a teeny portion and there was another app that was supposed to be eggplant but tasted like very pickled olives.
author: Amy Y.

description: Food is okay but under no circumstances is this lebanese food. Do not be fooled. I have lived in the Middle East my whole life and i was excited when i saw a lebanese restaurant. This was just disappointing.
author: Shaun T.

description: Super sweet, spot. Lovely waiters and great Mediterranean fare. Walked in just to have a few appetizers and some drinks and were totally surprised by great food and wonderful service. Healthy food and cozy spot !
author: A B.

description:
Delicious food, nice staff.
I was there twice, first time I dined in, on the second day I ordered togo.
The only problems I had there is parking your car, which is not the restaurant fault it is just san francisco, but what I did to like is when I ordered togo the put my yogurt cucumber in a white paper container, when I opened my bag in the hotel the container was all wet and  the yogurt was all over the other containers, I had to through it away, You should get a plastic container for yogurt and hummus.
The other part that is this is a lebanese restaurant and they HAVE NO grill Kebab???
author: Sam M.

description: Our family came twice to Mazzat this week, because once was not enough. We are just visiting SF.  Our waiter, Adil (?) was very sweet and helpful. (The young guy with brown curly hair). Our waitress Lisa was also nice. Great food, we had hummus, pita, falafel, lentil soup, rice, and a bunch of other dishes. Two thumbs up to this hidden gem!
author: Ashley M.

description: The food was amazing! Great quality..the owner's wife is super sweet as well. Definetly recommend this place especially at night time. The knefe is the best dessert they have hands down. I like their Hummus, Warak Enab and love their Fattoush and the taste of the vinegar. YUM. In addition, for entrees, I definitely recommend the Kafta and the Bemye. Although small, but great place all in all
author: Jaafar L.

description: We ordered the shankalah, falafel, and hummus harr to start with, which were SPECTACULAR. The server also recommended the perfect bottle of argentine Cabernet. We also order the ouzi rice with meat, which was disappointingly bland. The meat in the ouzi also tasted old and repurposed. We shared the kafta dinner, which was so delicious and comforting. We ended with cardamom coffee, which could have been stronger in my opinion, and extremely delicious baklava.
author: Seghel Y.

description: Good middle eastern good. Surprises in check. Won't be back as I'm from the east bay.
author: Ari B.

description:
Went here for the second time last night with a group and had another great experience. Nice ambiance, friendly service, and delicious Lebanese food.

We shared the 1. Hummus with Beef 2. Musabaha (chickpeas w/ lemon juice garlic and olive oil) 3. Tabouli 4. Bamia (Sauteed okra w/ tomato sauce and lamb)

The table was very happy with all of these choices. My favorite was the Hummus w/ Beef and the Tabouli was a close second! Great place for sharing bites.
author: Gabryell H.

description: The first thing we noticed on walking into Mazat is a smell of toilet, cleaning products and something moldy.  We soon realized why the restaurant didn't smell like food. They don't cook there, just warm stuff up.  I wouldn't mind if the food tasted good but between eggplant soaked in old grease and dried rice, it was an embarrassment to Lebanese cuisine.
author: Hadas R.

description:
I really, really wanted to like Mazzat. And the prices are reasonable, and it's a friendly, comfy neighborhood spot. But the food just doesn't stand up.

Unfortunately, they don't serve kebbeh nayeh, the quintessential mezze made of lamb/steak tartar with bulgur and spices. They only serve regular (deep fried) kebbeh, which was forgettable and not particularly flavorful..

The fatet batinjah was decent. The fatoush salad was tragically overdressed -- the lettuce was drowning in the dressing.

The kafta, like the kebbeh, was uninteresting, bland and totally forgettable. The only real winner (and it was still just good, not great) was the kabsseh, which while suffering from way too much rice-to-chicken ratio, was flavorful and benefitted from the yogurt accompaniment. 

I may be ruined by a recent trip to Montreal, when I had one of the best meals of my life at Damas (check out my Yelp review for it). Unfortunately it set a high bar for Levant cuisine that sadly Mazzat doesn't come close to approaching.
author: David C.

description: Authentic restaurant. Got the mint lemonade - very good. The rice dish was also very good. Portions were huge or maybe I'm just not hungry. Whatever it was I took the leftovers to go. Come check this place out!
author: Gilad P.

description: Wow. In top 5 of my favorite restaurants in SF. Amazing hummus, pita, and other dishes. The ordering system for Mazzats is a little confusing.  The right way to do it is to do the 3 cold and 3 hot mazzats for $20/per person. They adjust the portions depending on the number of people in your group. We did not know this the first time and we ordered individual mazzats and left hungry. Came back again because it was so good and did $20/person deal and left very full with leftovers. They should do a better job explaining this on the menu or just make the deal required for dinner and open it up to more options (like the pizza). Looking to stop by sometime for lunch and get a wrap.
author: Hank K.

description: Love love love Mazzat. Personally, the dinner sampler for two is ideal: it's $18pp and you get two cold and two hot apps to choose from. Everything you can think of from hummus to babaganuche to feta salad and much more. It's a lovely atmosphere, relaxed service (much like the Mid East) and just an all around delicious place I have always seemed to enjoy. Bonus: portions are hearty; I always come home with leftovers and get a lunch the next day out of it. Can't beat that for $18.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Very good food. We did the Mazzat sampler that includes 3 hot and 3 cold appetizers and it was enough food for four (including two teens). My wife got the lentil soup and lived it as well.
Friendly staff, relaxed atmosphere, reasonable prices. We were originally headed to the German place on the next block but the wait was 1.5 hours so we stumbled on this place. Glad we did!
author: Brent S.

description: Absolutely delicious. The best Lebanese food I have ever tasted. Portions are smaller and meant for sharing family style, which is more fun too because you get to taste everything! Next time I am in SF, I will go here again.
author: Andrea P.

description: My wife and I found this place on a stroll looking for a place for dinner. I got the wrap and she got the grape leaves and lemon cauliflower. Everything was way delicious! We were very happy with the service and the atmosphere. We would recommend it.
author: Benjamin H.

description: Food was good. Horrible service. Waitress checked up once with us but only filled up one water cup when there were 2 other empty cups. Didn't come to pick up our check and picked up a personal phone call instead. When paying for the meal I planned on tipping with cash since it is easier for everyone. But when I typed in "no tip" on her phone, she got rude. Still left a tip. Will not not return.
author: Jeronimo F.

description: It's one of my favorite Mediterranean place in the city. Everything is so good and well made. My favorites are their Labne and Fatet Batinjan.  Decent wine selection too. Copy and cute atmosphere that's unpretentious.
author: Hema P.

description:
3.5 
Decent place for dinner in Hayes Valley. I can't vouch for authenticity as I'm no expert in judging Lebanese fare but there seems to be many opinions on this. 

We ordered the...
-Kabsse - jasmine rice with some cooked veggies, nuts and yogurt topped with chicken thighs
-Hummus with flatbread
-Falafel with tahini 

It was a lot of food! 

My thoughts: The falafel was hard, dry and overcooked. I was only able to eat one out of the four. The Kabsse was flavorful and portions were great for sharing. Hummus was fairly basic and standard. Everything was bit pricier than it should have been in my opinion. 

Service was pleasant provided to us by a young gentleman who made sure we were satisfied and enjoying our dinner. 

I'd come back and give them another try again.
author: Esther A.

description:
An intimate restaurant with twinkly lights automatically gets some major points from me. There were also a few large parties (between 8-12) while we were there but the staff didn't forget about us party-of-two-ers. Overall, great date ambiance in a fun location (Hayes Valley) to walk around before or after.

We ordered the mazzat platter and got:
--Mosaka: amazing. We got it with beef and I couldn't get enough of it. The eggplant was creamy and tomato-garlicky. If you're on an early date, you may want to skip it but if you don't care about diving headfirst into garlic deliciousness, go for it.
--Fatet Batinjan: same as above. The eggplant was cooked the same creamy way but it was more yogurty than tomato-y. My other favorite from the entire meal.
--Ouzi: A good item to have if you don't like pita but want carbs. It wasn't anything special, though.
--Hummus harr: didn't taste that spicy at the time, although it somehow got spicier when I had the leftovers for breakfast. It had more tahini than I like in hummus and wouldn't order it again.
--Mutabal: my least favorite dish that we ordered. The eggplant was too sour.
--Jebneh & Zaytoon: pretty straightforward cucumbers, olives, feta, and tomatoes.

I would 100% go back to order the mosaka and fatet batinjan again. The wait staff were friendly and overall it was a fun place to have dinner.
author: Marissa G.

description: Great service and amazing food - get the tasting platter so you can have a bit of everything with a friend :)
author: Lindsay Y.

description: Coming from a Lebanese family, I always missed the traditional food from Lebanon in San Francisco, which is so full of flavors and colors. Today I finally found a place that reminds the food my grandmother used to cook for me. It's just very authentic and tasteful! My husband and I are definitely coming back here anytime we miss kafta, babaganush or rice with lentils and onions. Oh, don't miss the labne!!! It's just perfect.
author: Renata B.

description:
With all the great reviews, maybe I was expecting just a bit more...overall, I thought this place was good.

We tried a few dishes shared between 5 people: Kebbeh (fried pastry filled with beef and pine nuts), Hummus with Beef, Halloumi Cheese (grilled cheese), Ouzi (rice with lamb, beef and spices) and Hummus.  Everything was good, but not necessarily fantastic.  The warm/hot dishes arrived lukewarm and it changed the experience for me a bit.  I guess another thing that bothered me a bit was the price point - everything here is served "tapas" style, but you're almost paying the price for a full entrée.  

The service was friendly and very attentive.  I would come back to this place as far as a light snack or a place to dine if you're not really hungry since you can easily spend a lot of money for not very much food.
author: Ken G.

description:
Great food. Would have received 5 stars had they informed our party of 6 before dinner that they would only accept no more than two credit cards. After being informed after receiving our bill, the host left and didn't offer any solutions around this (split the tab into two tabs?). No one at our table had ever encountered this before so we were surprised and unprepared. It all worked out!

Bring cash!
author: Nancy S.

description: This was my first visit to eat in after having ordered take away a couple of times. Unfortunately the food just wasn't very good. I was raised by a Lebanese mother, who was an amazing cook, and this food was not good nor authentic.
author: phil b.

description:
DINERS BEWARE- I came into this restaurant last Monday looking to get something to go. I decided to get a $12 chicken shawerma which was very good. However, I just looked at my credit card statement and the waiter tipped himself an extra $85 in addition to the $1 I gave him for a TO GO order. The food here was good, but in my experience if someone has the audacity to change the amount originally purchased, they probably carry that shadyness over in other parts of their life. While I enjoyed the meal, it's not worth the headache I am going through with my bank to clear this up.

tip to people who want to eat here: If you pay card, check how much they end up charging
tip to restaurant: fire whoever was working Monday, 2/10 around 7pm at the bar.
author: Ray M.

description: Ok the service is pretty good, they have a good import selection of some actual Lebanese products, and the food is decent. But if you're looking for some quality Lebanese food still not the place....
author: Geoffrey M.

description:
Great little Lebanese place in Hayes Valley.

Came in on a sunday night for a double-date and we couldn't have picked a better spot. Cute, intimate, and most importantly delicious.

We ordered two Mazzat Platter (3 cold & 3 hot appetizers) and the dishes were both delicious and beautiful. We had some hummus, mosaka, tabouli, beef & lamb rice, eggplant, and a few other succulent dishes. 

Minus one star for the slower-than-average service and them running out of beef at 8:30pm. Also, the mazzat salad was a bit parsley-heavy and light on the couscous but the atmosphere, portion sizes, prices and friendly service easily make up for the very few drawbacks.

Very versatile. Bring your date, friends, parents, or all of the above! One of the better Mediterranean places I've been to in SF.
author: Teiki K.

description:
What a sad restaurant experience.  This is one of the few places where the food is not just "not good," but actually bad to the point where we had difficulty eating it.

We had the grilled halloumi (just okay) and the smoky eggplant.  The smoky eggplant was covered in pomegranate molasses (uncooked) so it was extremely sour and our table did not finish it.  

The menu you see online is not the menu you get, with about 40% of it being blacked out with a marker.  Additional items are also unavailable, for example, they were out of chicken (!) when I went on a Thursday night.  I could not order the chicken schwarma.   I got the falafel wrap and it was the driest wrap I've ever had.  It had not tzatiki or tahini or tomato or anything with any juice or liquid whatsoever.  It had tabouli in it, which I've never seen.  We asked for tzatiki and received it.   Did not finish this entree due to it being bad.

We ended up going somewhere else and eating more food.
author: Kelly M.

description:
This place is just so Average.. Hell, I felt like this is a quintessential 3-star rating for me to compare to others in the future!  
Portions are not tiny, but not quite big enough
Food is not bad, but just not that good - you have flavours, there are just not much of it, it feels like it comes short.
They took order really fast, but didnt refill out waters. 
It's not really expensive, it's just not quite worth it.
author: Anton K.

description: Lovely place to eat at late night. Dark atmosphere and delicious food. I had the Kabsse and it was more than enough. The chicken was just right too. And you must finish your dinner with a cup of coffee, It is served best here. The staff were all friendly and attentive.
author: Kyle Y.

description:
My friend and I visited Mazzat on a Sunday night and found this Lebanese restaurant moderately busy with mostly couples in their thirties and up. With its mood lighting and candlelit date-sized tables, this intimate restaurant is a great option for a classy dinner with a friend or a nice date. The restaurant serves wine and has a cozy bar area as well.

We ordered the Mazzat platter, which comes with your choice of 3 hot options and 3 cold options (2 person order minimum). If you're a first-timer at Mazzat, I'd highly recommend going the platter route, just so you can sample a little bit of everything in case you want to order a whole plate of something on your next visit. It was a reasonable price for a great selection of food, and we were both full by the end of our meal. 

We ordered the following: 

1. Kebbeh (fried beef balls)- hot
2. Fatet batinjan (fried eggplant with yogurt sauce)- hot
3. Ouzi (jasmine rice with ground lamb and beef)- hot
4. Hummus harr (hummus with garlic/lemon/chili paste)- cold
5. Tabouli (wheat with mint and parsley in lemon juice/ olive oil)- cold
6. Mazzat salad (feta and parsley)- cold

My personal favorites were the hot platter options, especially the fatet batinjan and the ouzi. The fried breaded part of the eggplants was complemented nicely by the yogurt sauce, and the jasmine rice, although a bit bland, was a good offset to our cold platters. As for the cold dishes, I thought the tabouli and Mazzat salad were slightly too lemony for my taste, but the hummus harr we had on pita bread had a full-bodied flavor.

The service was cordial and helpful. We sat at the bar, and both our waitress and the bartender were patient in explaining the dishes we weren't familiar with (i.e. most of them). Though I don't think I'll be splurging very often on Mazzat, it was a wonderful dining experience and I look forward to going back!
author: Esther W.

description: Delicious food, great service! We love Mediterranean food, And the food was very tasty .
author: Shalini K.

description:
We were there with my husband on Friday night and we really enjoyed it. 

After circling the area for 25 minutes in the attempt to find parking, and then stepping into crowded  Suppenkuche and feeling our eardrums popping out, we decided to try  Mazzat which was right next block.   This  place with it's dim lighting and friendly waiters seemed very inviting.  There was no wait time, although  it was quite busy.  The ambiance was great.  The noise was medium,  so we had to raise our voices, but we didn't have to shout. 

The food was good, without being anything extremely special.  I loved the warm pita and eggplant appetizer.  My husband took shwarma and I had a bite of it and it was pretty good.    Also, we had fried cauliflower, and it was ok.  The green beans could have been much better. 

Overall we had a very pleasant experience.  We would go there again, either with a group of friends or just two of us, and hopefully next time we would be luckier finding parking.
author: Michelle R.

description: We ordered the 3 hot and 3 cold platter / $18 per person.  Food came very quickly.  I enjoyed everything.  Portion size is good.  Drank delicious French red wine.  Talking is difficult for large group but manageable for two people.  A bit too loud for my liking.
author: Eric D.

description:
Good lamb schwarma. Dripped grey grease though. Delicious grey grease.

And you can't hear anyone seated across from you. But meh. Get it to go.
author: Emily D.

description:
We had a great experience at Mazzat. Our previous one was subpar as the service was lacking and the food was uninspired. This time, we decided to stop by again because of all the Yelpers who claimed this as a top spot in Hayes - and boy are we glad we gave it a second shot.

The Food and service were excellent.

The Mazzat Salad - parsley tomatoes and feta. A perfect blend of freshness and citrus to keep your palette ready for the oncoming onslaught of awesomeness.

The Fried Eggplant with Croutons - the yogurt sauce balances well with the richness of the eggplant. One of my favorite dishes.

The Kebseh - we finished here and were happy to put a big exclamation on the dinner. The jasmine rice was delicious and the chicken thighs are cooked in a nutty tomato sauce that is well seasoned. Easily the best dish of our meal.

We'll be back!
author: Justin O.

description: I'm lebanesse and the food was very oily but tasty. We were the first to be there and the place smelled bad and the restroom was dirty
author: Geraldine S.

description: The food was ok, nothing to write home about.  I tried a double bock czech beer though that I thought was really good.
author: Brian M.

description: WOMEN watch out! If you're alone, you'll be ordered to the bar. If you ask for a table, staff will confer. Blatant sexism ruins the experience. Saw this with 2 women.
author: Cat M.

description: One of my favorite places in Hayes Valley, fantastic Lebanese cuisine and wonderful staff.  This is a real neighborhood gem, only a block away from the crazy long lines on Hayes St.
author: A Z.

description: Food was delicious and highly authentic (the babaganoush was great among the other dishes)! Enjoyed a wine list that featured some Lebanese options...that were very palatable and enjoyable. Nice establishment and space. Appreciated the casual atmosphere.
author: J K.

description:
A series of pleasant surprises. Looks extremely fancy, but turns out to function like a casual restaurant. Thought it would be expensive, but it's incredibly affordable. Expected regular old Mediterranean food, got easily the best artichoke spinach pita I've ever eaten. 

I don't normally leave reviews, but this place was so awesome, I felt compelled to say thank you.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Some people dream about the lasagna their mom used to make when they were kids.  For me, it's my dad's hummus.  My parents lived in Lebanon for a decade so I grew up eating Lebanese food, and am usually disappointed by Middle Eastern food in restaurants because it doesn't taste the way  it does when my dad makes it.  

Mazzat is the real deal. I took my parents here last time they were in town and everyone was happy with the food.  We had hummus, tabouleh, baba ghanoush, kibbeh, falafel and a few other things, and everything was delicious, and  the consensus was that everything tasted exactly how it's supposed to.  No shortcuts here. They even had Lebanese beer and wine (with extremely generous pours) which I highly recommend; the wine is a little different than what you're used to, but goes perfectly with the food.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Saturday Date Night (Dinner and Movie): Jan 15, 2011 @ 6:00 PM

*Lebanese home-cooked cuisine in San Francisco.*

I was already feeling under the weather but I did not want to miss out on our Saturday Date Night.  I told my guy that I was okay to go!

Prior to catching a movie at Japantown's Kabuki, I wanted a homey, feel-good date night dinner. All I wanted was just some plain comfort food. And I took a chance when I found Mazzat on Yelp without having any idea if this was a dinky or not so pretty old cafe. 

My guy and I were pleasantly surprised when we saw a cozily lit little place on the corner of Fell.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=ml3AweHp31JVirVZVb4EkQ

Mazzat is a cafe. A small cozy and contemporary cafe with glass cabinets filled with mouth-watering mediterranean meat pies and desserts.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=Yo2yUmFTQDQKWK-WCeMg7Q

The far-end wall is a floor to ceiling wine cabinet. Little tealight candles add a touch of a little romance on each table. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=JNpQdOgZhw7OqV2pZs3WDA

The young Lebanese couple who own and run the place were very friendly and welcoming.  Mazzat is newly opened 5 weeks ago.

DINNER: And for $49 (a glass of wine, Diet Coke,  after taxes and before tip) my fiance and I ate well with plenty of leftovers for later. We had:

6 hot/cold Mediterranean tapas for $25, an order of the meat pie to go and Kasbah rice dish. Mazzat's menu is extensive and mouth-watering. They came with a basket of hot buttered pita bread.  It was hard to pick ONLY 6 dishes but we chose: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=KgqvjGS8UxWR5wwoWyQ28w

1. Chicken Pita http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=bODAAT6FxmoyOAJroZA_VA
2. Baba Ganoush
3. Fried Halloumi
4. Falafel
5. Hummus
6. Moussaka

All of the above dishes were generously served and tasty. However, our favorites were the halloumi cheese and the moussaka. The moussaka was extra tasty with lovely spices and great for eating with the pita bread. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=C8myE-G6kr-FMUoehuTzNw

The real star of the show was the KABSA ($10). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=meeB53zP1PA6_ERCfsih8w  The female owner asked us if we wanted to try this rice dish of pine nuts, raisins and exotic spices. She told us that she wanted our honest opinion because she wanted to know if she should include this rice dish as part of the regular menu. The rice was cooked for 5 hours and the spices were from abroad. According to her, Kabsa is not Lebanese by origin but this dish has become popular among Lebanese folks during the last few years. 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kabsa

We were wowed! The  Kabsa  was very delicious. So full of spices and we devoured the whole thing. It came with nice chunks of lamb which my guy happily obliged to eat by himself.

The $5 generously poured Chardonnay was nice and crisp, and paired well with the dishes. ($18 for a bottle of either their white or red.)

We left Mazzat full and satisfied vowing to go back again and again.

MOVIE:  Fifteen minutes into the "Green Hornet" the theater started spinning. I excused myself and found myself parked inside the bathroom throwing up x3.  My guy got worried and looked for me.  He drove me home at the back of his car without us finishing the movie and losing our 3D tickets.

A week later, we were both still in bed recovering from 102 fever and respiratory stuff.

MORAL OF THE STORY:
1. Do not go on a date night when you are sick.
2. Get your flu shot.

5 Stars for the Kabsa and moussaka.
5 Stars for the friendly couple.
5 Stars for the value and portions.
4.5 Stars for the cozy place.
3.5 to 4 Stars for the rest of the tapas.
author: Leah E.

description:
Mazzat is like one of those corner restaurants you pass by in Hayes Valley, but never actually get to try. Or well, at least for me. I finally had a chance to last Friday though, but I was a little disappointed. I liked the decor though, and the ambience was nice, kind of date-sy. My bf and I sat on one of their high tables in the front, one of the things I liked about the restaurant. 

We decided to order the Mazzat platter ($18/person), which includes 3 cold dishes and 3 hot dishes from their menu. They have plenty of choices from each side. For the cold plates, we ordred the halloumi cheese, hummus, and yogurt sauce (forget the name). The halloumi cheese, or "grilled cheese", was squeaky white cheese and included 3 pieces of it; that was pretty good. Hummus was okay; I've had better. I liked the yogurt sauce the most; it was light and minty. Also, their pita bread came out warm and fresh. For the "hot" dishes, we ordered falafel, tangy eggplant, and ouzi. Falafel dish came with 2 pieces, which were not even hot; actually, they weren't even warm, which bothered me. Isn't falafel supposed to be deep-fried?? The tangy eggplant was WAY too tangy. We just  tasted it and could not eat any more. For the ouzi (ground beef and lamb rice), I asked for no lamb because I'm not a huge fan, but they couldn't do that. So I assume their rice is pre-cooked... We also ordered the Kebbeh, which was pretty much ground beef in a deep-fried ball of bread. That one was good.

The service was friendly and attentive, but unfortunately, the food won't be bringing me back here.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I've been wanting to try this new place Mazzat for some time and read great reviews.  I was in the Hayes the other day and just had to check it out.  Located on the southwest corner of Laguna and Fell St.  Just looking at this place, it was very inviting and the same as I walked in as the sweet Lady behind the counter greeted me. 

I new this place would have a variety of small dishes/mezze like tapas, and that was exactly what I was looking for, an array to choose from.  They had a great selection/assortment from your cold/hot mezze.  I already knew what I wanted and ordered the:

- Kibbe - a torpedo-shaped bulgur shell stuffed with a savory filling of   spiced meat that's fried or baked until golden brown

- Halloumi - Delicious fried cheese served with their pita bread

- Meat pie - a savory meat filled pastry

Their Kibbe with the nice bite from the bulgur shell and tasty meat filling was really good.  The Halloumi (fried cheese) did it for me =) I love cheese and all that salty goodness which went perfect with their warm fresh pita bread.  The meat pies are awesome so flavorful, savory like Empanadas...what's not to love about tasty meat filled pastries.

I enjoyed everything I ordered.  It was absolutely delicious and full of flavor.  Great friendly service in a nice cozy, intimate atmosphere.  With their extensive menu, I'll definitely be back to try their other dishes as the owner advised that every thing they are serving is home made from scratch and to come back soon... Taboulleh, Baba ganoush, Moussaka, Sfiha, etc, and not to forget their desserts...I'll be back for sure =)
author: Jayne M.

description:
Came here with 3 other friends (total of 4 of us), and I would say that 4 is the perfect number for a group to come here. The space is a bit small, so any group over 4 would probably be a bit much.

We decided to do the dinner platter for the 4 of us (3 hot, 3 cold dishes) and it was definitely more than enough food to feed everyone. We got eggplant, fava beans, hummus, lamb and rice, roasted eggplant and cheese. Because we chose the platter, the portions of the food are a bit larger. We actually had a lot of each dish left over once we finished dinner.

If you're a big meat eater, your best bet may be to order a completely separate meat dish, as most of the smaller dishes don't carry much meat at all. Of all the dishes, I would probably say the hot, roasted eggplant was my favorite because it carried the most flavor. I was a little underwhelmed by the lamb and rice. It smelled great, but there really wasn't much flavor in the dish. Overall, though, I was really satisfied with the quality of the food. I do wish they gave more pita bread to start though...

The service was only OK - I would say maybe just 3 stars for that... We did find ourselves waiting around a little while to get things like another menu, order another drink, or more water. Considering the number on the wait-staff, with regard to how many seats were filled, that's just what bothered me I guess.

In any event, I'd probably end up coming back here - was a cute little place and the food was good.
author: Shawn B.

description: FINALLY! A Middle Eastern restaurant with food reminiscent of my Lebanese mother's cooking; the food is definitely authentic and incredibly good. I would highly recommend the chicken shawarma-- it is marinated in tasty spices and cooked wonderfully (not some knockoff shishtawook that you will typically find at most Middle Eastern restaurants). For dessert, the Arabic coffee with rice pudding was perfect. I felt like I was in a cafe in Beirut, great experience! They also had Elissa playing in the background, excellent touch.
author: Zeina A.

description: Lentil soup and beirut salad is so good. Ordered a rice dish and spices were strong for me. They totally took it back and gave me what I could eat. Great place with great service.
author: Hyun B.

description:
For some reason I resisted coming here for almost a year even though they are just around the corner from my place.   Mistake on my part.  While it is a bit pricey, they do the standard Maza/Mazzat platter style lebanese food really well.   Their Baba Gann[insert some letters here like ouj or oush or uth] is perfectly smoky and creamy, just like it should be.   And that's good, since Baba is how I judge a middle eastern place like this.  

Waitstaff is friendly enough, though they can be a bit harsh about not letting you combine certain dishes in the platters.  This is not because they don't want to make additions, but because they don't think they will taste good together. They are generally right though, so I can't really complain that they are trying to help me.  Still, it is a bit funny to be told you can't order something because you are wrong, think Tony Shaloub in Big Night, if you know what I mean.

My only real complaints are the price, which feels just a bit more than I'd expect for this fare, and the oiliness, as it seems many of the dishes are swimming in (delicious) olive oil.   Neither of those detract too much from the overall great food and solid atmosphere and decor. 

Definitely will be back.
author: Travis B.

description: Lebanese pizza had nothing to do with pizza. Just crappy canned stuff on bread that came out 20 mites after we were served. Hummus was good. Side of  Yogurt was huge and $6 for no reason. Lamb dish ($18) had 3 tiny pieces of lamb and 2 lbs of potatoes. Would have been good if it had more lamb in it.   Service was good.
author: reza n.

description: Ordered the Mazzat platter and everything was delicious! Every single item was not only very tasty but you could tell was prepared well. Nothing was bland or too aggressively spiced. Would absolutely recommend this place to anyone interested in trying out real deal Lebanese food. Will definitely be back!
author: Chef Derek R.

description:
Hipsters, you can do better.  For the rest of us, our neighborhood deserves better -- better food and better people (the owner is an unprofessional bully). 

First, the food is average to begin with.  Second, they microwave anything served hot.  Yes, last I checked, there is a microwave at the bar.  Regardless, nothing is cooked to order.  And, desserts, forget about it -- out of a box.  Finally, don't support bad service, arrogance, and a business that has no place in our neighborhood.

I really do not understand the ratings.  Are all you people to drunk to notice the poor quality?
author: Kiki I.

description:
Falafel lovers rejoice! Came here for dinner mid-week and was so glad I did. Such a relaxing and inviting place to enjoy a tasty meal. On the smaller side so never got too noisy/crowded, had a really great wine bar-ish vibe. We tried a few things but the standouts in my opinion were the falafel wrap and the HUMMUS! I know hummus can only be so exciting, but there was something about what they offer at Mazzat. 

Everything was really fresh and high quality, service was great, overall a successful dinner on the town!
author: Brianna M.

description:
My bff stopped in at Mazzat for the first time today while walking around looking for a snack or two.  We came across Mazzat and were pleasantly surprised.

Mazzat has a decent selection of Mediterranean/Lebanese food and much of the items are portable and can be taken to go quite easily (zapping things in the microwave at home works well).   While it used to be "Cafe Apollo" I think Mazzat is the same ownership that reinvented Cafe Apollo (my credit card receipt shows as "Apollo Market and Deli").  The Spanakopita (spinach pie) was large, fairly dense with a very nice flaky wrap.  One order of the meat pies gives you 4 decent sized pies -- easily feeds two diners as an appetizer.   The tabouli was fresh and tasty.  The ambiance of Mazzat is a little dull and uninspired but the fast and efficient service makes up for it.  They appear to have a decent selection of wines (see my pics) although since neither I nor my bff are drinkers, I can't really comment much on their wines.

Prices are surprisingly low for Hayes Valley.  One order of Spanakopita, one order of meat pies (comes with 4 pies) and a large order of Tabouli and a bottle of sparking water came in at $15.00 and was a great "snack" for two.  That's a pretty good deal for Hayes Valley.

We will definitely be returning to Mazzat for a larger dinner with friends next time!
author: Paul N.

description: This place is amazing! I've eaten at several restaurants that serve Lebanese/Mediterranean food and this one takes the cake! Make sure you get the hummus, tabbouleh, and the shankaleesh. I'd give it 6 stars if I had the option!
author: Laura L.

description: Pretty awesome.  Quiet, cozy, romantic atmosphere.  Excellent food.  Alcohol is meh at best and expensive.
author: Jolly R.

description:
This place is incredible.
for $18 we can order three hot dishes and 3 cold dishes.
I was lazy to read, so took the suggestion from the waiter.

We had Hummus, amazing salad, some rice with yogurt, fantastic eggplant, grape leave roll, and the other amazing dish.
Everything was super fresh.

All of them are amazing, and the portion is big.
Really enjoyed the food although some of them are very new to me :)
author: Angel W.

description:
Amazing mediterranean menu of small plates and delicious food. Their extensive selection of dishes made choosing difficult, but enjoyed everything we had - yogurt, babaghanoush, fried eggplant, and oh the haloumi (can never go wrong with grilled cheese). 

Quick and reasonably priced, great pre-SF Jazz option!
author: Aki N.

description:
This is a delightful corner neighborhood place with delicious Lebanese food. We usually order a wide range of things and share everything: potatoes, hummus (make sure you get the spicy one, please!), rice and beef (ouzi), falafel, arnabeet, chick peas. 

Go with a date or a small group of people. It's a really comfortable, not too noisy place for a good, lingering conversation.
author: D Z.

description:
The halloumi was cold, and sliced so thinly one could see through it.
The Warek Enab aka dolmas, were ok, not as good as homemade, no spices to be tasted or seen, but the rice was cooked and the leaves were not mushy.
The arnabeet was cold and the fried cauliflower was old,  limp and mushy. Lacking flavor and texture.
The rahib ehhh we were NOT fond of this.. Had one bite each.
Batata Harra was reminiscent of Kate's Kitchens breakfast potatoes with hot sauce.
Our waiter was very nice, as was the rest of the staff. However, the food was sub-par. 
As for dessert, we took a pass given the meal, I did ask about the baklava, and no, they do not make it in house. Maybe that's a good thing???

I LOVE Lebanese food, but I will just make it at home I can bust out platters that blow doors on this.....
author: Nana W.

description: Wow! Just happened by one night looking for some mid eastern food and just happened to find this fantastic place! Everything was served fresh and the waitstaff was attentive and pleasant. I don't usually spend a lot of time in this neighborhood but this place definitely gives me a reason to come back around.
author: Mark S.

description:
Nicer ambiance than a typical falafel and sharwarma slinging joint with reasonable prices on the food and the wine.  Open a tad later than other Hayes Valley restaurants, though by no means a night owl haunt.  I appreciated them taking this cuisine up a notch on the fancy scale (since ordering a falafel doesn't have to mean sitting in a chair with duct tape), but the food was just ok.

Meat Pie: I was envisioning something more like a lahma bi ajeen where the meat is spread out open on a flat bread, but got some of those mini-empanada looking meat pies.  The minced meat was a bit dense and lacked any vibrant spices.  Was one of those things they probably warm up in a microwave so wasn't a fan.

Halloumi Cheese: I'm a sucker for halloumi.  Gotta respect a cheese that can take an intense grilling and not melt away.  Crispy outer edges and firm inner cheese.  A pita was served with this that appeared to be freshly baked, a very impressive offering since most places use those pitas from a bag that have the dry inside.  This one was moist and chewy and warm!

Lamb Shawarma: I hate when places use the word "shawarma" but really mean bits of meat griddled or pan fried.  Isn't a real shawarma supposed to be thinly shaved from a large spit where one side of the shaving is super crispy and the side, which wasn't exposed to the flame, super moist?  Also breaking from tradition was panini pressing the lavash bread so the sandwich is a sealed in one large rectangle which is then cut in half.  I kind of liked that since it gave a crunchy texture and added structural integrity to a wrap that often falls apart.  The fillings of hummus, cucumber salad and fried potatoes were quite nice leaving me only the lamb to complain about.

Chicken Shawarma: Same aspects as the lamb shawarma, but with chicken.  The chicken too was in bits and not real shawarma shavings.  Was decent.
author: Adam B.

description: Sooo good!  I didn't know what a treat I was in for...  I was just commenting to a friend about how much I was craving good Mediterranean and this little restaurant certainly hit the spot.  Everything we had was so fresh and delicious, from the labne, hummus, and tabouleh to their roasted eggplant and fresh feta and olives.  If you enjoy Mediterranean with a Lebanese tilt, this is a solid choice -- -great ambiance for a fun date night out.
author: Rosa D.

description: Good food with big portions , i was really surprised about how big the mezzah plates were
author: Samoha A.

description: The waitress seemed like she'd have to pay out of pocket if she smiled. She had to be kinda tricked into getting us a chair when it was easily available but she pretended it wasn't there. Speaking with her was really painful and a downer in an otherwise cozy-ish restaurant. The mujadara was luke warm possibly premade microwaved and dry. Very ordinary. Overpriced at $15 for a below average experience.
author: Nutcrackin C.

description: Mazzat is one of the best Mediterranean places I've been, with a huge variety of traditional dishes in addition to American favorites with a Middle Eastern flavor. My boyfriend and I got the mazzat platter, which allows you to choose three hot and three cold dishes that they combine in a large platter. It comes with fresh, toasted pita for a really complete meal. We went with the spicy hummus, roasted eggplant, and tabouli for cold dishes. All were obviously made with fresh ingredients and lots of amazing Mediterranean spices. The hot dishes were just as good, and I highly recommend the rice mixed with beef and lamb for something heartier. We also tried the chicken artichoke pizza, which was basically thick grilled pita with pesto, chicken, and artichoke. The pita made for a great crust, and the toppings were all of my favorite things on a pizza! The best part is when you finish a huge meal and don't feel an ounce of guilt because of the quality and care put into the dishes.
author: Ashley T.

description: Solid good food.  Loved the mezza appetizer spread with the fresh flat bread.  Really nice service and I loved the ambiance - casual, warm and intimate.
author: Maile N.

description:
Absolutely delicious food. We ordered the lentil soup, hummus, cucumber and tomato salad, the lamb wrap, and both the Kafta and Bamia stews with rice.
