Everything was delicious, right down to the rice, which is served on the side and which my kids and I couldn't stop eating just plain (what do they do to that rice?!). I would eat here every day if I could! 
Also, the place was packed on a weekday night, but the food arrived surprisingly quickly and the service was friendly and efficient.
author: Michelle B.

description:
A nice dining experience for fancy greek food in Hayes Valley. We decided to head inside because it looked like a cute ambiance and who doesn't love hummus?

We tried--
1. Fatet Batinjan which is fried eggplant with garlic yogurt sauce, croutons, and pine nuts: This was a very unique dish and nothing like I've tried before. The eggplant was softer than we expected but the yogurt sauce and the crispy croutons complimented it well. 
2. Hummus Harr- this was a winner. I was a little skeptical about just getting hummus with so many other enticing options on the menu, but trust me, this is something you don't want to miss. The hummus was the smoothest I had ever tasted (sorry Trader Joes) and also so flavorful--not bland, but very rich, slightly spicy and perfectly seasoned. Think I hate about 10 pieces of bread through the night to finish the hummus. 
3. Zataar Pita- total letdown. Basically a open faced pita with tomatoes and olive oil. Might have been more to the ingredients, but tasted like just that. Wish we had gotten something more flavorful instead. We had to douse this dish with hummus and ask for hot sauce to even finish it. 

Adorable ambiance. Cute, intimate and a nice place to have dinner. Food is only so-so overall though but I would say come for appetizers, a glass of wine, and a nice ambiance. 

Other tips:
+Only wine/beer here. No other hard alcohol and pretty limited selection in terms of their wine list. 
+Can be a wait because it's a pretty small place. 
+Not the best for big parties, more intimate and good for smaller groups.
author: Anu P.

description:
Enjoyed quite a feast here with some friends who knew the owner and the menu fairly well, so I our table was quickly filled with a smorgasbord of dishes.  Trying to give credit were credit is due, here is my best recollection of some favorites:

- Falafel
- Fatet Batinjan
- Labne
- Hummus
- Tabouli
- Mazzat House Pita
- Fatoush

We weren't familiar Lebanese dishes, but by branching out we ended up with a memorable dinner.
author: Kim K.

description:
I'm really disappointed in the quality of the food and preparation. My friend and I both got sick after eating here last night, all of our symptoms lining up with bad food. We ordered:

-Mosaka (OILY, grease all over the plate)
-Fatet Batinjan
-Warek Enab 
-Jebneh w Zaytoun (it's a pile of unripe tomatoes, jarred olives, cucumbers and cut up feta)

He also brought out a dessert - Knahfeh - and it was unpleasant. The "sweet cheese" was tough and dry, no taste.

Also, there's no kitchen. I saw that in one of the Yelp reviews before we went but gave them the benefit of the doubt. There's a convection oven (like the kinda at Starbucks where they warm your sandwich), a panini press, and a counter-top deep fryer. The latter making the entire restaurant AND YOU reek of rancid grease.

Service wise, the owner was our server and was pleasant. But when it came time to split the bill on two cards, he mixed up the amounts charging the wrong cards the wrong amounts. No big deal, my friend and I can work it out. Except when I got home and randomly checked my bank account, he had made BOTH charges to my card.

I was testing out the place as a possible birthday dinner spot; definitely not happening. It's unfortunate because the restaurant overall is really pretty and I wanted it to be so much better. It's just not tolerable in a high-quality food city like San Francisco.
author: Chanda G.

description: This restaurant is in my neighborhood, it's one of my favorite places to go for a snack, or dinner. The staff are exceptional and being from Greece, and having been raised on the Mediterranean diet I think the quality of the food is very good. Excellent value, it will forever be one of my Staples.
author: Leah R.

description: I love Mazzat! I find myself coming here several times a month. The food is fresh and flavorful and the Lebanese wine is fantastic as well.  Aside from the cozy laid back interior, the service is great!! Adel always makes sure our table is happy and satisfied.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I was so excited that there was a Lebanese place in my neighborhood!  I checked the menu and it had all my favorites.  Sounds great, right?  Unfortunately not. 

I ordered the mujadra and the fattoush salad.  I should have known better when I read the menu and saw that the fattoush salad was made with a pomegranate dressing.  Pomegranate?  Really?  Not very traditional.  The salad came out and it was ok, but not lebanese at all.  Where is the lemon?  Where are the olives?  Radishes aren't typical lebanese.

Then the mujadra came out and I was soooooo disappointed.  This is hands down my favorite lebanese dish.  Similar to Dahl at an Indian restaurant Mujadra is a staple that always changes yet always has certain distinctive flavors.  Well, let's say this one was extremely lacking.  

A great mujadra is about half lentils and bursting with flavor.  This one was 90% rice with a few lentils scattered in, and absolutely no flavor.  Completely bland.  So sad.  And it cost $10... for what amounted to a small side of rice.  

It's too bad, I really wanted to like this place as it is so close to my house.  I doubt I'll be back.  

Are the owners lebanese?  I can't imagine they eat this stuff themselves.
author: Evelyn N.

description: Do not go here. We ordered a bunch of apps and they were all awful. The green beans were legitimately out of a can. The only thing that was decent was the pita and you can't go wrong with pita bread straight out of a box. Don't be fooled by the other reviews or the misleading, charming interior. That is all.
author: Ellie S.

description:
Nice clean restaurant with modern lines, not a very big place at all.  Unsurprisingly, nearly empty at mid-afternoon on a sleepy Sunday.

Service was plenty fast and reasonably friendly - expected but welcomed as we were one of about two couples dining.

We were drawn in by an offer, and elected to try the Mazzat Platter - three cold and three hot dishes selected from their large assortment.  Particularly interesting were the Arnabeet - a tangy fried cauliflower dish, Eraydiss - not the greatest shrimp dish ever, but the eggplants were exceptional, and Mutabal - a very different, somewhat sweet eggplant spread.

They have some great Belgian and Belgian-style beer on tap ( four taps, no less, Chimay, a couple Ommegang products ) as well as bottles of a Lebanese lager I had not seen before, and some Lebanese wines of which only a white is available by the glass.  Their pours are generous.

Upon reflection, $36 seemed a bit much for the reasonably large platter that came complete with some wonderfully soft flatbread.  It was all very good, but a lot of money for what amounts to a light lunch of salads made from relatively inexpensive ingredients.  I'd be back armed with another special offer, but the price is a little hard to swallow without some sort of discount.
author: Albert H.

description:
I have driven by this,place so many times, always saying I need to check it out. Well, tonight a friend that has just moved to SF agreed to try it with me.  We decided to order a mix of small plates (mazzats) and settle on five hot options and one cold one. Really liked the hummus with beef, eggplant with shrimp, and the fried cheese (halummi?). Our waiter, Adel, was great. Recommend a nice Lebanese red wine to enjoy. Will certainly be back  

Only complaint, and a small one at that which I forgot about as I enjoyed the wine, was that it was a,bit warm for me in the restaurant.   The food and service certainly were great. Thank you Mazzat for a really enjoyable evening.
author: Reinold T.

description:
I've eaten here several times prior to Symphony or Opera. The $18/pp  tapas plate is a great deal. You get to choose 3 options from the hot tapas and 3 from the cold tapas. In particular, the hummus with beef and the stuffed grape leaves stood out in my mind.

It's probably the most affordable and healthiest option in Hayes Valley for pre-concert dining. Only catch is that they are not on OpenTable, so you actually have to email the manager for a reservation. They've always been able to accommodate us and have served us in plenty of time for concerts.
author: Robyn G.

description:
The food is good, and there are several vegetarian options. I particularly adore their hummus. It comes studded with whole chickpeas and sprinkled with paprika and parsley. I am also a fan of their fatet batinjan - a dish of grilled (not mushy!) eggplant in a yogurt sauce, topped with pine nuts and pita croutons. And I'm not even a fan of eggplant.  Also love their minty black tea. 
One star off because I think they're overpriced (i.e., $8 for about 3 thin little pieces of halloumi cheese on a bit of romaine) and I know they raised their prices at least once in the past year.
author: Joyti J.

description: Upon sitting at the bar, I couldn't help but notice how much of the food is microwaved at this establishment. That was a disappointing indeed. I still really love that cheese. Affordable bottles of wine are a a plus here.
author: Mark S.

description:
Mazzat accomodated our big group of 14 wonderfully!
We ordered EVERYTHING that was on the menu and loved every single dish. Food tasted delicious, portions were great, and service was friendly....
Can't wait to return to this awesome little place....
author: Bhavnak K.

description: Not sure why it took me so long to finish this review but I'm glad I was reminded about this place so I can eat there again.  Everything was great except for the heavy-handed fake smoke taste in one of the eggplant dishes.  Looking forward to eating here again.
author: Jay S.

description:
I wish I could give Mazzat a higher review, but I was severely disappointed by my dining experience here.  Although service was excellent, the two entrees were terrible.

The meal started out promising. We had the Grilled Halloumi salad and it was delicious. But again, it's pretty hard to mess up Halloumi. It's always delicious. Then, everything was downhill from there.  

I was shocked when I received my entree and received 3 small pieces of Kafte. 3 measly pieces of Kafte for $18?! I thought that maybe they were small, but they were going to be amazing? I was also wrong. I love Kafte, and I order it whenever I see it on a menu. This was the worst Kafte I've had in recent memory: tough and chewy. The sweet tomato sauce and rice did nothing to salvage the dish for me.

Just when I thought the meal could not get any worse, I tried my boyfriend's Chicken Schwarma. I bit into the wrap and immediately thought, "That's weird. It's lukewarm and the meat tastes chalky." I had never tasted a schwarma like it and trust me, that's not a good thing. I kinda gagged, the texture of the meat and fillings were that bad. My boyfriend likened it to what he thought cat food might taste like. My boyfriend forced himself to finish it only because it was so expensive.

Even now, we feel cheated knowing we paid about $50 for such a disappointing meal. The only reason I'm not giving it 1 star is because the Grilled Haloumi salad was very good.
author: Monelle A.

description:
The other positive reviews speak the truth. We ordered the family-style, $18/person deal. We chose all vegetarian options (dalmas, those spinach pastry things, cous-cous, green beans, cheese/olive/tomato plate, and that eggplant/mint yogurt/onion thing) and they all exceeded expectations in terms of wonderfully balanced flavors.

Ain't got time to add something witty to this one, just eat there if you're feeling rich. I'm only going to give 4 stars though because it *is* pretty damn pricey.
author: Kim L.

description: We have visited this restaurant 3 times . Each time was excellent quality, served elegantly and just the right amount of food. Service friendly and kind. We are vegetarian so always get the Baba ganouq, dolmas, eggplant dishes and yogurt salad. Fresh Pita on demand. Highly recommended.
author: Mata K.

description: Got this reservation thru open table. For my 40th. A friend in Georgia called the restaurant before I got there and paid for a bottle of wine. The food was perfect. We tried 6 different dishes; hummus plate, ouzi, shankaleesh, and the vegetarian specials of the day. Staff was very accommodating, food came out quickly, this was such a treasure. I recommend reservations. Reasonably priced, reasonable portions, really- no complaints.
author: Mollie S.

description: Came here for dinner before a show at Rickshaw; fairly convenient, being only about 3 blocks away. I don't know much about Lebanese food and our server was very helpful in explaining some of the menu items. I really enjoyed the hummus with beef, and the pita was so toothsome. Since this was my entree, I liked that the ground beef made the hummus more substantial, and it was seasoned well. I also had the tabouli, something I've never had before, and it wasn't what I thought. I expected more of the bulgur wheat, but I learned that the dish emphasizes the veggies that go in it. It was a very lemony, light and healthy. I had a few bites of the bf's kafta and that was delicious! Loved the complexity in the tomato sauce, and it tasted especially good sopped up with pita. I also had a glass of the "classic red" Lebanese wine, which came out in a massive globular glass and was definitely more than a standard glass (I'm not complaining about that!).
author: Rita L.

description: Food was mediocre compared to Old Jerusalem, La Zeez, Palmyra or several other Mediterranean options and surprisingly expensive. Service was OK. Would not return.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Wow I am so amazed this place gets high reviews on yelp... I'm realizing I can't trust it so much. And I'm starting to feel like SF is so overcrowded that people are just grateful to be able to get into a restaurant in a nice neighborhood since the actual good ones are booked out 3 months in advance. I came here with my girlfriend and my parents who are visiting from DC. We went before going to the ballet. I wanted to go to Suppenkuche but they don't take reservations for less than 6 and my parents were worried about getting to the ballet on time so they suggested Mazzat because we could get a reservation, plus they really like Middle Eastern food - I like it too plus I often pass this place driving home up Fell and wonder why I haven't tried it.

Well it's not very good. The cauliflower is decent. There was a cauliflower main dish that I got and small plate that Mom got - both were ok but not super special. The spicy potatoes were like home fries at a diner - ok but not spicy until I asked for some hot sauce. Should have added some ketchup too. Eggplant was cold and slimy. Chicken shwerma was unmemorable. Fattoush salad was unflavored lettuce. Haloumi cheese was ok cause how bad can cheese be, but worst version I've had - tough texture. Cucumber salad was uninspired. Greenbeans were disgusting mush that we sent back. 

Also my girlfriend has super sensitive tastebuds and she tasted chlorine in the potatoes and cucumber salad. 

Also the cooks were not middle eastern. They were speaking Spanish. 

Had a decent bottle of Sauvignon Blanc from Portugal - that was the best part.
author: Jesse K.

description:
Lebanese guy here, grew up eating Lebanese food, lived in the Middle East, and have eaten at countless Lebanese restaurants, including in Beirut.  I was super-excited to come here and taste the food as I've been looking for good Lebanese food in the area.  Unfortunately, the food fell far short and is arguably inauthentic.  

The Loubieh Bil Zeit (green beans with tomato and garlic sauce) felt like the green beans were frozen and microwaved - they're supposed to be stewed in an olive oil confit with tomato and garlic sauce, instead they just sprinkled some tomatoes on top.  The Tabouleh used curly (Chinese?) parsley - the parsley is the key ingredient and using curly parsley changes the texture/dish completely. The Hummus with Meat used ground beef, instead of chopped lamb as the meat, and the hummus itself was over-garliced and lacked the appropriate seasoning.  The Kefta meat was overcooked and dried out.  And the Halloumeh is supposed to be grilled, I have no idea what they did to it but it didn't taste right.  The ful was actually ok.  At least the service was decent enough, so I'll add a star for that.

I could have a really high bar given my background, so other people may enjoy the food - but authentic Lebanese food is so much better than this.  I've found the food at Arabian Nights in the mission to be much closer to authentic (though still not as good as the real thing)
author: Nadim H.

description: First time at a Lebanese restaurant. Glad we tried it. Decent wine by the glass and big pours. Absolutely loved the Lebanese pizza with chicken, tomato, artichokes,spinach and feta. Friendly smiling staff. Dinner for two with one glass of wine was under $35.
author: Joe M.

description:
yum yum yum!  Went here last night with some friends and it was D-lish.  Here is what we had.

Halloumi Cheese -- squeaky cheese is always yummy...

Mosaka -- Very tasty.  

Eraydiss -- The shrimp and sauce went really well together.  Kind of a bummer to share because having only one shrimp wasn't enough.  Perhaps better to have to yourself

Meat pie -- not really worth it.  There is not enough meat in comparison to pie.  Tasty but there certainly are other items that are much better.  Perhaps if they put more meat I would change my feelings on it.

Labne -- OMG I LOVED THIS STUFF.  Seriously, I was probably hogging most of it but whatever!  I could have ordered just this and been one happy camper.  I total must.  It is like yogurt and sour cream and cheese had a baby together. Seriously tasty...

Kafta --  Good but again not really great to share.  I know I am a meat lover and to be honest I would have liked more Kafta and less sauce in this dish.  Tasty all the same however just a little disappointing on the proportions.

Falafal -- Won't order this again.  It was too dry for my liking...

All in all I had a really great time and will totally come back to try more.  Really inexpensive for such a tasty experience.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Great spot one block off the busy Hayes Street. An excellent menu, everything we tried was great. 
The first time I came here I had one of there wraps, which was huge and very tasty.
The second time, just a few days ago, we sat outside and ordered a few appetizers and a glass of wine. 

We had:
- Babaghanough 
- Labne 
- Sfeeha 

Everything was great, very fresh, made to order. And they were happy to bring out as much pita bread as we wanted .
author: Carlynn A.

description: I am lebanese and I know its hard to find good middle eastern food besides my mom's cooking.  This place is definitely one of the better middle eastern places I've tried.  Very delicious and the staff is very nice.  Loved it!
author: Juliana K.

description: We've been to Mazzat a couple of times now and food is really really good! The best is to share some small dishes and try not to eat too much ;)
author: Vincent V.

description: This was my first time having Lebanese food. For appetizers my family and I shared the Fatet Batinjan, Ouzi and Tabouli (we added feta to it). They were all three delicious. Then we shared the Kabsseh for dinner and the chicken was so tender and flavorful. Will definitely dine again!
author: Megan B.

description: It is all about the sampler plate! We had the sampler for 2 (which is the min amount of people you can have to order this, house rules). In it we had the freshest, richest tasting hummus dish I'd ever had, two distinctly different tasting eggplant dishes that were both simply delicious and a simple and light garbanzo bean dish with a lemony glaze which really rounded it all out. Fantastic, perfect experience. You won't be disappointed if you're looking for impressive flavors in a relaxed and elegant atmosphere. Perfect rating. I loved it.
author: Curtis M.

description: They don't make the food in this restaurant so that it's fresh. They use ready-made food and just warm it up, so it's overcooked. The hummus had so many additives our immune system reacted. The chicken on the pizza-pita was so stale it had the flavor of mold. The Arabic salad was so minuscule in size  -- perhaps because we came around 5 pm and they were saving the ingredients for more people who come to eat around 7 pm. Though at least the vegetables were cut while we were there. For sure - the worst Arabic restaurant in the Bay Area. The next night we went to Old Jerusalem - much cheaper, and by far, the best Arabic restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Ayala K.

description:
Having spent a lot of time in the Middle East, my expectations for the food are pretty high when I am in the US. It is all about freshness and American restaurants aren't known for that... This restaurant met my low expectations.

1. the bread was wonder-bread-tasting-store-bought pita bread (NOTHING) like the real thing. No restaurant in the Middle East would survive if they served that.

2. I tasted the boullion in the rice that came with the chicken dish, and the rice was otherwise completely bland

3. the kibbeh was so hot in the middle and a little soggy on the outside (obviously microwaved

4. the hummus did not taste fresh at all. I ate the same exact tasting hummus at Holy Land restaurant in Oakland--it is just a weird tasting (I think they mix it with mayo or yogurt) and not fresh. They must buy it from the same place. Also, real homemade hummus should taste different at each place.

5. the bamiah (okra) was so oily my friend couldn't eat it. Also the taste was underwhelming. It just tasted like the canned tomatoes it was cooked in, with no other spices or falvors

6. the fuul (fava beans) were ok, but underwhelming

The positives: the chicken itself was cooked well and the halloumi cheese was good.
author: Mini A.

description:
I came here for the first time here and was definitely impressed.  Service was good (we got seated right away) and the food was delicious. 

We ordered:

Arnabeet (sauteed cauilflower topped with garlic lemon juice)- SOOO amazing we had to get a 2nd order after we devoured our first!!! My favorite dish by far!

Fatet betinjan (grilled eggplant topped with yogurt, pita croutons and pine nuts)- The waitress said this was one of their most popular dishes. It had a slight pumpkin taste and the yogurt and crunchy pita croutons balanced it out well.

Labne (lebanese kefir cheese with olive oil and thyme)- More of a dipping sauce with the complimentary pita they serve. The cheese was really thick and creamy with a subtle taste to it.

Fatoush salad- I've had a better salad at a different Lebanese restaurant I went to in LA, but its a nice, light dish to compliment the others.

Mazzat is a solid choice for any occasion and I'm sure I'll be making my way back here soon.
author: Kelley H.

description: This is a great spot. We ordered four apps. We all agreed the best was the beef hummus. Super creamy. Fun busy atmosphere with great middle eastern tunes. The pita was remarkable. Didn't love the foul.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Had some hit and miss dishes here, overall was solid. 

Pluses: nicely decorated, atmospheric. great prices on wine. good value. The hit dishes: eraydiss (eggplant and shrimp dish) was delicious, good flatbread, good feta cheese, not a fan of the bamla dish.
author: Christy D.

description:
After an AMAZING massage down the street at EarthBody (check them out too!), the boyfriend and I decided to grab a bite at Mazzat.  I had read the reviews on Yelp and thought we'd give it a shot.  

Bottom liine: We loved it.

~ Atmosphere ~
I can't get enough of Mediterranean cuisine, so I knew I'd be judgy.  So far, so good.  Atmosphere is lovely - definitely date-worthy.  Candles, dim lighting, dark cherry wood tables.  We grabbed an elevated table by the window, but we were the only ones there so we could've picked anywhere.  I wondered what the empty room meant about the restaurant, but sure enough, the place filled in 10 minutes after we sat down (we got there around 7:15PM).  

~ Food ~
Soooo yummy.  We didn't have to wait long, either.  It was our first time at Mazzat, so we weren't positive what to order, and there was a nice selection of hot and cold mazzat, meats, wraps, salads, soups, wine, etc.  Our friendly and attentive waitress pointed out the dine-in-only special - a platter of 3 cold mazzat and 3 hot mazzat, plus all the warm pita bread we could eat.  YUM. We ate that shit up.  Aaaand we still had leftovers. Personally, our favorites were the tabouli, hummus, labne, and mujadara with cucumber yogurt sauce.  We also had the mini meat pies and eraydiss (also very tasty).  Didn't order wine, so can't say anything about that, but everyone around us had a glass or two.

~ Service ~
Our waitress/hostess was very welcoming and attentive throughout our meal.  Unfortunately, we didn't catch her name, but she got a nice tip!  I think she's the main waitress.  (Hopefully we won't run into that credit card overcharge issue another Yelper mentioned.  I doubt it.)    

Overall, great place. Quality food. Romantic atmosphere. Attentive service.
author: Karina C.

description:
tl;dr: They microwave the kebbeh and falafel. :(

We had:
- Kebbeh
- Falafel
- Hummus
- Labne

The Good:
- Everything was well seasoned and tasty
- The pita was excellent and plentiful
- They used good quality olive oil with the hummus and labne

The Bad:
- The kebbeh and falafel were microwaved!
- The kebbeh disintegrated with little provocation
- The falafel were soggy and spongy

We had arrived a little after 9pm, so I asked the waiter whether, had we arrived earlier, the kebbeh and falafel could have been made to order. He advised that they're prepared before dinner and microwaved before serving.

This restaurant apparently has a low opinion of their customers.

The Verdict:
- We won't be back
author: Geoff S.

description: okay. i'm easily pleased and easily convinced. All it took was acknowledgement of a mistake, a will to correct it and rating go back up accordingly.
author: Tu L.

description:
One star to let the people know that this is not 4 star yelp worthy.  

We ordered a pita pizza, a wrap and the spinach in filo dough appetizer and all of the above were dry, unseasoned and absolutely lacked a wow factor. 

Honestly, the place was just okay... nothing worth talking about or making an effort for.  Service was okay, the waitress messed up our order and then tried to pin it on us... however in the end they gave us what we wanted.

The chicken was weird... some pieces overcooked and some still raw in the middle.  My solution was just to eat around the meat. My boyfriend ate the overcooked pieces.
author: Homechicken P.

description:
FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, DO NOT EAT HERE.

I got terrible food poisoning from the kafta. Spent some quality time with the toilet for the next two days.

We went around 7pm on a Thursday night. There was only my party of four and one couple in the restaurant. The man that I presume to be the owner took our order. I should add that he was pretty drunk, going as far to tell us that the wine was good and that he's been drinking it all night. 

We ordered three appetizers and four entrees. Ten minutes after ordering, we received our entrees. Ok......where are our appetizers? We told him we never got our apps and he looked at us with a blank stare. He opened up his notepad to check the order, and I noticed he never even wrote them down. He apologized and put in our app orders. Doesn't do us much good since our food had already come, suspiciously fast might I add.

I ordered the kafta and was disappointed to see that I got three measly meatballs and a heap of rice for $18. The kafta was decent, nothing to write home about. The apps were actually pretty good. We ordered hummus, dolmas, and a rice with lamb in it (forgot the name).  

I woke up around 4am the next morning with terrible stomach pains. I spent the next few hours puking uncontrollably. After puking up all my food, the stomach acid came next. I thought the worst had passed. NOPE. Next came the endless waves of diarrhea. I'll save you the rest of the details but suffice it to say I was out of commission for the next two days, pretty much following the same routine of puking and diarrhea. I couldn't keep anything down. 

Overall, I was really disappointed with my experience here. I am afraid to eat meatballs from anywhere now. So thanks for that, Mazzat.
author: Bob C.

description:
Went for dinner last night and had a great time with good food.  We opted for 3 starters, Fatet Batinjan- was the best of the bunch, fried eggplant with crispy pita croutons, could just had that and been satisfied.  We also had a "pizza" which was pita topped with chicken & artichoke.  I found it to be great, others at the table just thought it was good.  We also had the halloumi salad, which was decent and huge.  But maybe the star of the night was the main Bamia a lamb and tomato stew with okra, while light on the lamb, the flavor of the dish was deep a total win.  The only down side was they only had one of the three dessert options.  

We will be back.
author: Mickey D.

description:
The food at mezzat is actually really really good...but the service is not so good. First off, I booked a table from opentable.com and my friend with me didn't realize and called in to make a reservation for 15 minutes after my opentable.com reservation. When we got there, the staff acted so confused, we told them to cancel the phone reservation and use the opentable.com reservation, they said "why? so you can get your points." I thought it was very rude and unprofessional, but yes...that is the reason, why not? Then it turns out, they did exactly that, they cancelled the opentable.com account so I didn't get my points. That started us off to a bad start....then we order our food and the check comes and they won't/can't split the check or use more than 2 credit cards...okay, fine, so one of us didn't end up paying and we split it by 3 credit cards...no biggie. One of my friends at the table had been to Mazzat before and said "make sure to save your receipt because they are kind of shady and ended up charging my credit card 3 times in the past." Sure enough everyone at the table was charged double for the meal and our credit cards were all charged twice...
these people are kind of shady, the food is good but just be careful and keep your receipts so you can show your bank.
author: Karley A.

description:
Mazzat has a local neighborhood feel although we went before the Symphony and there was a couple next to us similarly dressed.  I initially thought it was a little noisy, but it turned out fine.  It's noisy enough that you don't have the feeling people are eavesdropping but not so noisy that you get fatigued or can't converse easily.

We made reservations and they treated us with respect.  We waited maybe 5 min for a nicer table but they sat us at the bar very nicely.

Food was very good.  We got the platter where you choose three hot and three cold dishes.  You get good pita bread cut into nicely sized fourths.  I'm no Lebanese food expert but I've had all the dishes at one time or other.  i thought the food was "nuanced" in that the flavors were interesting, sometimes sharp, but not so strong that you get overwhelmed before you finish.

Had Fatoush salad:  nice tangy dressing that didn't overwhelm this Mediterranean salad.  Six dishes were:
o  Mosaka eggplant (yum)
o  Mujadara (very yum)
o  Halloumi Cheese (ok, but would try something different next time)

o  Hummus (nice flavor)
o  Tabouli (wife likes it, but i don't go for vast quantities of parsley)
o  Shankaleesh (surprisingly long lasting tang to the flavor; very interesting).

Service was good.  They seemed generally interested in helping our selection without talking down or offering info without a viewpoint (aka, "they're all good").
author: Darrel S.

description:
Tasty!

I've tried a fair number of well rated places on Yelp for this kind of cuisine and this is my favorite place for hummus and baba ghanouj so far! 

Go for the appetizers here.  

Casual ambiance.  If you're looking for a romantic night out, this isn't really the place but it's a good place to gab with a few friends.  
Never too crowded. 
Easy reservations. 
Service is fine but nothing to write home about. 
The entree portions are big. 

Yays: 

1. Hummus and Hummus har: not too acidic/ lemony. Great flavor. 
2. baba ghanouj: so tasty, please get this. 
3. Finally, pita that is decent pita. 
4. Fatet Batinjan: eggplant with croutons : this was good but very heavy. I know everyone says this is the dish to get but to be honest, I was happier with the Hummus har and Baba ghanouj. 
5. Kabsseh: very tender chicken - if you're feeling like an entree - we liked this better than the kafta.

Pass 
Pizzas: very average, no big flavors, toppings are .... just pick something else.
author: S C.

description: Everything we ordered was flavorful. Chicken was support moist and juicy, potatoes ware spicy and crisp, moussaka was great as well.
author: Angry B.

description:
Lebanese food, great lebanese food. It's extremely hard to find kibbeh and sfihas anywhere in Northern California. Mazzat has them in spades! 

The meat pies (that I, and Syrians, Lebanese, Brazilians, call sfiha) are to die for! I like them so much that I've been to Mazzat three times and I am yet to order an entree! I could live solely on the starters they serve there!
author: Gatola I.

description: Very awkward space, but food is tasty, and menu is fun.
author: Michael E.

description:
What a great find in Hayes Valley!

Food = 4.5.  Great mediterranean food.  Our group of four had an assortment of hot and cold small dishes.  I also had as my entree a falafel wrap.  OMG, good stuff!  I also recommend the Lebanese beer!!!

Service = 4.5.  Our server gave us her personal choices on hot and cold dishes in order to create the perfect, balanced combination.  She was super helpful, attentive and fun.  I was half-way joking at dinner when I said, "See you tomorrow for lunch!"

Atmosphere = 4.0.  This place is small with just a row of tables along the wall.  The restaurant is clean and open without any design bells and whistles.  Nothing fancy but very cozy.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Mazzat is amazing! The quality of the ingredients coupled with an abundant variety of great dishes is what keeps us coming back. They recently updated the menu, and the new additions are just unbelievably good. Our guest tried a new chicken dish served on a bed of fragrant rice that made all of us jealous. 

I highly recommend trying the Mazzat Platter (choose a total of six items from the appetizer selections). It's great for groups and can easily accommodate vegan, vegetarian, etc. preferences and will definitely satisfy any appetite. At first I worried it's not enough food, but we always leave completely stuffed.

Also, I have dreams about their hummus, it's the best in the City!
author: Christine B.

description: Great hummus, but the rest of the dishes were just OK.  We only ate the meatless options, though. Perhaps the meat dishes are better.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I would say, dinner is probably more exciting at this little place than was lunch. I won't take points off for the tacky soundtrack - Buddha Bar AND Enigma? C'mon now, guys! But I will take a few off for the insubstantial, and slightly underseasoned, plates of appetizers.

Halloumi cheese - great in and of itself, 'cuz it's so clever, that little cheese, the delicious way it grills and yet retains its salt and shape and texture. But simply putting it on a bed of lettuce is, well, just a little unimaginative. 
Hummus, not bad. Needed more olive oil and a dash more paprika. But I'm a snob, and have made my own for years, so. Slight bias.
The kebeh was very nice, but again, one spice too few. Make it kick! Add diced parsley. Something!

Wonderful service and clean, sharp decor. And their dinner menu looked packed with classics, so I'll be back one of these evenings to indulge. 

I'd say, however, look elsewhere for lunch, unless you're standing, well, right in front of the door.
author: Eva L.

description: I went in one night and it seemed a little busy so I cozied up to the chefs counter. The waitress was with another customer which was not a problem because the chef behind the counter was very attentive. Overall the service was outstanding, the waitress and chef were very helpful. The only downside is the next time I went in I heard that waitress is no longer there and the service seemed to lack. The food is amazing though.
author: Maria F.

description: We tried the grilled Lebanese cheese-was fresh and salty good white cheese. The yogurt cauliflower dish was tasty but mine came with lamb when I didn't want the lamb version. The lebne was fresh and delicious but I could eat Labne every day! Hummus was fresh and great too. Plenty of pita. I like this place. Service was fair (was very friendly but seemed inexperienced in many ways) but I'll give it another shot some day when I'm visiting my BFFs in Hayes Valley.
author: Piper W.

description:
Is everything supposed to taste sour? Maybe it was just the dishes I ordered, but I kept tasting sour notes in everything I was eating. Especially from the meat pies. For me, these are two things that should just not go together. Sour. Meat. 

I don't know. I'm seriously perplexed by this one...
author: Ray W.

description: This place has amazing food, so much flavor! The owners are very friendly and explained the menu in detail.  The atmosphere is right on point, good spot to just chill and enjoy yourself.  I am glad I live a few blocks from the place! I would highly recommend it for people looking for authentic Lebanese food!
author: David K.

description:
I consider this one of my go-to recommendations for just about anyone.

The FOOD: My favorite is the mezze platter. With this you get to taste 6 delicious flavors of your choice for $30 and it is definitely enough to feed 2 hungry people. My favorites are the hummus with meat, the labne, the tabouli, and the haloumi. And having tasted a lot of Lebanese food I find that they are providing top-notch flavors. They also have delicious pizzas and Lebanese beer.

The SERVICE: It varies ranging from - just OK to excellent. Everyone is always polite, but Ive found that the female servers are exceptionally attentive and cheerful. They just add that something extra.

The ATMOSPHERE: The restaurant is quite small seating no more than 25 people. Bringing a group larger than 8 may prove difficult if not planned in advance. Its a nice looking restaurant. It does however, have a large display counter that makes it seem more like a take-out spot but you quickly forget about it.

The PRICES: It think they are quite reasonable. I recently fed 6 people there for dinner (without alcohol) for $80 and had leftovers. I also hear they have a happy hour but I have not experienced it myself.

The CONS: Not much. I've tried most of it and the only thing I didn't care for was their spankopita.
author: T S.

description:
So delish, but a bit on the pricey side. Only your tongue can decide if this insanely flavorful Lebanese cuisine is worth your hard-earned cash. 

Food: To do this properly it is essential that you dine with a horde of your closest friends. The dishes are on the small side so you need to order enough so that everyone can sample each masterpiece without hostility. We feasted on the Mazzat platter ($15 per person) which allows you to choose three hot dishes and three cold. Our hot selections included the mosaka (marinated grilled eggplants in roasted garlic tomato sauce, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=AkbSQmqdBXRP1jA7ln-Hdw), chicken artichoke pita pizza (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=su8VFCK80OPm6oSIIpPeqQ), and falafel (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=ues3QYOg2I0Mq7LMYzY5WQ), while our cold included labne (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=KAcOzd8ywuAjJx5NIrfkcA), eggplant pomegranate (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=fRUCbvbaQPJ4r1CfgqncvQ), and hummus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=qk5LQZqo_rClaIJUUsuSag). We also had a side of pita bread (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=1F2nUJzVeNnq_w8M8KmatA). Especially pleasing were both dishes with eggplant and the pizza. The falafel were also good, but there were only four to go around which was a bit disappointing. I really ate myself sick here. Everything was just that good! I do wish they had given us a little more food though. We took a bit home, but not much. 

Atmosphere: Gorgeous. I was almost scared away by how beautiful the restaurant itself was. A meal at such a refined, modern establishment must cost a fortune, right? The interior is decorated with pretty strings of lights (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lxb2mz0Yay7y8HSmvJ7dmA?select=jFq3xeruBUcCsPd2K_e94w), a fountain, and plenty of dark accents. Love it. 

Service: They're a bit slow here, but not to the point of irritation. The owner gave us some details on how he started the restaurant and his background. This place is 100% authentic as certified by our Lebanese friend. 

Synopsis: Yurm. Come hungry.
author: Toni L.

description:
Hands down, this was the best kabsa I've had in a restaurant outside of the Middle East! Their mezzat (appetizers) are also good, and they had great service.

The place is really cute but I wouldn't recommend it for larger parties simply because of its size.
author: Suzan E.

description:
Romantic atmosphere and the largest glass of red wine I have every enjoyed.

We shared a Mazzat Platter and it was just enough for two people.  Mazzat offers lots of choices for Lebanese and Mediterranean fare and everything is well-prepared.  I have tasted better but the nice environment makes up for the average food.
author: Chad S.

description:
I'd give it a 3.5 if that were an option.

My boyfriend and I split the Mazzat platter. Everything was good, but some dishes had a bit too much olive oil on them. The grilled cheese offered was a bit disappointing.

My biggest gripe was the service. Different people seemed to be serving us at different times. The gentleman that sat us was the one that took our food and drink order, but he didn't come back to check in on us, so while we wanted a second round of drinks no one was there to notice.  Service was fast, but there was nothing personable about it.

Also, a small and admittedly kind of silly thing to complain about-- they use really tiny thin paper napkins reminiscent of ones used in fast food joints.
author: KA K.

description:
Delicious food! I just came from a trip to the Middle East; these guys are the real deal. Combine the food with the attentive and personalized service and you have yourself a keeper. I have a feeling I'll be frequenting here often :).

If you are in a group, get the Mazzat platter. You get to combine 6 different dishes for $15/person; lets you try lots of options, doesn't break the bank, and will leave you absolutely stuffed. Also make sure to try the Lebanese wine.
author: Dan F.

description:
Came here with my friend for dinner, avoiding the crowds, and loved it!
We got the platter option, and were both totally enamored with the lentil rice; who'd have thunk that would be amazing?  Spanakopita were yummy, as were the dolmas and baklava.  Our other big favorite was a chicken flatbread pizza; the chicken was great, the cheese delicious and the hot sauce a wonderful flavor. Don't mistake the hot sauce for a mild marinara, like I did on first bite; it kicks!

Service was totally excellent, as Adam the owner kept our wine glasses full and showed off his new upstairs lounge, opening soon!
author: Amber S.

description:
I love this place! 
Since i live around the corner, I am very happy that a casual restaurant/cafe with excellent food and wine has opened up. I returned from a trip to florida recently where they don't really serve vegetables and i asked the waiter at Mazzat to throw something together vegetarian and he said yes i can do something. I asked him to also bring me a glass of something red. He came back with an assortment of the best of everything. The grape leaves, the baba ganoush, the hummus, the eggplant, the cucumber salad, the falafel... everything was perfect and the the wine was a pinot which i don't even like but it was excellent too and only $5 a glass. The spinach salad with grilled halloumi cheese was fantastic. I go now for breakfast too which is just as good. The salmon fritata and the Good Morning Lebanon are very good.
Just try it!
author: john b.

description:
As someone who has recently started working the corners of Hayes Valley, I know what it's like to embark on a new business. 

Things you have to think about:
-Location, location, hoe-cation!
-Clientele: who I should be marketing myself to & what do THEY want out of my experience
-Easy access in and out
-Best ways for customers to pay for my goods

Let's focus on that last bullet point. I stepped foot in Mazzat on a rainy Sunday in December with a friend, just a few weeks after they opened. We came for the coffee but stayed for the syrah. We ordered our drinks, set up our laptops, drank our wine, worked and talked for an hour, and left. 

Can you spot what was missing from that sequence of events?

WE FORGOT TO PAY. 

It didn't even hit me that we forgot until I was at work on Monday afternoon. So instead of going home after work, I got off at the Van Ness station and walked quickly to Mazzat (you know, as if those extra 5 minutes would make a huge difference in them forgiving me). 

I came in and explained what happened and asked if I could pay for the wine. The guy said he realized he never asked us to pay until after we left and was really appreciative that I came back (being a new business, and all). 

PHEWWWW.

Aside from the free drinks, the atmosphere is great. About 10 tables with benches and chairs, soft and cozy lighting, and an array of coffees, wines and Mediterranean cuisines.

As a fellow business person, I appreciate them understanding my plight. Just like I understand how you haven't paid me for my services yet. 

But don't worry, I'll wait. 

Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock. 

(Buzzzzzzzzzzzzzz)
author: Jared S.

description: Really fast service, even on a crowded Friday night.  I was surprised by how good the mujadara was.  I am probably misspelling it but its the rice with lentils and caramelized onion.  I have never had such creamy well textured rice.  I am gluten free so it was a great way to be able to enjoy all the dips and sauces.  Somehow I forgot to try their Lebanese coffee with cardamon but I will not make that mistake again!
author: Emily O.

description:
Absolutely delicious.  Lebanese cardamom coffee ("turkish" on the sign board) is incredible, and lovely atmosphere, especially on a rainy day!  Strongly recommend the the mazza platter and be sure to include the couscous and the moussaka.  Very classy in a casual way.  

The restaurant is brand new, adapting space used previously for a grocery store that had a very good lebanese deli to a full-blown lebanese restaurant.  The seating is a bit awkward, especially the high-top seats, but I suspect this will be a temporary problem.

Strongly recommend you try!
author: Jaime R.

description:
Oh, Mazzat!  I wanted to like you...I really did.  I liked your decor and had great hopes, but service was lacking, food disappointing, and pricing a bit stiff for the amount of food.

The bright spot in the meal were the yummy pita and dolma.

But, the salad was dull and the other dishes (fava beans, lentil rice, & eggplant spread) just ok.  Perhaps we just picked poorly.

Lo, the final straw came when the waiter was too busy chatting up a girl to clear our table or bring our check.  Sigh.  Adieu, Mazzat.
author: Tracy R.

description: This is a solid place for middle eastern food. I agree with everyone else that you should get the large sampler of food.
author: Shang S.

description:
Hidden gem. I love hidden gems.

It seems the world hasn't discovered Mazzat yet, which is just fine by me. It's a great little intimate spot in Hayes Valley with excellent food. We went on a Friday night around 8, were seated immediately and ordered glasses of wine - wine and food prices are reasonable.

We then treated our dinner like tapas and sampled lots of dishes from the menu. One of our favorites was the lentil dish served with yogurt. We also loved the falafel and the salad was outstanding.

Service was very friendly, although at times the waiter seemed very confused. Maybe he's just new. In any case, they took care of us and we felt very welcome. We'll be back!
author: Gretchen S.

description: This Lebanese restaurant appears to be family owned. I really appreciated the quaint environment and friendly service. The food was so flavorful and the dessert was fresh out of the oven when we ordered it.
author: Ashley B.

description: Food and service are certainly four star but the wine list is seriously tragic.  All the 'wines' by the glass are thin, acidic and nearly undrinkable.  The first time I dined there they had one California wine by the glass that actually tasted like grapes were an ingredient but the second time it was all European 'wines' that I don't think I would use for cooking.  I understand you can buy these no-name European wines for super cheap and you are making a killing on the wines by the glass but please, PLEASE, at least provide one alternative that is a good glass of wine even if you have to charge a lot more for it.  Let me decide if I want cheap wine or good wine.
author: Stan B.

description:
I came here for the first time over the weekend.  It's a cute little place and very friendly staff and owner, which is always very much appreciated.  Plus I had excellent Lebanese wine that I really enjoyed.

However, the two stars are for the food.  Sigh.  Maybe I just had too high-expectations (considering I grew up on this food).  While the presentation of the food was great, it lacked in freshness and flavor.  It was very obvious in the Falafel.  Falafel is supposed to be cooked upon order and served crispy on the outside, and moist on the inside.  Their falafel had very obviously been sitting for a while or reheated...it was just chewy and dry.

I also had the mujadara, dolma, lebne, couscous salad, meat pie.  All were also just okay and did not compel me enough to want to go back.  Sorry....I just didn't get that "yummmm" feeling while eating the food here.   There aren't that many great middle eastern cuisine spots in the city, so I think if this place took it up a notch they would be super successful !
author: S G.

description: Great place to go with friends and share small plates. We had the chicken/artichoke/feta pizza, the hummus, the fried cauliflower and lamb meatballs. The pizza was by far the table favorite: generous portions of toppings with clean, distinct tastes of super ingredients. The hummus was also popular. It sounds simple but the few ingredients were balanced perfectly and the grilled flatbread was awesome. We used our leftover bread to dip in the meatball sauce. Nice relaxed but attentive service, casual atmosphere. I will definitely go back!
author: Greg J.

description: I love this place.  Nice ambiance, friendly service and great food!  I like to get the mezze platter.  You get to choose 3 cold dishes and 3 hot dishes.  My personal favorites are all of their eggplant dishes, hummus with beef, and labne.  Their dishes are heavy on the  garlic, but I personally don't mind too much because everything else is perfect!
author: Gran A.

description: A group of 4 of us tried this place for the first time last night. It was delicious. They had a great menu for groups where you order 6 item to share. It was perfect. I can't wait to go back.
author: Terese P.

description: The hummus is so good I had to write a yelp review. It is thick, It is creamy, and it is the best thing you will ever eat. It was smooth and garlicky and just coats your throat and mouth with flavor, oh my god. It is served warm with a side of toasted, thick, fluffy and perfect pita. It even tastes good the next day! I'm writing this review after eating the leftovers that's how good it was. I ate it last night, had the leftover hummus about an hour ago, and now my stomach is already aching for more as I write this- that is how good it is.
author: Caitilin D.

description: Great location for us as it was so close to our B&B but we could tell that parking in the area can be a challenge. In the restaurant the service was great, very attentive and our server really cared that we liked the food. Great food for sure.
author: T J.

description: If you want Lebanese food, this is a solid place. Hayes Valley is a fun area, and they have pretty good atmosphere and food (and it's relatively easy to get a table). That being said, since I don't live in the neighborhood, I don't see a huge draw to bring me back for this place, unless I'm really craving some kufte.
author: Mike G.

description:
The bamia is to die for, highly recommended, absolutely delish.
Friendly service without overdoing it.

Will be coming back.
author: Bob G.

description:
Very good food but when we went there to eat at only 730 in the evening would you believe that they had already run out of not 1 but 3 dishes!!! This shows an inexcusable lack of preparation!
Just be warned that what you see on the menu and desperately want to try might not be there.
author: Emily M.

description:
If the chef can't make substitutions, then you know that there is something wrong with the kitchen. And yes, a lot of the food seem to be pre-made and then reheated. The pita pizza was almost inedible, dry, tasteless and hard like a rock. Like something that came out of a box.

Service was OK, friendly but not very attentive. The crowd was mostly older, getting tipsy on wine. Not coming back here.
author: Maggie X.

description:
Back for seconds.

Not Lebanon. Yet. Wraps for lunch.

Chicken shawarma hit the spot. Plenty of healthy grilled chicken. Just the right amount of hummus. Lavash. Nothing else. Perfect.

Lebanese coffee complemented nicely as the fog rolled back in.

Eleven bucks for the wrap is more expensive than most other places so I can't give the full five stars. But it doesn't lessen my enthusiastic recommendation of Mazzat.

And Lebanon.
author: Jason B.

description:
BEST Lebanese food in SF!

Hummus is SO good!
Tabouli is made correctly with mostly parsley!
Assorted Pickle Platter is yummy!
Spinach Fatayer is perfect!
Mosaka was delicious!

Next time I'll try the kebbeh and other stuff too! We got the Mazzat Platter which is an excellent price and portions for 2 were perfect!
Will definitely return!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Just discovered this place in Hayes Valley. I think it has been here a while - but I never noticed because it is one block down from the main Hayes Street. Really glad I know about it. My date and I had a great experience. The ambiance is casual but sexy and hip ... the food was very fresh (I really liked Kibbeh) ... and the service was very attentive and friendly (we had an Asian waitress but I can't remember her name). All in all it was a superb. Also reasonable priced - so I may start just ordering to pick-up on my way home from work.
author: Dirk G.

description:
We absolutely love this place!  We've visited often enough they have started to recognize us, always a good thing, but this is the first time we took a larger group there.  They did an impeccable job with everything.  Food was perfect, wine was flowing, service was exceptional.  

I would highly recommend this place to anyone.
author: Ben E.

description:
After visiting a lot Mediterranean restaurants in the city, this is the one I definately would want to go again.. They were kind to accommodate us despite we being 20 mins late on our reservation. [reach before time to find street parking]
Priced just right, menu had plenty of vegetarian options for my mom. Resturant ambience is very cozy, almost like a wine bar.
author: Mehak K.

description:
This place is a really wonderful go-to casual weekday dinner option. I went for the first time last night and was delighted by how cozy and tasty it was. 

Ambiance: 3 stars (while the ambiance is just fine, it's not where its strengths lie. they've redone the space, but it's sort of a hodgepodge between upscale deli and casual restaurant. a bit random, but it works for a functional lunch or dinner.)

Service: both of the owners are so warm. their mom makes the lebanese food from scratch every morning, and you truly get the sense that this is a family enterprise. they're attentive and conversational, good people. 

Food: 4 stars 
Lentil soup- a-mazing. really delicious, comforting soup, just a tad lemony, spiced well. one of the best lentil soups i've had.
Spanokopita- i've had better. the filling is good, but the pastry isn't all that great. overall, it's a bit clumsy, so i would skip this next time. 
Chicken-artichoke pita- this is a good--not amazing. the chicken, haloumi cheese, and crust are really wonderful here, but the wilted spinach between the crust and toppings tastes exactly as such--wilted and tired. interestingly, i would order this again, because despite the wilted spinach, it's pretty good. 
Babaganoush- yum. it's a lemony mixture of roasted eggplant, tahini, and spices and it's served with hot grilled pita triangles. it tastes like it's made with love, and can easily feed 4 as an appetizer. 

Other:
Wine- the wine list isn't extensive, but the pours are big (and cheap)-- about $5 per glass
Portion size- much bigger than we anticipated! We got the above four items, but could have easily done with three. I would advise on starting with fewer and ordering more as needed. They also have a wonderful option of ordering 6 hot/cold tapas for $25 (serves 2). This is a great deal, especially considering the portion size. I'll definitely try this option in the future. 

Will be back again. I live around the corner, and it might be one of my favorite casual dinner options in Hayes Valley yet.
author: sfgal g.

description:
Amazing Tahini + Kibbeh. 

Friendly staff and fairly cheap! Beautiful location, horrible parking. Buahaha
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Half of the food I ordered was from frozen packages including Lubleh Bezalt "fresh cut  string beans" appetizer as well as the mix for Kabsse "rice dish with chicken". The rice for Kabsse was overcooked, and the whole dish felt like a huge plate of leftovers.
For the price point, I would expect fresh food choices that are staple in the Mediterranean cuisine.
author: Anna R.

description:
middle eastern guy here and really if you are looking for a fine traditional food its the place to go in the city, the food has the house made taste not a Costco premade style, the menu give you a good variety to choose from not a one style of food, I try most of them and the taste is more than fine.
like the atmosphere, the music is quite and nice, the price is good for what u order.
not like any other restaurant were they serve only bean style (hummus, falafel ..etc) and shawerma, it has a decent  food to eat, good place for friends dinner

I LIKE IT
author: Ammar A.

description: We have become regulars at Mazzat after discovering this place about a year ago. The food is fantastic and it's perfect spot for a date night or a group.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Spotted this place as we drove by and then found a place to park and stopped in. Catching from the outside (so different from Apollo) and it looked quite inviting. 
Great little space. I especially like the embedded power strips in the benches along the wall so people can plug in their equipment (laptops and what not) but thought it was odd when staff left their laptop plugged in and seated a couple right near that outlet!
It's clean, well lit in the day time, dimmed down nicely for the evening. Big display case with all the tasty goodies at hand. 
Service was a little slow. There was only one guy going around the tables and he couldn't handle the volume too well (forgot a few items, took a while to get our bill.) But the place is just newly opened, so I think they're just working out the kinks.
We ordered the 6 hot/cold tapas for $25 (serves 2). It seemed like everything was pre-made and warmed up. Spanokopita (spinach and feta cheese in filo pastry) was a little heavy. It would be nice if they were in smaller portions. The dolma (grape leaves) was very good. The falafel wasn't as good as I imagined, a little dry and not very flavorful. But the kibbe (ground meat, in little balls) was very tasty. The babaganoush was very good. A strong lemon influence dominated over the roasted eggplant and tahini. The grilled pita triangles worked well with it.
Coffee was a little cold. Lemongrass chamomile tea (in a bag) was good. Wish they had hibiscus tea. 
I like the ambiance and I think the service was just getting off its feet. I'll be coming back to get a Turkish coffee and a few bites to eat.
author: Naomi K.

description: I'm Lebanese so I was skeptical, but found myself impressed. Great ambiance, an easy walk to venues in Hayes Valley, and solid food. The okra dish (Bamya) was solid!
author: Omar M.

description: Fine, traditional Lebanese/Middle Eastern cuisine. Absolutely cosy, uncomplicated and genuine. Friendly staff. Affordable prices and generous portions. Dishes are delicious, unless you hate garlic :-)
author: Daniele R.

description: Fantastic food and service.  Quiet location.  Love this neighborhood gem.  Get in early as it fills up on the weekends.
author: April M.

description:
Great food, poor service...  My boyfriend and I came in on a lazy Saturday afternoon when no one else was in the restaurant.  It seemed the staff was more occupied with working on their laptop and having an internal meeting than with customer service.  With both of us having worked in restaurants, we are pretty understanding when it comes to being served our food (don't expect much, understand when delays in the kitchen happen, etc.).  We waited for the waitress to finish up a call on her cell phone prior to coming to our table.  When I later asked her what she recommended on the menu, she gave me a blank stare.  

The food was delicious, the wine was OK, the service needs improvement.
author: Mimi S.

description:
The mezza platter is the best way to try more things from the menu.  We ordered the baba ghanoush, hummus, dolma, meat pie, something with pomegranate in it, and falafel.  The first three were my favorites, the pomegranate thing was slightly watery, and the falafel, though well prepared, just seemed a little bland to me.

The server was personable and attentive, the ambiance is nice.  I'd go back to try other things.
author: Jenn C.

description: Wow yelpers, I'm surprised at all the positive feedback for the food at Mazzat. It is subpar at best. Nothing tasted home made or even close to fresh. American's have far too low expectations of what real Middle Eastern food should be...trust me, this is not it. The stuffed grape leaves were hard as a rock, as were the falafel. My table had ordered a bunch of things to share, and nothing stood out. I can always tell if the food is going to be legit by the pita. Let's just say whatever that bread was that they served is not pita- it was hard, tough, and dense. Not good. To be fair, the ambiance is nice and the service was very friendly. Here's what I want to know, do the owners of this place think this is good Lebanese? Do they eat this or do they go home and eat the good stuff?
author: Kylie S.

description: I don't seek out Mediterranean, in fact in may be one of the last options that come to mind when searching for a great meal out. While none of the dishes were ultra original or creative they were well executed, flavorful and delivered on authentic taste.  The service was friendly and attentive, the space is 'quaint' as they say. A solid 4 stars for food, ambiance and service.
author: Kristy M.

description: The food here is pretty good. In particular the hummus, cous cous and the pizzas. Overall their food is pretty good, but their service needs a bit of help on the phones. They are nice enough, but I guess often i want people to be REALLY nice when I spend money as a customer. We like eating here in Hayes Valley as it's easy and good.
author: Brent T.

description: I came here a year ago (sorry for the late review) and I loved everything about this place.  The food, vibe, and service were great.  We ordered plates of hummus, babaghanouge, tabouli, Kebbeh, and kafta.  The food was very fresh and our bread basket was always refilled.  The owner of the restaurant also made other great recommendations (I don't remember what! but I remember being really happy eating them!) and was very pleasant to talk to.  I will definitely be coming back again!
author: Mimi N.

description:
We (two people) ordered tapas style platter with three hot items and three cold items. The ingredients were fresh. We ordered grilled cheese, Spanakopita, Mosaka as hot items. All were yummy. 

The service was excellent.
author: Lo Y.

description: Amazing food at a reasonable price point. My girlfriend and I couldn't decide what to order (it all looked so good), so we opted for the platter. Highly recommend it. Great wine by the bottle as well.
author: Matthew H.

description: Perfect for a nice dinner out: delicious food (we got the "everything" platter), sexy ambiance, really friendly, nice, laid-back waiter.  Loved it.
author: daisy s.

description: We were in SF for a few days visiting from Santa Cruz, staying in a friend's apt in the Hayes Valley, so this was a random visit for us.  Very happy with the outcome!  Ordered the platter for 2 & cleaned our plates, esp enjoyed the eggplant salad & kibbe.  Nothing special about the wine selection but would definitely return on a future trip.  It was late on an early weekday evening so we didn't have reservations, but probably a good idea on the weekend.
author: Linda W.

description: I was part of a large group celebration at this restaurant and had a fantastic, splendid meal with all the tasty food you would expect: falafel, hummus, fatoush, babaghanouge, warek enab (grape leaves), kafta, etc. Everything was obviously prepared with great care and all fresh ingredients. Our host (from Beirut) confirmed the authenticity of everything served and I can confirm it all being very delicious! I would definitely go back here again.
author: Noah P.

description:
Get the Babagenouj (sp?)

This used to be the Apollo Market at Fell and Laguna. Now it's been totally upgraded inside, and they serve a fabulous and really inexpensive menu of home-made Lebanese food.  By home-made I mean that they seem to be using someone's mom's recipes. The owner and the staff are very friendly and welcoming--if you've ever been to a middle eastern country, you've experienced this kind of genuine hospitality.  Hard to find in the US, especially hard in wacky California.
author: Michael C.

description: Ended up there because the restaurant we wanted to go to was too busy. Mazzat was also busy but shorter wait, and I'm glad we waited! Loved the food! Excellent service! I think this place is a family business. Waiters were very friendly! The place is super cozy! We had appetizers and entrees. The baba ghanoush was delicious! Have to recommend that!
author: J. S.

description: Really great food overall. We totally fatted out there. Had hummus w beef, fatoush, tablouli, beef and lamb kafta, chicken pita pizza, mint lemonade, and a few other things I can't remember but I have no issues with any of the food. It was all absolutely delicious.
author: Annie W.

description: Authentic food.  Phenomenal olive oil, great service.  Lebanese coffee just like it should be.  Kibbe that was crisp and juicy.  What a find!
author: D M.

description:
The service here is so great, and the food is delicious.
For Sunday brunch, the besties and myself opted for something new instead of waiting in some hideous line for once, and this looked new-ish and fun. 
Totally worth it! 
Beans, artichokes, coffee, and salad. 
Perfection. 

Give this little jewel some love!
author: A. H.

description: Tabouli salad is the best tabouli that I've ever had! I also love the Shankaleesh, hummus, and the lamb Shawerma wrap!
author: Logan S.

description: Was really excited about trying this place but it was just average. Their wines averaged $12 a glass with an $18 minimum per person. We ordered the six hot/cold plate combo. The green bean dish was not good. The ouzi rice with beef was not good at all-- it was actually very disappointing. They mixed the rice and beef together so there weren't actual pieces of beef-- the rice was infused with it. On the positive, I will say the highlights were the tabouli, labneh, and the spicy potatoes. Again, I was really looking forward to this place after reading the reviews-- but I wasn't too satisfied with the food. The service was wonderful-- the servers were great-- just wish our food was yummier!
author: Lissette L.

description:
Great food.  Very nice owner, came to our table and treated us extremely well.  

The baba ghanoush was stellar, as was the grilled chicken pita.  Would have liked to see more kebob plates.

Two thumbs up for Mazzat!
author: Fred J.

description: This place is azeem (great!)  Three of us shared a mezza with kibbe, sfiha, baba ghanouj (the best I've ever tasted), hoummous, waraqat anab (stuffed grape leaves), tabouli.  I followed that with the delicious lentil soup, while my companions tried the chicken wraps, which came grilled like panetta.  Brilliant.  We enjoyed the kanafe to round off the meal, along with mint tea.  Mabrouk to Suzi and Adel. Hope you are a big success!
author: Judith R.

description: Just plain  rude is what they are. The food was good. Never going back. Not even a thank you when we left the restaurant.
author: Jason F.

description:
I really like this place.  The happy hour is hard to beat - very inexpensive wine and beer, good food in a pleasant atmosphere.  The hummus is some of the best I have had in SF.  The Shwarma also very tasty.  That's all I have tried so far, but am looking forward to trying more things on the menu.  

If you are looking for authentic middle eastern food (as opposed to Turkish, which is what the other two "Kebab" places in Hayes Valley are), this is a great choice. 

So glad they are in the 'hood!
author: Leah A.

description: I REALLLLLY wanted to love this place. The wait staff is friendly. The interior is warm with nice background music.... But one does not eat the environment alone. The lentil soup was hot but lacked flavor. The Malbec wine rocked. We sampled 3 cold platters and 3 warm ones. It was....ok. The baklava kicked butt tho!
author: Darrin D.

description: I LOVE this place. No matter what, there is more than enough food to go around. I tend to order the Mazzat Platter and get some good variety. Their hummus is to die for, the best hummus of any restaurant in SF I've had. They also have great babaganoush and mousaka. I have yet to have something I don't enjoy there, such great food. The pitas are always fresh, they have great wines and the ambiance is fab. Love the owners, they are so sweet and attentive. Definitely one of my faves!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Last Saturday evening, my brother and I found ourselves wandering in Hayes Valley, looking for a place to eat dinner and catch up. After being quoted long wait times at the neighborhood's trendier venues, we stumbled upon Mazzat, a new Lebanese restaurant and wine bar on the corner of Laguna and Fell. We were enticed by the offerings listed on the menu in the window, and were sold when a group sitting at a table inside made eye contact with us, pointed to their plates, and gave us the thumbs up.

Upon entering, we were kindly greeted by Manuel, both the host and our waiter. The restaurant was clean and modern inside, yet cozy with dark, wood-top tables, dim lighting, and candles - great ambience for a date or a nice dinner with a small group of friends. It was also quiet enough that my brother and I could talk over the extensive and delicious options on the menu, plotting our gastronomic plan of action.

You see, Mazza are the Arab equivalent of Tapas, so my brother and I decided to forego the more traditional dinner options (which included Lebanese rice dishes, wraps, and pizzas), and opted for the Mazzat Meal Platter ($18 per person). With this we could choose three hot and three cold mazzat dishes, which would be served family-style with warm pita bread. We were happy to find many vegetarian options (neither of us eat meat), though with twenty-nine mazzat dishes to choose from, there were plenty for the carnivorous crowd, too. We finally thought we had decided on our six dishes, but just to be sure, we asked Manuel what he thought of our selection. He suggested we try a few mazza we had initially written off as not quite our style, but my brother and I decided to trust his expert opinion -- especially when he said that he'd bring us our original selections if we were unsatisfied with his recommendations.

But not a bite went back once the plates came out. Elegantly served on a family-style platter, all the dishes were full of flavor, a reflection of both the freshness of the ingredients and the delicate balance of spices, herbs, and mints used in their preparation. My brother and I both agreed that the best of the six was the one we were most wary of, the Fatet Batinjan. Manuel recommended this dish of fried eggplant topped with garlic yogurt sauce, pita croutons, and pine nuts. Definitely not your standard hummus or tabouli, this dish was the highlight of our dinner. I also enjoyed the Mujadara, a lentil rice dish topped with grilled onion and served with a side of cucumber yogurt sauce. I'm usually not a fan of cucumber yogurt sauce, but the cucumbers were so fresh and the yogurt so light that I used my last piece of pita bread to clean the inside of the cup. In fact, there wasn't a crumb left on the entire platter when my brother and I were finished with our meal. Alex, the owner, came to clear the plates and told us that nothing made him happier than to see a platter as clean as ours. Such personal service made the dining experience that much more enjoyable.

I washed my meal down with a glass of cabernet ($7), while my brother had a pint of the Ommegang brew they had on tap ($8). And finally, although we were stuffed from the generously portioned feast, we couldn't say no to dessert since dinner had been so delicious. My brother got the Namoura ($3), a Lebanese pastry made with semolina, soaked in sugar syrup, and sprinkled with pistachios (although the menu said almonds). I had two delicious forkfuls, and would recommend it as one of the best Middle Eastern desserts I've had. 

All in all, Mazzat is a classy and delicious spot for dinner, especially for a special date night. Alternatively, it'd make a great stop for just a small plate and a glass of wine before a night out. Given the high quality food, the impeccable service, and the trendy area of town, the prices are fair (though not cheap for those of us on a student budget).
author: Theresa P.

description: Disappointed with the service, just seemed overwhelmed! We stood at the door forever, and we almost walked out. Acknowledge people at the door, at the very least! They couldn't handle giving us tea at the same time and gave some lame excuse about how they ran out of hot water and then it was not even good anyway! The gave us a chippped plate, which I was surprised to see and yes, disappointed. The lentil soup was subpar--very little flavor, had to squeeze lemon to salvage it. My main dish was very good--lamb, so that's why it got three stars instead of 2.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
This place had some of the most interesting and tasty versions of food I thought I knew! And as a super beer geek, I enjoyed that they had Lebanese beer. 

The atmosphere was modern but welcoming and kinda romantic. The service was fantastic. I think everyone who was working there at some point asked us how we were doing. 

I defiantly recommend this place.
author: Dani O.

description:
I really wanted to like this place as its only one of a few middle eastern restaurants relatively speaking in the city. This may have been an off night but TERRIBLE service, at least on Friday December 5. Lots of wait staff but all huddled around the bar talking to one another and acting busy, not attending to the room, at least to us. Place was empty for a Friday night (I understand why now). We were sat and then ignored, till my friend went up and asked if we could place our order as we were going to a show. Owner must have hired all his friends and relatives (young and inexperienced); no one here seemed to really understand service or what it meant to be competing with the tons of great places to eat just around the corner.
Food was fairy good (warning..beef is the only non vegetarian protein on the menu..no chicken, no fish, which is kinda wierd); good vegetarian options tho. I wont be going back. Too many other great restaurants with great food and good service... If I were the owner, I would get involved in the operations. You are losing money!
author: Mischa M.

description:
either i was really hungry or..,

...the falafel wrap was awesome.  perfect falafel, hummus and sauce inside.  add hot sauce on top, and pickled veggie salad.

must go back to try other things!
author: Robert S.

description: Mazzat is delicious!  It is located on the edge of Hayes valley.  The interior is very nice yet simplistic.  The service felt very homey and authentically Lebanese.  We had a few appetizers - the baba ganoush was terrific, as were the lemony cauliflower and the yogurt/cheese dip with herbs.  Plates are medium sized and a bit on the pricey side.  Overall, I would recommend.
author: Kurosh H.

description: As much as I'd like Mazzat to be good, I am honestly shocked that it has an average of 4 stars.  I've eaten a lot of Mediterranean food in my day, and this place is just not great.  I feel a little guilty that I'm giving them a bad review because the staff was super nice and friendly, but . . . well, first of all, the meat pie.  The dough used for the pie was dense and dry.  The halloumi cheese should be avoided at all costs.  They were basically congealed, waxy slabs of plastic and nearly inedible.  Fatet betinjan - merely okay.  And when eggplant is merely okay, I get suspicious because I love eggplant in all its varietals.  If you're somehow forced to eat here, I would go for the babaghanouge or couscous - those were both pretty decent.  But Jannah on Fulton or even Ziryab on Divis are both substantially better, and there is no way I'd waste any more precious food calories on Mazzat.
