author: Jenny R.

description: Went here with a friend who knew the place. The food was excellent as was the service.  They have a few different beers, white and red wine, etc.  BTW, their wine glasses/pours are huge.  Adam the owner was super nice and attentive.  Will go back for sure.
author: Manuela P.

description: A-M-Z-I-N-G. If you like the genre, like I do, you'd love this place. Ambiance - 5 stars. Food - 5 stars. They run out of Hummus the day we were there, but I can't wait to come back and try it. Judging by the rest of the food, it will not disappoint.
author: Oren R.

description:
seriously delicious.  we came here for dinner last night and were definitely not let down.  we ordered 3 plates and some drinks for 2 people and that was more than enough food.  at about $10 a plate (some less) this was such a great value! you can try a bunch of things in decent portions and not completely break the bank.

my favorite was the fatet batinjan( fried eggplant with pita croutons and garlic yogurt sauce).  spread on a warm, grilled pita, this was absolutely delicious (i'm still thinking about it the next morning).  we also got the mujadara (lentil rice with grilled onions with a yogurt cucumber sauce) and the grilled haloumi.  the mujadara and the grilled haloumi were both good but not anything particulary special.

i would definitely come back here, even if just for a drink and the eggplant!
author: Lisa C.

description: Best Lebanese food I've had in a while! I'm from Lebanon so that means a lot. Everything tasted homemade like my mom made it, the kibbeh, spinach pie, hummus, meat pie, shawarma and all! The prices are great and the food is great, you really can't ask for more. On my way out they gave me a free baklava bc I'm from the homeland which was sweet. It was also delicious! Great ppl that run the place and work there :)
author: Sandra G.

description: By far, the most elegant, delicious, welcoming lebanese restaurant in Hayes valley and SF. Food was delicious, service impeccable and the ambiance intimate and chic. I started with the lentil soup which was as authentic as my mom's recipe. All the mazza plates were true to their origins as well and are tastefully decorated. Being lebanese myself, I am always super picky when it comes to eating out Lebanese dishes since it's so hard to get lebanese recipes right. This restaurant truly perfected all the mazza on their menu. Host was super friendly without being too invasive. Prices are very reasonable, especially with big portions. This is the ideal place for an after work glass of wine joint, a date or a night out with friends to share all these delightful plates..
author: Zeinab C.

description: Great place to grab a quick bite to eat. The prices are extremely reasonable for the area. The baba ghanoush is fantastic!
author: Jeff V.

description:
I went here for a family dinner one evening and was pleasantly suprised.  The service and food were both great.  Large portions of the hummus and dip, but not enough pita bread on the side to go with it.  So we did find ourselves ordering more.  At least it was nice and warm and fresh.  

I love halloumi cheese so I knew immediately what I wanted to order.  I ordered a halloumi wrap and should have listened to the others when they tried to tell me it's massive.  And it was, but it was sooo good!  They had lots of other options so I will definitely go back.
author: Urvi R.

description: Good stuff. Feeling it. Happened upon it on the way to Hayes Valley. Attentive service and all around welcome atmosphere. Food was good to boot ya heard.
author: Gregory H.

description: Lebanese Awesomeness!!!!!!!! I have now been here about 8 times so I can honestly write a good review. This is probably one of my Favorite  Mediterranean restaurants ever! The wraps are amazing, the Lebanese Pizza KICKS MAJOR taste bud ass, the service is great depending on the server, The young kid is the best so try to get sat in his section. Everything I have tried there has been above and beyond awesome and I will be attending this joint regularly.
author: Matthew F.

description: Finally a lebanese place in San francisco, a warm welcome , great service and staff and most importantly the food is amazing,  this must be only place that reminds me of backhome, and the owners are such welcoming people , eventhough they are busy they give you their time and talk to you and always concerned about how their food taste , has the mazza for 2 , great presentation and taste , will surely go back to try different things and can't wait for the new menu , i wish them best of luck because they deserve it , don't miss out on this place people !!!!
author: NAEL K.

description: Great Lebanese food! (And I've been to Lebanon a few times!) I usually don't like baba but theirs is so fresh I loved it. All the dishes we had were exceptional. I'll definitely come back. Much better food than La Med or Medjool.
author: Jarrett S.

description:
Mazzat is a gem; middle eastern food at its best.  The decor is quiet and unobtrusive, lending itself to a feeling of calm, privacy and cozy intimacy. 
 
We ordered several items from the "Cold Mazzat" menu: hummus, babaghanouge, and eggplant pomegrante.  Having lived in the mideast, I am used to being disappointed by one or more of these dishes.  Not so here:  all were excellent. The hummus felt home-made, from the kitchen of a friend. The babaghanouge had a just-right smoked flavor.  The eggplant pomegrante was new to us, and we loved it.   

We also ordered one of the main house salads, called Faloush.  It is one of the very best salads l've ever had.  The pomegrante dressing was to die for.  I would go back again and again for this dish alone. 

Suzi, one of the owners, was there each time we needed her, and consistently went out of her way to make our visit perfect.  For example, we were having trouble fitting our cups and saucers on the table.  She whisked them away, replacing them with lovely tall tea mugs. 
 
The menu is fairly extensive.  In future visits, we want to try:  Lebanese wines, wraps, and main courses (especially a chicken dish with jasmine rice, veggies, raisins and pine nuts). 

I'd advise calling ahead if you have a party of more than 4.  We were there on a weekday; it might also be a good idea to make a reservation on a Friday or Saturday evening. 

Finding a parking space in this area might take of time; we found a parking space quite easily, but I think it was sheer luck. 

However, this same location has an added benefit we didn't realize beforehand:  Mazzat is on Fell Street, one of the "inner highways" of San Francisco, this one leading toward the ocean.  Thus, if you live in the Haight, the Richmond, the Sunset, etc., or - if you live north of the city (Marin or Sonoma), or if you're heading to Highway 280, Mazzat it an excellent choice since you just drive up this inner highway and you're well on your way home.
author: lahni d.

description: We got there without a reservation (after attempting multiple times with no success) at 5:30pm on a Saturday.  The place was completely empty, however they would only seat us at a table meant for 2 (we were 3) up against the door.  We asked them to move us to a normal table and they said no because they had only reservations.  They showed us their reservation book and everything.  The place was COMPLETELY EMPTY!  Unfriendly.
author: Gabriela M.

description: Standard middle Eastern food. Every dish was a bit heavy handed with the olive oil on top so for that I will not be returning.  I prefer hayes and kabob.
author: LT B.

description:
I have to say I was truly excited about trying this place out as I had heard many nice things about it and I am Lebanese!  First off the menu is not user friendly.  The wait staff was not the most attentive as it took awhile to take our order, the waiter did not check in to see how the food was either.  Now on to the food.  We ordered the eggplant mousaka and falafel for an appetizer.  The mousaka was quite good, but the falafel tasted as if they were not fried, but baked.  Not good at all.  We both opted for trying shawermas.  We ordered one lamb and one chicken.  Both of them were SOOO DRY it was horrible.  There was no barely any tahina in the wrap, it was down right awful.  Neither of us barely ate half our dish.  I decided to tell the waiter as he could see neither of us finished hardly anything.  He acknowledged that he knows their shawerma is on the dry side.  He asked if we wanted anything else instead and we opted to get out as soon as possible.  The waiter showed up with a complimentary dessert which was mediocre.  We ended up spending over $50 for really bad food.  At the very least we would have hoped the owner would have apologized and comped one meal as most gracious restaurants would do, but they did not.  This is a true sign of the kind of establishment this is.  We were not looking for a free dinner by anymeans, but as a business owner there is a right way and a wrong way to deal with customers having a bad experience and this was the wrong way.  Now I am so upset I am writing this negative review and will tell all my friends NOT to go here.  Being Lebanese this was a true insult to my culture. 

OH WELL!  They say the best cooking is from your MOM :)
author: Mary B.

description: I had the chicken artichoke pita with tea.  It was nice and light, it wasn't greasy, and the price was right.  The people watching is great - it's right by the Hayes Valley Farm.  Definitely a keeper.
author: Anne Marie F.

description: If you are looking for fresh, healthy, perfectly-spiced, well-portioned Middle Eastern food, Mazzat is your place. Mazzat's menu is full of variety and reasonably priced, offering  incredibly fresh and tasty dishes. It is my go-to place when I want something I know I will like. It is my go-to place when friends and family are visiting.  It is my go-to place when I want to introduce locals to a restaurant they have never tried - always with good results. It is consistent, and did I say fresh? If I have only one complaint... occasionally they have been out of a dish or two when I've ordered; however, I tend to eat late, sometimes near closing time, and it only makes sense that they could sell out given they make everything so fresh. The ambiance is also very intimate and warm. Perfect for a romantic date night or a casual night out with friends.
author: A. O.

description: Great food, great service, beautiful atmosphere. Friendly, elegant, exotic, yummie! Give them a try.
author: Kathy S.

description:
So I was a little upset when Cafe Apollo closed abruptly for renovations, which seemed to take awhile to complete.  I really loved their food, and was afraid when the new place open, the food wouldnt live up to the homestyle-cooking of Cafe Apollo.

What has now opened in its place is Mazzat, which far exceeded my high expectations.  The food is just as good, if not better, with a wider range of choices and elegant presentation.  A cozy atmosphere, and beer and wine selection to boot.  From what was a quasi-liquor store/deli before,  one could even bring a date  to this new establishment for coffee or a snack.  Worth checking out.
author: Jay D.

description: This place is AWESOME!  Both their falafel and chicken wraps are the best I've ever had.  I got it to go & there was a delicious shredded pickled carrot/cabbage mini salad included. The extra side of tahini I requested was homemade with fresh diced tomatoes and onions. The people that work there are so F'n cool. Both times I went they were closing up and still took my order & treated me like a best friend. I HIGHLY recommend!
author: Tommy W.

description: I wasn't around when this location was Cafe Apollo, but I can't imagine anyone being disappointed at Mazzat.  The owner is very involved and attentive, the $3 house wine at happy hour was fantastic, and I have already been back twice to order appetizer platters.  I love that they serve halloumi cheese and hummus with ground beef, and during the day when it's slower they play fun Lebanese music and serve great turkish coffee and lattes.  I was also happy that tea was served in traditional Lebanese glass cups.  Thanks Mazzat!  I'll be back often!
author: Sarah D.

description: Were you sad to see Apollo Market & Deli and its falafel sandwich close down? Apollo has re-opened as a restaurant with the same falafel sandwich and with more menu options.  Nice upgrade.
author: Wakako U.

description: The baba ghanoush, lentil rice, and artichoke chicken flat bread were all fantastic.
author: Michael A.

description: Decent food, rude/short service and a nice atmosphere. I'm not sure how to rate this one. I wouldn't go back, but if you find yourself here I liked the Mosaka (eggplant and tomato mazzat) but the spinach stuffed dough tasted overwhelmingly acidic. Not a memorable spot compared to the gems in Hayes Valley.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
WOW.  Authentic.  Phenomenal.  As wonderful as the Lebanese food I grew up with!  (Sorry, Aunt Alia!)  

Fatthyr (both spinach and meat pies) were baked to a picturesque golden brown.  The kibbe was surprisingly accurate (replete with pine nuts in the center), the hummus (with ground meat and pine nuts) definitely the best I've had in the City.  

Turns out, my surprise birthday lunch was there this past weekend.  The table of 16 (many Middle Easterners), RAVED.  

Great service.  Kind owners.  Easy location.  Fun Arabic Happy Birthday songs.  Simply can't get a better quality Lebanese meze for two for $25.  GO. GO. GO.
author: Steve D.

description: 4 of us went for dinner on Sat night and shared the falafel,kibbeh,cauliflower dish,hummus with beef,house pizza and baklava - all ok but nothing was particularly outstanding. Unfortunately, although it didn't seem to be that late, they had run out of eggplant -which is when I remembered that this is not a restaurant in the middle east! Also,had 2 glasses of  v.delicious Lebanese red wine and wrapped the meal up with very good turkish coffee.
author: Renuka V.

description:
I'm giving this 4 stars for now, with the option to upgrade to 5 in the future.

The fouol was almost soup-like, doing its best to fall out of the came-with-it pita I spooned it into. It was sooooo full of flavor that I forgave it its logistical issues.

The "Lebanese pizza" house pita was merely satisfying  (well, anything would be hard to match the fouol) with a generous layer of diced tomatoes and a decent amount of feta. Still, it was quite good and I'd try their other "pizza/pitas."

Seating is on the awkward side. I'm not sure why tiny places get those awkward high tables and chairs for the two tops, but this place has them.  The three-seat counter seating has a shallow shelf that looks really uncomfortable and like it barely has room for the food. So, while I'll be back for the excellent and reasonably-priced food, I'd only eat here solo or duo during off-peak hours.

Good music at a reasonable volume. Friendly service.
author: Charles B.

description: Lamb shawarma with hot sauce- yum! Best one I've had in SF! Also best baba ganoush. Owner is very nice & friendly. Service attentive.
author: Susan D.

description: I decided to stop in for a quick bite before their dinner rush while i was running around that neighborhood.  The place is elegant and clean.  While i didn't get around to trying some of their fantastic wines, i did get a delicious meal.  Bamieh (Okra ) is one of my favorite middle eastern dishes.  Just a few bites were enough to send me back to the days of old in Lebanon. Delicious food and great selection on the menu.. I will be going back to try more of their dishes and re-yelp.   Staff is super friendly and the music is great.  Glad to have a place like that in Hayes Valley.
author: momo m.

description:
Bomb Lebanese food.
Hit the spot with the folks for my pops birthday.
The Kibbeh was a different style than mom's cooking but extremely tasty.
Gotta love variations on a theme.
author: Aaron S.

description: Overpriced basic food made without any inspiration. We had a family style serving of different dishes of cold and hot dishes, which all tasted more or less the same. The Lebanese white wine, which was specially recommended by the server, compared to the cheapest California one. Same story, no taste. Just the amounts of the hummus, eggplant and rice were big, probably trying to make up for the missing flavor.
author: Gunter Z.

description: Amazing. Wonderful service. Food like your momma makes. We got a half bottle of wine for free. Great place to come for lunch or dinner.
author: Laura L.

description: It's good but for middle eastern I prefer Jannah on fulton.
author: Raquel B.

description: So bomb!! I am new to the city and my boyfriend is Lebanese. He said there are no good Lebanese/ Mediterranean restaurants in SF, so for Valentine's Day I thought I'd surprise him with Mazzat. He was thoroughly impressed and so was I! The food is so flavorful and light - seriously you can't go wrong with anything you order there. I was obsessed with the yogurt labni. It's like greek yogurt with this spice that they import from Lebanon -  wayyy better than taziki. If you are new to the cuisine I say just get the Mazzat platter and go to town. Also - great wine and the staff is really nice.
author: hayley h.

description: This place feels like a mixture between a cafe and a sit-down restaurant and manages to pull it off well.  The food was very authentic and it was good to see a true 'greek' place in SF, instead of the generic mediterranean.  So far so good, though when we looked at the menu we were hard pressed to find dinner 'platters' or dishes, the options on the menu are limited. Would be nice to see this place expand its menu and serve more of the delicious food.
author: Prakhar S.

description: Good food and always friendly service. Pleasant ambiance that feels like home to me. Good variety in the menu. Love the tabbouleh and the hummus! Ideally would improve the wine list!
author: D F.

description: Made the mistake of coming here very hungry. Between my dad and I, we ordered almost one of everything. Mazzat has some wonderful Lebanese food and otter Arabic dishes that I put up to one of my other favorite Arabic places, Jannah in the panhandle. The staff is friendly an makes very good recommendations. This is another cash only place, so be prepared. You will be pleasantly surprised by the portion size and low price, as well as the casual dinning atmosphere. This is a great place to relax with friends, eat and talk. I recommend doing their starter platter if you want to try a lot of things, as well as their hummus mixed with ground beef. Also, their falafel wrap is huge and delicious.
author: Benjamin M.

description: Fresh fab food, period.   Hummus is to die for.  Seriously.  Great place to dine with friends - you can get an app sampler plate of 6 cold or hot dishes for $55.  The portions are very generous and easily can feed 4+.  This place makes me want to relocate to Hayes!!!
author: Mischen C.

description: Excellent food, reasonably priced, loved the ambiance, didn't have to wait for a table (even w/o a reservation on a busy night), and the owner was so sweet and friendly. Definitely check this place out!
author: Marianne G.

description:
A nice cafe with warm, wonderful service and great food. We enjoyed our dinner and would very happily eat here again.

My wife and I were in the area to attend a concert at Herbst Theatre. We discovered Mazzat on Yelp and since it  was a short walk away we decided to give it a try.

As another reviewer mentioned, the menu is essentially hot and cold Mediterranean tapas and some salads. There aren't really any formal entrees. However, you can share some number of dishes family style for a set price. In our case, we shared 6 dishes for $25, and also split a salad.

We chose falafel, babaganush, pickled vegetables (anti pasta), couscous with feta, spanikopita, and a chicken, artichoke, and feta "pie".

They were all delicious and freshly made. The couscous with feta was tasty and filling -- pretty much as it sounds. The spanikopita was a bit too rich for me, but my wife loved it. I loved the babaganush, which had a great texture and just the right amount of lemon. It was outstanding.

The chicken, artichoke, and feta "pie" wasn't really a pie but an open-faced pita, and it was generously topped and flavorful.

The spinach and smoked salmon salad with grape tomatoes and onions was served in a light dressing. We probably didn't need -- the platter was plenty for us -- but it tasted great and definitely filled out the meal. We didn't have any room left for dessert.

We had a glass of the house merlot, which was a very nice table wine. 

The service was extremely friendly. We lingered a bit over dinner and were there for about an hour and twenty minutes, and the owner (who was also our waiter) couldn't have been nicer. This was early so there was no wait and we weren't inconveniencing anyone.

All in all, we were very happy to have found Mazzat, and look forward to eating there again the next time we are near Davies and the Opera House.
author: J M.

description: I ordered chicken shawarma for take-out from here and it was okay. Everything looked and tasted fresh, but the flavors just didn't do it for me. The presentation of everything in the restaurant was nice though, and I'd consider going back to try another dish.
author: Richa A.

description:
The food is great and very tasty, but the ambiance and service have room for improvement. 

We went there with a party of seven on a Saturday early evening before 6pm. We had a reservation, which they hadn't noted down. They moved two small tables (to be used by two people) together and crammed the seven of us into this space. The waitress was good about recommending food for our party. The food was very delicious and the portions were generous.

After the food was brought out, the service became more inattentive, e.g. we had to catch the waitress for our water to be refilled. The music was too loud and jarring for my taste and - in combination with our party being packed into a tiny space - made the quality of the food pale and the overall experience not so pleasant.

I might give this place a 2nd chance and go back there with with a single companion during off-peak hours, just for the quality of the food, but wouldn't go there with a group again.
author: Bernhard K.

description:
Wondering around the city after flying in.  A chilly summer night and all the area bars are hopping.  We walked by this establishment and thought... no don't want to try something new (Lebanese cuisine)  Walked around a bit more, then walked by again and thought, lets do it.  And I am glad we did.  They did get our entree order wrong, (Ordered chicken thighs, got lamb) but when it tastes this good, who cares. 

Good service, great house wine at a nice price.  They have an option to pick 6 small plates, 3 hot and 3 cold.  If we had a small group this would have been the way to go.  We just ordered our entrees.  
The rice is amazing, buttery and nutty.  Flavors of the lamb and meatballs ground lamb were spot on. Great natural flavors for the sauce, simple and did what more places should do.  Let the flavor of ingredients speak for themselves.
author: Erick M.

description: I've passed on this little place before because the menu seems pretty basic and I like things that are a little more creative. Finally went Friday night though and loved it. Charming, cozy, small space. Friday night around 730 there were only 2 seats at the bar, which I happen to enjoy but I'd suggest making reservations as it seems that's what most people have done and they're busy. Food was much more interesting than the menu suggests. Ask for the eggplant dish that is their best seller--I will go back specifically for that. Really liked the fava beans as well as a rice and ground lamb (I think) that had a great cinnamon spice. Our service was attentive and friendly yet I never felt rushed even on a busy night. Definitely going back.
author: Shari D.

description: great food honestly, but the only problem was that once you step out of the restaurant the smell of the kitchen is stuck to your clothes.
author: Sulaiman B.

description: Fantastic food and extremely friendly staff and owners. Easily my favorite restaurant in Hayes Valley.
author: Kenneth L.

description: Went with a couple friends on a weeknight. The service wasn't amazing but the food was great! I'm definitely going back
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Came here with my Lebanese/Palestinian friend and she loved it ("best place I've been outside of France/Lebanon").  We just did an assortment of the mazzat (small plates) and fattoush.  The meat pies and the kibbeh are awesome (everything is good, but those were my favorites).  All the stalwart dishes were good and my lemonade was pretty tasty too.  

Cute little place, definitely a nice addition to Hayes Valley.  I'll be coming back and bringing more friends.
author: Josh D.

description:
Yay, I'm a fan.  

I am an Arabic food snob.  In any other city, I'd give this place a 3, but considering the arabic food landscape of SF, it gets 4.  I am on a quest for good shawarma and this place had a decent one.  We had a pretty in-depth conversation with the cook about why she uses this type of bread, that type of sauce, her spice mix, and how she puts the shawarma together.  

Good things:
- cute ambiance
- hummus (i think it had a tad too much tahini, but my Arab accompaniment though it was great)
- friendly cook
- meat pies were decent
- shawarma.  this is some good, some bad.  
  *i'm not a fan of lavash, but evidently the reason all the Arab places in this city use lavash is b/c the good pita bread is not easily and freshly available.  
*  chicken- seasoned well but a bit too dry for my taste.
*  other fixins- good mix, good taste.  sauce was good.

Things that could change:
- they were cleaning the kitchen with some pretty strong chemicals while we were eating.  it made it difficult to enjoy the food.  then they opened the windows and door...and wow, did it get cold in there!
- the menu is pretty limited.  they know this and are expanding it.  they hope to have an expanded menu within a few days- something to look forward to!
- kibbe were a little soggy, but tasted really good

I'll keep my eye on this place as it expands and will definitely give it another try.
author: goph s.

description: Pre cooked shrimp.  I'm almost positive it was frozen pre-cooked shrimp or something you'd get from a Safeway deli tray. The edges all smooth and the texture hard.  Its better to say you're out than serve terrible product. They also said they were Jumbo shrimp and they were really small (36/40). We ordered the platter so tried six dishes total.  Hummus- decent but runny. Maybe that's how the Lebanese like it?  Eggplant w/yogurt- very good, eggplant with the "shrimp" was pretty good (if you're a fan of cinnamon) sans the shrimp, fava beans - gross- I've only had canned fava beans that tasted like that.  Labne was good but how could it not be? Its just strained yogurt.  We got the pickles and vegetables which were pretty good too.  But I won't be going back because of those shrimp.  I don't trust the person cooking/buying who serve pre-cooked shrimp. And honestly I didn't see or hear a kitchen. Just one guy behind the counter cooking? Microwaving? Not sure but super quiet.  Without those shrimp I'd give 3 stars for food, 4 stars for ambiance and for our waitress who was very nice.
author: Sarah A.

description: The people who work here are very nice and helpful. I really did not enjoy the food here. i don't know where all these 4-5 stars are coming from. It might be authentic lebanese food but it just was not good. Strong garlic flavors, canned beans, defrosted  precooked shrimp. Maybe it was just what we ordered was not good but we ordered a lot.
author: Sammy M.

description: The food is phenomenal. A friend that lived in Lebanon said it tasted just like when she lived there. the babaganoush even converted another friend who does not like eggplant. The wine selection is very good. Go for the Lebanese wines. You will positively surprised. The ambiance is awesome. The service impeccable. The owner and the waiters are extremely friendly and make you feel at home.
author: Erdmann R.

description: My friend and I walked in to the warm and cozy restaurant, but left rather disappointed in the food quality. The falafel was totally dry with very little tahini sauce to go with it, the red wine was too warm, the salad was wilted, and the spanikopita was not made of the flaky filo dough you would expect. I was pretty disappointed in the quality of the food for how nice the ambiance was. I would definitely recommend other mediterranean restaurants in the area if you're looking for good falafel, hummus, or other tasty tapas.
author: Cait S.

description:
This place is phenomenal!  The grilled halloumi is delicious, as is the moussaka.  The real gem of the meal was the namourra - it was heaven drenched in honey with a delicate lavender essence.  That in itself is enough to make me come back time & time again.  The fact that everyone was so friendly & that the dessert was on the house made us feel like we had been brought into the family.

The owner is extremely knowledgeable and friendly.  He has various kitchens around the bay area, but this is his first stand alone restaurant.  It is most definitely a success!
author: Jessica H.

description:
I'm amazed by all the four- and five-star reviews -- would love to visit the place they're referring to. 

In the course of my two visits, I've never had a waiter ask me how my meal was, or refill my drink. The service was nonexistent. 

If you decide to try it anyway, get something other than the falafel deluxe -- it's flavorless.
author: Cameron B.

description: Found this restaurant cuz the German place down the block was way too  overcrowded for my taste... But, WHAT A FIND! Absolutely fantastic and delicious cuisine, simply presented. Listen, the portions were perfectly suited for my partner's and my appetite... not too much, not too fru fru skimpy. Just right. We had the hummus appetizer to start with, followed by entrees of steak and lamb. Not too much, not too little... just right. Very tasty! I'm telling everybody about this place!
author: Randolph M.

description: Nothing but good news here folks - food is great, Adam the owner/operator treats you like family the minute you walk in until you're out the door.  Everything you know and love is on the menu, with some really nice surprises, deserts are awesome and they will be adding much more to then menu in the coming weeks and months as they just opened a few months ago.  Mazzat will be on our regular neighborhood stop list - one note if you're driving, parking is tough but not impossible.
author: Matthew B.

description: I visited based on the reviews. I found the food was not well prepared, the rice in my dish was very mushy. Service was slow, waiter forgot to ask if I wanted any drinks.
author: Charles B.

description:
A small, friendly place with terrific food and excellent service.   We ordered an appetizer plate + a small pizza-like appetizer with chicken for my husband (I'm a vegetarian).   All the spices and flavors in each dish seemed to merge perfectly.   I tried just the crust of my husband's pizza.  With a little feta on top, it was crisp and delicious.  Mazzat's version of moussaka is very different from the Greek but even tastier, and almost velvety in texture.

Combined with cool, dry Lebanese white wine it was truly a meal to die for.  We eat a lot of Middle Eastern and Greek food, so our palates can get a little jaded.  But we fell in love with Mazzat and will return as soon as we can.
author: Kellin D.

description:
Unfortunately I don't remember what We ordered. We ordered lots of different dishes that night. They were very accommodating and made us a breakfast item not on the dinner menu. It was a Fava Bean breakfast dish with lots of vegetables, lots of garlic, olive oil, lemon slightly warmed. So good. It was amazing!  The hot chocolate was good. We had three other dishes, all DE-lish. Although the wine selection is ok. Their location was just off the Hayes Street hustle. 
I recommend a try, maybe become a regular.  Fresh tasty food and friendly staff.
author: flashegirl e.

description:
First restaurant I've fallen in love with since moving to Hayes Valley.

The owners are kind and courteous. The cooks wave at me every time I pick up my to-go orders. 

I've tried Hayes and Kebab and the other place further down on Hayes and neither of them measured up in taste and quality. I love falafel and their competitors sandwiches are made with inferior bread that flakes apart and the falafel is in chunks instead of a tasty morsel. I usually get an order of Hummus or Tabbouleh on the side as well and they are also excellent. 

Proof is in the pudding. Stop by and try it out for yourself.
author: Mike F.

description: Stopped in the other night for a quick dinner and got a mezze platter for one (it's not listed on the menu for 1 person, but they'll make it).  They were super accomodating (letting me get soup as one of my six choices) and the food was very very good.  Portions are huge so I was able to take some home for lunch the next day.  The platter also comes with a healthy serving of olives (yum!). The owner was super friendly and attentive (even though the place was filled to capacity (including the outdoor seating).  Considering they just opened ten days ago, they really impressed me.  Plus, they serve complimentary little bite-sized dessert tastings after your meal!  I'll be back... weekly.
author: leah w.

description: Loved it. Best kibe I've ever had (and I've had a lot of it in my life). Would definitely go back.
author: Tatiana C.

description: Authentic middle eastern food, great atmosphere, and not expensive. What else do you want? Highly recommended for a quick lunch, or business meeting over tasty Lebanese tapas.
author: Daniel K.

description: The owner was a great guy and all of the staff were extremely friendly. I didn't know what to order, but the owner recommended trying the 3 hot/3 cold combination deal and suggested particular dishes that Mazzat does best. The dishes were all healthy and fresh, the restaurant was very clean, and the food was authentic. I will be going back for the food and friendly service very soon. Not to be missed!
author: Paige G.

description: Having several chefs in the family I feel confident in giving this eatery two thumbs up.  I Have eaten there at least 5 times and I come back with wanting to return soon! My Lebanese friends all feel the same way.  Simple, delicious, well-prepared and presented.....and the prices are very reasonable.
author: phil s.

description: I am confused by the high star ratings for this place. Have these folks never had Lebanese or Middle Eastern food before?  One review talked about the amazing Mousaka. Cut up pieces of eggplant with tomato sauce is a far cry from what I know Mousaka to be. They sure keep to their 10 pm Saturday night close. We were seated at 9:40 pm and at 10:10 asked to lift our legs for them to sweep.  I am NOT exaggerating. I want to love this place so bad - it's 2 block away from my house. Guess I'll have to walk another block to the other Middle Eastern restaurant in Hayes Valley. Or walk another two blocks for the third middle eastern restaurant in Hayes Valley.  What's up with middle eastern food and Hayes Valley?
author: Howard G.

description: I tried to visit Suppenkuche but the line was an hour long and we did not want to wait. So we walked one block to Fell street looking for a place to munch and saw a sign on a corner of Fell & Laguna for Lebanese cousine. It looked attractive inside and we decided to check this out. We were not disappointed. The owner greeted us and explained what she has on a menu; we opted for a plate of 6 appetizers - 3cold and 3 hot for $30. I eat a lot of Middle Eastern Food but I must say this is one of the best prepared dishes I had in a long time. We tried hummus with beef, fried salumi cheeze,babaganush,dolmas, egglant with yougurt and tabuleh. All were very flavourful with elegant hint of lemon and spices.. Eggplant with yougurt had a fantastic crunchy taste to it. All dishes are freshly prepared on premises by owner. We completed our meal with two cups of excellent turkish coffee each and could not escape a tempation of a slice of a fresh baklava that was not one of too sticky variety but just right - lightly sweetened with a layer of tasty chopped nuts. If I were not dieting, I would eat the entire plate of these but got to leave some for other happy diners.
author: Alex k.

description: I am giving this cozy place 5 stars because of the entire experience I've been having since I first came to dine here. I mostly come here for business group meetings, every time with new clients, and they all always love the experience. I came here also with some Middle Eastern friends and they also loved the Mazzat experience. It's hard to find a place that will make you feel as if you're really dining somewhere in Lebanon. The owner Adam and his staff are warmly welcoming from when you step in until you leave. Generosity is felt all the time at this restaurant. Almost every time I've been here (7-8 times), Adam offered us either wine, or some fresh appetizer, or a desert for FREE. Super generous spirit that makes you feel at home. The food at Mazzat is always getting better every time, keeping in mind that they are the only Lebanese cuisine in the area...I can see here on yelp some people criticizing their food, and I am Lebanese myself and grew up eating this food. I see that their food is authentic and has definitely gotten better and better every time, so I am sure that at one point they will be the most authentic Lebanese cuisine in the Bay area. But the most important thing is not only the food, it's the entire experience you feel since you step in this warm ambience. You feel so welcomed and well taking care of, something that everyone wants to feel when dining out. Every one of my customers and friends that dined at Mazzat shared similar opinion about the Lebanese experience they all have here. And not to mention, their Lebanese wine takes me back straight to the green mountains of Lebanon, absolutely the best! Thanks Mazzat for bringing Lebanon to San Francisco, I will be coming again and again to what I call, the Lebanese house of generosity :)
author: Ron D.

description: The food here is very good with a definite Lebanese flair. For those that don't know, the tastes and spices used to prepare dishes vary wildly across Middle Eastern/Mediterranean food.  Moroccan, Lebanese, Turkish, Iranian/Persian- (and shhh..Greek- but don't tell them that, it's a sore spot from the ottoman empire) can make a huge difference- even in foods with the same name, like kebabs or kufte or baklava. The place is quaint and the service was excellent with a family relaxed feel- as opposed to high end being catered to. Don't leave without trying their kebbeh and I highly recommend the tasting plates ($15) and their labneh (kefir cheese) was great too!
author: N A.

description: Love love LOVE this place. The food is FANTASTIC, fresh and flavorful....some of the best shwarmas in the Bay Area. Service is great, the owners are incredibly friendly and attentive. It can get crowded on weekends but totally worth it. In terms of food, I would highly recommend the fatet betinjan and hummus for appetizers. For the main meal,  the chicken shwarma and kafta are divine! Amazing lebanese food. Will be coming back again and again :)
author: Rabia K.

description: A little slice of Lebanon in SF! If you love middle eastern flavors then go here! Loved the personable manner of the owner who made it really worth the trip! Gave us suggestions and even gave complimentary semolina dessert! The service and food were both excellent. Try the falafel, fried eggplant and hummus for sure and cool to see a selection of Lebanese wine! Also love the concept of tapas to try many more options and quite frankly not overpriced. Very simple but clean layout! Will be returning for sure!
author: sue c.

description: Food is so good!!! We had, an appetizer, something as fried eggplant, in yogurt- deliscious as it gets! We also ordered traditional lebanese pizza (it was with chicken, feta and artichoke), it was amazing and nothing to compare with pizza we all used too. it is small though. We also ordered an entree, the one that server recommended, it was rice with chicken- amazing. rice had a cinnamon flavour, and had yogurt on side, with fresh cucumbers in it... again, very tasty! and extremely cheap-  the dinner with drinks was around 50$... and for dinner for two- it's pretty affordable! great experience. service was great too!
author: Alex F.

description: Great food, and a great environment. It's a true pleasure to finally have such a great Lebanese place in SF.
author: Samer E.

description: Went to Mazzat tonight based on Yelp reviews.  Overall, we had a solid meal.  The Falafel was excellent as was the Tibouli and Hummas.  The other food was good, but not spectacular.  The service was very good and the atmosphere was nice.  It was also a pretty value for money.  It didn't blow us away, but it was well worth going.
author: Scott B.

description: My daughter wanted to try this restaurant, so we met friends there....and were NOT disappointed!!!  From the Lebanese wine(very light and refreshing) to the baklava(the best I have had in years) we all enjoyed every bite...two mazzat platters and entrees so we tried a little of everything.  I have been promised a table when I am next in town...it helps to have "connections"....thanx!!!
author: Carrie K.

description: Dropped in after seeing this pleasant looking restaurant every time I drove down Laguna.  As I suspected for its appearance, it was quite good.  The coffee (and I only had plain American) was exceptionally good, the meat filled pastries pie-lets delicious and tasting of fresh flavorful tomatoes, the Babba Gahnouj delcious and a generous portion and the lentil soup very fresh and tasting of lentils not overwhelmed by spicing.    Best of all for me was that this small attractive restaurant had quiet lovely background music from the Middle East and was quiet enough for comfortable conversation (a rarity in San Francisco) despite our presence there during the center of the lunch hour.  The menu is small and probably not suited for a large meal but lovely for snacks or lunch or a light dinner.
author: Lee R.

description: Friends and I were wandering Hayes Valley looking for a fun new place for dinner.  We came across Mazzat and the fun ambiance and interesting menu drew us in.  Suzi, one of the owners, waited on us. Recipes are hers... And we shared the Mezzat platter of tastes.  Delicious!! As were the desserts!  She and her husband Adam give the restaurant its welcoming, warm and lively personality.  Highly recommend it!  JK San Francisco
author: J K.

description: I rarely review restaurants but this one I had to give it a 5 stars! As a Lebanese native, I can say that the food at Mazzat is the most authentic Lebanese food you could get in the Bay Area and believe me I have tried many Mediterranean restaurants and nothing comes close to this one! We were a group of 12 people and not a single person left anything in her/his place it was so good! We were all so full by the end of the dinner and I could not believe that we just payed $25/person even though we had ordered wine and beer too. Keep it going Mazzat!!!
author: Sami A.

description: Two friends and I had plans to dine before a concert on Saturday night, and Mazzat was close to the Herbst Theatre. The three of us were seated at a table that was approximately two feet by two feet, i.e. it was basically a cocktail table.  we were constantly juggling dishes throughout the meal.For a restaurant that serves multiple small plates to have such small tables displays poor planning.  The waiter was not able to tell us anything about the two Lebanese red wines, other than one was more dry than the other. We had a bottle that was decent, but tasted similar to a Sangiovese that one can but at Trader Joe's for $3. This bottle cost $40. I'm prepared to pay a mark-up for wine at a restaurant, but this was beyond reason. The fava bean preparation may have had too much vinegar, as it tasted almost as if it had been left in the back of the refrigerator for a week. The grape leaves were passable, but again, no better than other preparations that I have elsewhere enjoyed at a lower price. The eggplant in pomegranate sauce was mushy, and almost devoid of flavor. The chicken shawerma was little more than cubes of chicken rolled up into a pita, and toasted. It was dry, and again had no discernible flavor. Finally, we were constantly being interrupted by a staffer asking if things were alright. I can understand making the effort to ensure that customers are happy, but after eight times, when conversation was repeatedly disrupted by someone not waiting for at least a pause in our talking, it was pretty annoying. I don't think that I'll return.
author: John S.
